blurb: There are things in the world considered to be unsurpassed, but none of them compare with the Dhamma.

title: Các Căn
blurb: A mendicant is worthy of gifts because of six faculties.

title: Hữu Học
blurb: Things leading to decline or non-decline.

title: Không Thối Ðọa (1)
blurb: A god speaks on things leading to decline or non-decline.

title: Không Thối Ðọa (2)
blurb: The Buddha recounts the events of the previous discourse.

title: Ðại Mục Kiền Liên
blurb: Mahāmoggallāna is visited by a Brahmā god who had formerly been a mendicant, and they discuss which of the gods are stream-enterers.

title: Minh Phần
blurb: Six kinds of perception that lead to wisdom.

title: Gốc Rễ Của Ðấu Tranh
blurb: If a mendicant nurses six kinds of defilements it leads to bitterness and disputes in the Saṅgha.

title: Bố Thí
blurb: Seeing the laywoman Veḷukaṇṭakī preparing a meal for the Saṅgha, the Buddha celebrated by saying that giving is of great benefit when the donor and the recipient each possess three qualities.

title: Tự Làm
blurb: The Buddha rebuts a brahmin’s claim that there is no such thing as actions initiated by oneself.

title: Nhân Duyên
blurb: Greed, hate, and delusion are the roots of deeds.

title: Tôn Giả Kimbila
blurb: The Buddha explains to Venerable Kimbila the reasons why Buddhism lasts long after the Buddha’s demise.

title: Các Lực
blurb: A mendicant is worthy of gifts because of six powers.

title: Ðống Gỗ
blurb: Even a simple block of wood can be perceived in different ways by a mendicant with advanced meditation.

title: Tôn Giả Nagita
blurb: When visited by a noisy crowd, the Buddha speaks to his attendant Nāgita of his love of seclusion and solitude, and of his regard for forest mendicants.

title: Con Voi
blurb: When going for a bath, the Buddha encounters a giant royal elephant. But a spiritual giant is even more impressive.

title: Migasàlà
blurb: In response to criticism, the Buddha explains that it is difficult to compare the spiritual development of different individuals, so we should not be judgmental.

title: Nghèo Khổ
blurb: Poor people suffer when they get in debt. Spiritual practitioners who are devoid of good qualities suffer in a similar way.

title: Mahàcunda
blurb: In a discourse evidently set some time after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Mahācunda urges different groups of meditators, whether they emphasize serenity or insight, to respect and support each other.

title: Cho Ðời Này (1)
blurb: The Buddha explains to the wanderer Moliyasīvaka how the teaching may be realized in the present life.

title: Cho Ðời Này (2)
blurb: The Buddha explains a brahmin how the teaching may be realized in the present life.

title: Khema
blurb: Two monks separately come to the Buddha and speak of awakening in terms of letting go conceit. The Buddha affirms that they are, in fact, awakened, and that such indirect means are the proper way to make such declarations.

title: Các Căn
blurb: Just as a tree without leaves cannot grow, sense restraint is the foundation for spiritual growth.

title: Con Ngựa Thuần Chủng (1)
blurb: A steed is worthy of the king for six reasons, and a mendicant is worthy for six similar reasons.

title: Ananda
blurb: Venerables Ānanda and Sāriputta discuss how a mendicant can further their learning and understanding.

title: Vị Sát Ðế Lỵ
blurb: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇī the ambition, quest, commitment, insistence, and ultimate goal of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, women, bandits, and ascetics.

title: Không Phóng Dật
blurb: With a series of vivid similes, the Buddha shows how diligence leads to benefits in both this life and the next.

title: Dhammika
blurb: The monk Dhammika annoys both the monks and the layfolk so badly that they banish him. He comes to the Buddha, who consoles him and raises his spirits with a story, while at the same time showing him the error of his ways.

title: Sona
blurb: When Venerable Soṇa thinks of disrobing, the Buddha comes and encourages him with the famous simile of the lute that is tuned neither too loose nor too tight.

title: Phagguna
blurb: The Buddha consoles Venerable Phagguṇa on his deathbed, and he dies at peace. The Buddha then explains to Ānanda the benefits of hearing the Dhamma at the right time.

title: Sáu Sanh Loại
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about the six classes of people described by the rival ascetic Pūraṇa Kassapa. The Buddha rejects them, and proposes an alternate scheme, emphasizing the importance ones deeds in this life.

title: Các Lậu Hoặc
blurb: The Buddha explains diverse methods for overcoming diverse kinds of defilements.

title: Người Bán Củi
blurb: The householder Dārukammika claims to give gifts to arahants. But the Buddha warns him that it’s hard to know who is really an arahant, and encourage him instead to make offerings to the Saṅgha.

title: Hatthisàriputta
blurb: The junior monk Citta Hatthisāriputta rudely interrupts his seniors, and is admonished by Mahākoṭṭhita. His friends speak in his defense, but Mahākoṭṭhita warns them with a long explanation of how hard it is to know another’s mind. Ultimately, Citta disrobes.

title: Con Ngựa Thuần Chủng (2)
blurb: A steed is worthy of the king for six reasons, and a mendicant is worthy for six similar reasons.

title: Con Ðường Ði Ðến Bờ Bên Kia
blurb: Several senior mendicants discuss the “Questions of Metteyya” from the Pārāyana (Snp 5.3). Each propose an interpretation, and they then ask the Buddha. He praises each reading, but gives his own intended meaning.

title: Lời Cảm Hứng
blurb: A monk asks whether, when the Buddha said that Devadatta was going to hell, he was speaking metaphorically. The Buddha castigates him, wondering how anyone could misunderstand such a straightforward statement, and explains how he reads the minds of others and understands where their deeds will lead them.

title: Một Pháp Môn Quyết Trạch
blurb: A detailed analysis of several central themes, including sense perception, feeling, defilements, kamma, etc.

title: Tiếng Rống Con Sư Tử
blurb: The Buddha possesses six spiritual powers that enable him to roar his lion’s roar.

title: Vị Bất Lai
blurb: Six things lead to non-return.

title: A-La-Hán
blurb: Six things lead to perfection.

title: Những Người Bạn
blurb: With bad friends, a mendicant cannot fulfill six good qualities, but with good friends they can.

title: Hội Chúng
blurb: A mendicant who loves to socialize can’t find peace in meditation, but one who loves solitude can.

title: Vị Thiên Nhân
blurb: A god speaks on the factors of non-decline. When the Buddha repeats what he says, Sāriputta gives an explaination.

title: Thần Thông
blurb: Without samādhi or immersion it is impossible to realize the higher truths of the path.

title: Con Ngựa Thuần Chủng (2)
blurb: A steed is worthy of the king for six reasons, and a mendicant is worthy for six similar reasons.

title: Chứng Nhân
blurb: Six qualities that enable a mendicant to gain understanding.

title: Sức Mạnh
blurb: Six qualities that enable a mendicant to gain strength in meditation.

title: Thiền (1)
blurb: Six qualities that enable a mendicant to gain the first absorption.

title: Thiền (2)
blurb: Six qualities that enable a mendicant to gain the first absorption.

title: Khổ
blurb: Six qualities that lead to suffering, and whose absence leads to happiness.

title: A-La-Hán Quả
blurb: Qualities for realizing arahantship.

title: Thượng Nhân Pháp
blurb: Qualities for realizing superhuman states.

title: Lạc Hỷ
blurb: Qualities leading to happiness.

title: Chứng Ðắc
blurb: Qualities for gaining and strengthening good qualities.

title: Lớn Mạnh
blurb: Possessing six qualities a mendicant attains to greatness.

title: Vô Thượng
blurb: Six things that are unsurpassable.

title: Ðịa Ngục
blurb: Things leading to hell or heaven.

title: Ðịa Ngục (2)
blurb: Things leading to hell or heaven.

title: Pháp Tối Thượng
blurb: Things leading to or obstructing the attainment of perfection.

title: Ngày và Ðêm
blurb: Things leading to growth or deterioration by day or night.

title: Mát Lạnh
blurb: Possessing six qualities a mendicant attains to coolness.

title: Chướng Ngại
blurb: Things that enable or obstruct true understanding while listening to the teachings.

title: Nghiệp Chướng
blurb: Things that enable or obstruct true understanding while listening to the teachings.

title: Không Ưa Nghe
blurb: Things that enable or obstruct true understanding while listening to the teachings.

title: Cần Phải Ðoạn Tận
blurb: Requirements for becoming a stream-enterer.

title: Chứng Ðược Ðoạn Tận
blurb: Things given up by a stream-enterer.

title: Tùy Niệm Xứ
blurb: Six topics for recollection.

title: Làm Cho Sanh Khởi
blurb: Things impossible for a stream-enterer.

title: Bậc Ðạo Sư
blurb: Things impossible for a stream-enterer.

title: Hành
blurb: Things impossible for a stream-enterer.

title: Mẹ
blurb: Things impossible for a stream-enterer.

title: Tự Làm
blurb: Things impossible for a stream-enterer.

title: Sự Xuất Hiện
blurb: Things rare to find in the world.

title: Các Lợi Ích
blurb: Benefits of stream-entry.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: A mendicant on the path cannot see any condition as permanent.

title: Khổ
blurb: A mendicant on the path cannot see any condition as pleasurable.

title: Xan Tham
blurb: The fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, envy, and stinginess.

title: Ðược Ái Mộ (1)
blurb: Seven qualities that make a mendicant either agreeable or disagreeable to their fellow monastics.

title: Tùy Miên(1)
blurb: The underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

title: Tùy Miên (2)
blurb: The purpose of the spiritual life is to give up the underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

title: Gia Ðình
blurb: Factors that make a family worth visiting.

title: Các Hạng Người
blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

title: Ví Dụ Nước
blurb: Seven people found in the world who are like those in water.

title: Không Thường Xuyên
blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

title: Khổ, Vô Ngã, Tịch Tịnh
blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

title: Khổ, Vô Ngã, Tịch Tịnh
blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

title: Khổ, Vô Ngã, Tịch Tịnh
blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

title: Sự Thù Diệu
blurb: A mendicant with seven qualities is qualified to graduate.

title: Ðược Ái Mộ(2)
blurb: Seven qualities that make a mendicant either agreeable or disagreeable to their fellow monastics.

title: Tại Sàrandada
blurb: The Buddha teaches the seven principles of non-decline to the Licchavis at the Sārandada shrine near Vesālī.

title: Vassakàra
blurb: King Ajātasattu of Magadha wishes to invade the Vajjians, and sends his minister Vassakāra to tell the Buddha of his intentions. The Buddha recalls the time he taught the seven principles of non-decline to the Vajjians.

title: Vị Tỷ Kheo
blurb: The Buddha teaches the seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

title: Công Việc
blurb: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

title: Tin Tưởng
blurb: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

title: Giác Chi
blurb: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

title: Tưởng
blurb: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

title: Hữu Học
blurb: Seven qualities leading to the decline of a mendicant who is a trainee.

title: Thối Ðọa
blurb: Seven qualities leading to the decline of a lay follower.

title: Bất Hạnh Thối Ðọa
blurb: Seven failures for a lay follower.

title: Các Sức Mạnh Tóm Tắt
blurb: The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.

title: Bất Hạnh Thối Ðọa
blurb: Seven ruins for a lay follower.

title: Không Phóng Dật
blurb: A god speaks of the the seven principles of non-decline to the Buddha, who repeats it to the mendicants.

title: Xấu Hổ
blurb: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.

title: Dễ Nói (1)
blurb: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.

title: Dễ Nói (2)
blurb: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god. Sāriputta offers additional explanation.

title: Bạn Hữu(1)
blurb: When a friend has seven factors, one should associate with them.

title: Bạn Hữu (2)
blurb: When a mendicant has seven factors, one should stay close to them even if they send you away.

title: Vô Ngại Giải
blurb: With seven qualities, a mendicant will soon realize the four kinds of textual analysis.

title: Vô Ngại Giải
blurb: With seven qualities, Sāriputta realized the four kinds of textual analysis.

title: Ðiều Phục
blurb: Seven qualities leading to mastery of meditation.

title: Các Sức Mạnh rộng Thuyết
blurb: The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.

title: Ðiều Phục
blurb: With seven qualities, Sāriputta became a master of meditation.

title: Sự Thù Diệu (1)
blurb: Sāriputta visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.

title: Sự Thù Diệu (2)
blurb: Ānanda visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.

title: Thức Trú
blurb: Seven planes of consciousness in which beings may be reborn.

title: Tư Lương Cho Ðịnh
blurb: The path factors are the prerequisite for right immersion.

title: Lửa (1)
blurb: Seven fires, some physical, some psychological.

title: Lửa (2)
blurb: The brahmin Uggatasarīra has arranged a great sacrifice. On Ānanda’s advice, he asks the Buddha how to make a sacrifice beneficial.

title: Tưởng (1)
blurb: Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in brief.

title: Tưởng (2)
blurb: Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in detail.

title: Dâm Dục
blurb: The brahmin Jāṇussoṇī asks the Buddha about behaviors that are a blemish to the celibate life.

title: Các Tài Sản Tóm Tắt
blurb: The wealth of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

title: Hệ Lụy
blurb: By focusing on their own gendered attributes, a man or woman becomes attached to them and develops lust for the opposite sex.

title: Bố Thí
blurb: The lay followers of Campā seek a teaching from the Buddha. Together with Sāriputta, they ask the Buddha about what makes a gift fruitful.

title: Mẹ Của Nanda
blurb: Sāriputta and Moggallāna are on tour in the southern hills. A deity informs the laywoman Veḷukaṇṭakī that they are approaching. When Sāriputta expresses his amazement that she speaks with the gods, she goes on to list many other of her own amazing qualities.

title: Không Tuyên Bố
blurb: The Buddha explains why a noble disciple has no doubt when it comes to the unexplained points.

title: Sanh Thú Của Loài Người
blurb: Seven kinds of rebirth for non-returners, as well as extinguishment by not grasping.

title: Tissa
blurb: Two gods come to the Buddha on Vulture’s Peak and declare that the nuns are liberated. Moggallāna interrogates one of the deities on what he means, and the Buddha adds further explanation.

title: Sìha
blurb: The Buddha explains the benefits of giving that are visible in the present life, and one that is only apparent in the next.

title: Không Có Che Ðậy
blurb: Four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide, and three ways he is irreproachable.

title: Kimbila
blurb: Venerable Kimbila asks the Buddha the reasons for the long-lasting of Buddhism after the Buddha’s demise.

title: Bảy Pháp
blurb: Qualities required for arahantship.

title: Các Tài Sản Rộng Thuyết
blurb: The wealth of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

title: Ngủ Gục
blurb: Before his awakening, Moggallāna is struggling with sleepiness in meditation. The Buddha visits him and gives seven ways to dispel drowsiness, and other important teachings.

title: Thắng Tri Tham (3)
blurb: Develop insight into greed through the awakening factors.

title: Thắng Tri Tham (3)
blurb: Develop insight into greed through seven perceptions starting with impermanence.

title: Thắng Tri Tham (3)
blurb: Develop insight into greed through seven perceptions starting with ugliness.

title: ─644. Thắng Tri Tham (3)
blurb: Develop complete understanding, etc., of greed.

title: Ngủ Gục
blurb: The incalculable benefits of merit that last for many aeons.

title: Các Người Vợ
blurb: Anāthapiṇḍika’s home was in an uproar due to the badly behaved Sujātā, newly wedded to one of his sons. The Buddha speaks to her on the different kinds of wives.

title: Sân Hận
blurb: When someone is angry, they wish ill upon their enemy, and are disappointed if they do well. This sutta includes a powerful set of verses.

title: Thắng Tri Tham (4)
blurb: Develop complete understanding, etc., of hate, etc.

title: Xấu Hổ
blurb: A sense of conscience is the foundation that leads step by step to liberation.

title: Mặt Trời
blurb: A rare discourse on cosmic evolution. The Buddha describes the successive appearance of seven suns and how even the earth will be burned up.

title: Thành Trì
blurb: When a king’s fortress is well supplied with seven things and has four kinds of food supplies it is impregnable. Similarly, a noble disciple with seven qualities and the four absorptions is impregnable.

title: Pháp Trí
blurb: A mendicant who has seven qualities is worthy, with a special emphasis on listening to and learning the teaching.

title: Cây Kovilàra Pàricchattaka
blurb: The blossoming of the Shady Orchid Tree delights the gods of the Thirty-Three, and in the same way, the renunciation of a Buddhist ascetic is delightful.

title: Vị Tỷ Kheo Phải Kính Trọng Ai?
blurb: Sāriputta reflects on what a mendicant should revere in order to develop the wholesome. He reports to the Buddha that these things are indeed found in himself.

title: Ugga
blurb: Migāra of Rohaṇa is a wealthy man, but even his riches are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of life, unlike spiritual wealth.

title: Sự Tu Tập
blurb: Liberation doesn’t happen because you wish for it, but because you develop the path.

title: Lửa
blurb: It would be better for a monk to embrace a blazing fire than to lie with a maiden.

title: Sunetta
blurb: There have been many great teachers in the past, who should not be reviled. But reviling a single noble disciple is even more serious.

title: Araka
blurb: Araka was a famous teacher long ago, when the life span was much greater than today. Nevertheless, he still taught impermanence; how much more is it relevant today!

title: Trì Luật (1)
blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

title: Trì Luật 2)
blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

title: Trì Luật (3)
blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

title: Trì Luật (4)
blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

title: Chói Sáng
blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

title: Chói Sáng
blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

title: Các Kiết Sử
blurb: The fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

title: Chói Sáng
blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

title: Chói Sáng
blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

title: Thông Ðiệp
blurb: The Buddha teaches the Vinaya expert Upāli a short summary of the teaching.

title: Diệt Tránh Pháp
blurb: Seven principles for settling issues and disputes that have arisen in the community.

title: Sự Phá Hoại
blurb: A mendicant destroys seven defilements.

title: Các Pháp Khác
blurb: An ascetic  destroys seven defilements.

title: Các Pháp Khác
blurb: A brahmin destroys seven defilements.

title: Các Pháp Khác
blurb: A scholar destroys seven defilements.

title: Các Pháp Khác
blurb: A bathed initiate destroys seven defilements.

title: Các Pháp Khác
blurb: A knowledge master destroys seven defilements.

title: Ðoạn Tận
blurb: The purpose of the spiritual life is to give up the fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

title: Các Pháp Khác
blurb: A noble one destroys seven defilements.

title: Các Pháp Khác
blurb: A perfected one destroys seven defilements.

title: Phi Diệu Pháp
blurb: Seven bad qualities starting with faithlessness.

title: Diệu Pháp
blurb: Seven good qualities starting with faith.

title: Người Xứng Ðáng Ðược Cung Kính
blurb: Seven people worthy of offerings due to observing impermanence in the eye.
Seven people worthy of offerings due to observing suffering, etc., in the eye, etc.

title: Các Ðồ Rác
blurb: When a certain monk was admonished, he responded by attacking his reprovers. The Buddha tells the other monks to expel him, explaining that when such a monk lives hidden in the Saṅgha, his corruption can spread to the other monks.

title: Từ
blurb: The eight benefits of practicing the meditation on love.

title: Veranjà
blurb: The brahmin Verañja rebukes the Buddha for his lack of respect for senior brahmins. He levels a series of criticisms, each of which the Buddha deflects by redefining terms. The Buddha affirms that his claim to superiority is because he was the first to achieve awakening.

title: Tướng Quân Sìha
blurb: General Sīha, a prominent disciple of the Jains, visits the Buddha against the wishes of Mahāvīra, the Jain leader. He challenges the Buddha by bringing up the various ways that people criticize him. Convinced by the Buddha’s response, Sīha wishes to take refuge in the Buddha; but the Buddha urges him to be cautious and to continue supporting the Jains.

title: Con Ngựa Thuần Thục
blurb: With eight qualities a royal thoroughbred is worthy of a king. Likewise, with eight qualities a mendicant is worthy.

title: Ngựa Chưa Ðiều Phục
blurb: Eight flaws in wild horses, similar to eight flaws in mendicants.

title: Các Cấu Uế
blurb: Eight different kinds of stain.

title: Sứ Giả
blurb: A mendicant with eight qualities is worthy of being sent on a mission.

title: Sự Trói Buộc Của Nữ Nhân
blurb: A woman imprisons a man in eight ways.

title: Nam Nhân Trói Buộc
blurb: A man imprisons a woman in eight ways.

title: A-Tu-La Pahàràda
blurb: Demons delight in the ocean for eight reasons, and likewise the mendicants delight in the Dhamma for eight reasons.

title: Ngày Trai Giới
blurb: On a full-moon night, the Buddha was to recite the code of conduct for the monks. However, he remained silent until dawn, due to the presence of a corrupt monk.

title: Tuệ
blurb: Eight conditions that lead to the arising of wisdom, its growth and perfection.

title: Ugga Ở Vesali
blurb: The Buddha celebrates the eight amazing qualities of the householder Ugga of Vesālī. Ugga himself speaks of these qualities.

title: Ugga Người Hatthigama
blurb: The Buddha celebrates the eight amazing qualities of the householder Ugga of Hatthigāma. Ugga himself speaks of these qualities.

title: Hatthaka , Người Alavì (1)
blurb: The Buddha celebrates the seven amazing qualities of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī. When he hears of this, Hatthaka is anxious to know that no lay people were present. Learning of this, the Buddha adds humility as an eight quality.

title: Hatthaka, Người Xứ ALavì (2)
blurb: The Buddha learns from Hatthaka of Āḷavī how he maintains a large following. He then celebrates Hatthaka’s eight good qualities.

title: Thích Tử Mahanama
blurb: Questioned by his relative Mahānāma, the Buddha explains what makes someone a Buddhist lay follower, a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower practicing for the welfare of all.

title: Jìvaka Komàrabhacca
blurb: Questioned by Jīvaka Komārabhacca, the Buddha explains what makes someone a Buddhist lay follower, a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower practicing for the welfare of all.

title: Sức Mạnh (1)
blurb: Eight very different kinds of powers.

title: Sức Mạnh (2)
blurb: Eight powers of a perfected one.

title: Không Phải Thời
blurb: Eight lost opportunities for spiritual practice.

title: Tôn Giả Anuruddha
blurb: Venerable Anuruddha reflects that the teachings is for someone who is of few wishes, content, secluded, energetic, mindful, peaceful, and wise. To these seven thoughts, the Buddha adds an eighth: the teaching is for those who delight in non-proliferation. Practicing in line with these eight thoughts of a great man, Venerable Anuruddha achieves perfection.

title: Các Pháp Không Ðược Ái Mộ (1)
blurb: Due to eight qualities, a mendicant is displeasing to their fellow monastics, but with the opposite qualities is pleasing.

title: Bố Thí (1)
blurb: Eight ways of giving a gift.

title: Bố Thí (2)
blurb: This verse on qualities of a good person appears to be a fragment of text, perhaps originally part of the previous sutta.

title: Căn Bản Ðể Bố Thí
blurb: Eight grounds for giving.

title: Thửa Ruộng
blurb: The rewards of giving are compared to fields of different qualities.

title: Thọ Sanh Do Bố Thí
blurb: When giving, if you expect a certain result in the next life, you can get it, if the conditions are right.

title: Phước Nghiệp Sự
blurb: The good deeds of giving, ethics, and meditation lead to good rebirths, depending on the level to which they are developed.

title: Người Chân Nhân (1)
blurb: A good person gives gifts in eight ways.

title: Người Chân Nhân (2)
blurb: When a good person is born, it benefits eight kinds of people, like a rain-cloud showering all over the land.

title: Nguồn Nước Công Ðức
blurb: Eight streams of merit, consisting in going for refuge and five kinds of gifts.

title: Rất Là Nhẹ
blurb: Eight kinds of misdeed are conducive to bad outcomes.

title: Các Pháp Không Ðược Ái Mộ (2)
blurb: Due to eight qualities, a mendicant is displeasing to their fellow monastics, but with the opposite qualities is pleasing.

title: Các Trai Giới
blurb: When the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Such a sabbath is glorious.

title: Ngày Trai Giới
blurb: When the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. The benefits are explained at length.

title: Visàkhà
blurb: The Buddha teaches the wealthy laywoman Visākhā that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones.

title: Vàsettha
blurb: The Buddha teaches the layman Vāseṭṭha that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Vāseṭṭha exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.

title: Bojjhà
blurb: The Buddha teaches the laywoman Bojjhā that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Bojjhā exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.

title: Tôn Gỉả Anuruddha
blurb: Some “Agreeable” gods put on a display of music and dance for Venerable Anuruddha, but he is not impressed. He then asks the Buddha how women are reborn in such a heaven.

title: Visàkhà
blurb: The Buddha teaches the laywoman Visākhā eight qualities through which a woman may be reborn among the Agreeable gods.

title: Nakulamàtà
blurb: The Buddha teaches the housewife Nakulamātā eight qualities through which a woman may be reborn among the Agreeable gods.

title: Ở Ðời Này
blurb: The Buddha teaches the laywoman Visākhā four qualities through which a woman succeeds in this life, and four through which she succeeds in the next.

title: Ðời Này
blurb: The Buddha teaches the mendicants four qualities through which a woman succeeds in this life, and four through which she succeeds in the next.

title: Tùy Chuyển Thế Giới (1)
blurb: The eight worldly conditions in brief: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.

title: Mahàpajàpatì Gotamì
blurb: Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī, the Buddha’s foster mother, requests ordination from the Buddha. He declines, until urged to relent by Ānanda. He allows Mahāpajāpatī to go forth on eight conditions.

title: Ai Giáo Giới?
blurb: With eight qualities a monk may be appointed to teach the nuns.

title: Pháp Tóm Tắt
blurb: Mahāpajāpatī wishes to go on retreat, so the Buddha teaches her eight principles that summarize the Dhamma in brief.

title: Dìghajanu, Người Koliya
blurb: Dīghajāṇu of the Koliyans asks the Buddha to teach in a way suitable for lay people who enjoy life. The Buddha teaches four practical ways to ensure success in this life, and another four ways to ensure success in the next.

title: Bà-La-Môn Ujjaya
blurb: The brahmin Ujjaya is going abroad, and asks the Buddha to teach him. The Buddha teaches four practical ways to ensure success in this life, and another four ways to ensure success in the next.

title: Sợ Hãi
blurb: The Buddha explains how addiction to sensual pleasures is perilous.

title: Xứng Ðáng Ðược Cúng Dường (1)
blurb: With eight qualities, a mendicant is worthy.

title: Xứng Ðáng Ðược Cúng Dường (2)
blurb: With eight qualities, a mendicant is worthy.

title: Tám Hạng Người (1)
blurb: Eight kinds of person are worthy.

title: Tám Hạng Người (2)
blurb: Eight kinds of person are worthy.

title: Tùy Chuyẻn Thế Giới (2)
blurb: The eight worldly conditions in detail: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.

title: Dục
blurb: The Buddha describes eight cases where a mendicant has a desire for material things. Sometimes they fall under the sway of that desire, but sometimes they rise above it.

title: Vừa Ðủ
blurb: Eight sets of qualities pertain to benefiting oneself and others.

title: Pháp Lược Thuyết
blurb: A monk asks for teachings before going on retreat, but the Buddha rebukes him, as he has not practiced sincerely. Nevertheless, he persists, and the Buddha teaches him meditation in detail.

title: Tagayà
blurb: At Gayā, the Buddha describes his meditation before awakening. He was able to see lights and forms, converse with gods, and understand the deeds that made them gods.

title: Thắng Xứ
blurb: Eight dimensions of meditative mastery, based on the vision of certain shapes and colors.

title: Các Giải Thoát
blurb: Eight meditative liberations, based on the vision of forms and the attainment of the formless.

title: Phi Thánh Ngôn
blurb: Eight kinds of ignoble statement that misrepresent the truth.

title: Thánh Ngôn
blurb: Eight kinds of noble statement that convey the truth.

title: Các Hội Chúng
blurb: Eight kinds of assemblies: aristocrats, brahmins, householders, ascetics, and various deities. The Buddha has visited each of these in disguise.

title: Ðộng Ðất
blurb: When the Buddha gives up his life-force, an earthquake is felt. The Buddha explains to Ānanda the eight causes of earthquakes.

title: Devadatta
blurb: Devadatta’s downfall was the eight worldly conditions.

title: Lòng Tin (1)
blurb: Beginning with faith, a mendicant completes all good qualities that fulfill liberation.

title: Lòng Tin (2)
blurb: Beginning with faith, a mendicant completes all good qualities that fulfill liberation.

title: Niệm Chết (1)
blurb: Various mendicants practice mindfulness of death, but do so inadequately. The Buddha explains how to do so with proper urgency,

title: Niệm Chết (2)
blurb: A mendicant should reflect each night on the dangers that lie around them, and practice mindfulness of death with urgency to give up the unwholesome.

title: Ðầy Ðủ (1)
blurb: Eight accomplishments, both worldly and spiritual.

title: Ðầy Ðủ (2)
blurb: Eight accomplishments, both worldly and spiritual, in detail.

title: Dục
blurb: Sāriputta describes eight cases where a mendicant has a desire for material things. Sometimes they fall under the sway of that desire, but sometimes they rise above it.

title: Vừa Ðủ
blurb: Eight sets of qualities pertain to benefiting oneself and others, explained by Sāriputta.

title: Thối Ðọa
blurb: Eight conditions for the decline or success of a trainee mendicant.

title: Tám Căn Cứ Ðể Biếng Nhác và Tinh Tấn
blurb: Eight grounds for laziness, and the corresponding eight grounds for energy.

title: Tôn Giả Uttara
blurb: In a discourse evidently set some time after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Uttara, staying in a distant land, teaches that a mendicant should review their own failings and those of others. Questioned by Sakka, the Lord of Gods, Uttara affirms that he learned this from the Buddha.

title: Niệm
blurb: Mindfulness and situational awareness are a foundation for developing higher spiritual qualities leading to liberation.

title: Tôn Giả Punniya
blurb: Venerable Puṇṇiya asks the Buddha why he sometimes feels like teaching and other times doesn’t.

title: Cội rễ Của Sự Vật
blurb: The root of all things, and other factors that apply to all things.

title: Ðại Ăn Trộm
blurb: The Buddha teaches how to be a success as a master thief. Unusually, this discourse has no “spiritual” counterpart, so it sounds like the Buddha just giving a lesson in thievery!

title: Người Sa Môn
blurb: Different titles for the Buddha.

title: Ðảnh Lễ
blurb: When the householders of Icchānaṅgala make a racket in the monastery, the Buddha asks his attendant Nāgita what is going on. The Buddha speaks strongly of his dislike for material gains, and his love of seclusion.

title: Bình Bát
blurb: Eight reasons the Saṅgha may overturn the bowl against a lay follower.

title: Phản Ðối
blurb: Eight reasons the lay followers may declare no confidence or confidence regarding a mendicant.

title: Buộc Tội
blurb: Eight reasons the lay followers may enjoin an act of reconciliation on a mendicant, or relax said act.

title: Hành Xử Ðúng Pháp
blurb: Eight things a mendicant charged with aggravated misconduct must observe.

title: Tôn Giả Nanda
blurb: The Buddha praises the grace and restraint of Venerable Nanda.

title: Ðáng Cung Kính
blurb: Nine persons are worthy of gifts: the eight noble persons and a member of the spiritual family.

title: Chánh Giác
blurb: Beginning with good friendship, the Buddha teaches nine things that give rise to the qualities that lead to awakening.

title: Sau Khi An Cư
blurb: After the rains season, Sāriputta takes leave of the Buddha. Another monk falsely accuses Sāriputta of hitting him before leaving. The Buddha calls Sāriputta to answer the accusation. Before the Saṅgha, Sāriputta denies it, uttering a powerful statement of spiritual prowess.

title: Không Có Dư Y
blurb: Sāriputta visits some wanderers, who claim that only perfected ones are free from bad rebirth. Sāriputta has no opinion on this, but asks the Buddha, who replies that even stream-enterers are freed from lower rebirth.

title: Tôn Giả Mahàkotthita
blurb: Venerables Mahākoṭṭhita and Sāriputta discuss whether the spiritual path is for the purpose of changing the results of deeds.

title: Tôn Giả Samiddhi
blurb: Sāriputta questions Venerable Samiddhi on the basis of intentions and thoughts.

title: Một Ung Nhọt
blurb: The body is compared to a boil with nine orifices.

title: Tưởng
blurb: Nine perceptions to be developed in meditation.

title: Gia Ðình
blurb: Nine factors in how a family relates to the Saṅgha.

title: Từ Bi
blurb: Nine factors for a glorious sabbath: the eight precepts and the meditation on love.

title: Chư Thiên
blurb: Some deities come to the Buddha and speak of how their practice in their past life was limited and unsatisfactory.

title: Velàma
blurb: The wealthy and devoted lay supporter Anāthapiṇḍika rather curiously says that only poor alms are given in his home. The Buddha praises gracious and bounteous generosity. But meditation surpasses even the greatest offering.

title: Y Chỉ
blurb: The things that a mendicant relies on as supports in spiritual practice.

title: Trong Ba Phương Diện
blurb: A comparison of the people of India, of Uttarakuru, and of the heaven of the Thirty-Three.

title: Ngựa Chưa Ðược Ðiều Phục
blurb: Nine kinds of horses are compared with nine kinds of monks.

title: Ái
blurb: Nine things that are rooted in craving.

title: Các Loại Hữu Tình
blurb: Nine realms into which sentient beings may be reborn.

title: Trí Tuệ
blurb: Nine reflections by which a mendicant knows their mind has wisdom.

title: Trụ Ðá
blurb: Venerables Candikāputta and Sāriputta differ in their interpretation of a teaching proposed by the notorious schismatic Devadatta.

title: Sợ Hãi Hận Thù (1)
blurb: A householder who has eliminated the perils that come with breaking the five precepts, and possesses the four factors of stream-entry is freed from lower rebirths.

title: Sợ Hãi Hận Thù (2)
blurb: A householder who has eliminated the perils that come with breaking the five precepts, and possesses the four factors of stream-entry is freed from lower rebirths.

title: Xung Ðột Sự
blurb: Nine grounds for resentment.

title: Ðiều Phục Xung Ðột Sự
blurb: Nine ways of removing resentment.

title: Tôn Gỉa Meghiya
blurb: Venerable Meghiya, while attending on the Buddha, wants to go off and meditate in a forest alone. The Buddha discourages him, but he goes anyway. When his meditation doesn’t go well, he returns chastened to the Buddha, who teaches him about the benefits of good companions and other fundamentals of a balanced spiritual practice.

title: Chín Thứ Ðệ Diệt
blurb: Nine meditative states, each of which arises from the cessation of something present in the previous state.

title: Chín Thứ Ðệ Trú (1)
blurb: Nine progressive meditation states.

title: Chín Thứ Ðệ Trú (2)
blurb: Nine progressive meditation states, explained in detail.

title: Niết Bàn
blurb: Sāriputta declares that extinguishment is bliss, precisely because nothing is felt there. He explains this apparent paradox with reference to the nine progressive meditations.

title: Con Bò Cái
blurb: Just as a foolish cow can get in trouble wandering the mountains, a foolish mendicant can get lost practicing absorption if they do it wrongly.

title: Thiền
blurb: The ending of defilements happens due to the practice of absorption meditation.

title: Tôn Giả Ananda
blurb: Ānanda exclaims how amazing it is that the Buddha has found a way to freedom while still experiencing the world. Questioned by the monk Udāyī, Ānanda recounts a discussion on advanced meditation with the nun Jaṭilagāhiyā.

title: Các Bà-La-Môn
blurb: Two brahmin cosmologists ask the Buddha to decide between competing claims as to whether the cosmos is infinite. Rejecting metaphysical claims, the Buddha says that there is no end of the world that can be reached by traveling; but without reaching the end of the world you can’t be free of suffering.

title: Chư Thiên
blurb: In the wars between gods and demons, they find safety only in their own fortress. Similarly, a mendicant finds safety in absorption.

title: Con Voi Lớn
blurb: A bull elephant, annoyed by living in the herd, goes off by himself. Similarly, a mendicant feeling crowded in a monastery goes off by themselves and happily meditates in seclusion.

title: Tôn Giả Nandaka
blurb: Nandaka is teaching the monks when the Buddha arrives. Unbeknown to those inside, the Buddha waits until the talk was finished, then enters. Nandaka is embarrassed at keeping the Buddha waiting, but the Buddha praises him and offers a teaching on the four things a mendicant should complete. Nandaka then teaches five benefits of listening to Dhamma.

title: Tapussa
blurb: The householder Tapussa reflects that it is renunciation that distinguishes lay from monastic. The Buddha responds by giving a long account of his practice of absorption before awakening.

title: Pancalacanda
blurb: At Udāyī’s request, Ānanda explains an obscure verse spoken (in SN 2.7) by a deity. The nine progressive meditations are the escape from confinement.

title: Vị Thân Chứng
blurb: The Buddha speaks of a “direct witness’, that is, someone who personally has thorough and proficient experience of the different meditation states.

title: Tuệ Giải Thoát
blurb: One liberated by wisdom first enters the meditation states, then understands them.

title: Giải Thoát Cả Hai Phần
blurb: One freed both ways is both proficient in and understands the meditation states.

title: Chính Thực Mình Thấy (1)
blurb: The teaching apparent in the present life is experienced provisionally in deep meditation, and completely when the defilements end.

title: Chính Thực Mình Thấy (2)
blurb: Extinguishment apparent in the present life is experienced provisionally in deep meditation, and completely when the defilements end.

title: Những Sức Mạnh
blurb: A noble disciple who develops four powers overcomes five fears.

title: Thiết Thực Hiện Tại Niết Bàn
Cần Phải Thân Cận
blurb: Four kinds of person who one should or should not associate with. A similar distinction is made regarding robes, almsfood, lodgings, towns, and countries.

title: Du Sĩ Sutavà
blurb: The wanderer Sutavā asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine.

title: Du Sĩ Sajjha
blurb: The wanderer Sajjha asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine, which differ slightly from AN 9.7.

title: Các Hạng Người
blurb: Nine kinds of persons: the eight noble persons and the ordinary person.

title: Không Thể Tăng Trưởng
blurb: Ten things must be given up before attaining perfection.

title: Với Các Minh
blurb: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.

title: Ý Nghĩa Gì
blurb: The purpose of ethics, leading step by step to liberation.

title: Tưởng
blurb: Three ascetic perceptions lead to seven results.

title: Giác Chi
blurb: The seven factors of awakening lead to realizing the three knowledges.

title: Tà Tánh
blurb: The tenfold wrong path leads to failure, the tenfold right path leads to success.

title: Chủng Tử
blurb: When a person has wrong view, all their path development is wrong. But when they have right view, everything good follows.

title: Vô Minh
blurb: Ignorance is the precursor of wrong view and the other bad qualities, while right view is the opposite.

title: Nguyên Nhân Khiến Cho Tổn Giảm
blurb: Each of the ten path factors wears away its opposite.

title: Tẩy Trần
blurb: The Buddha speaks of a southern land called “Bath”, but says that a spiritual bath is better.

title: Y Thuật
blurb: The Buddha speaks of a purgative for curing ailments, but says that a spiritual purgative is better.

title: Mửa
blurb: The Buddha speaks of a emetic for curing ailments, but says that a spiritual emetic is better.

title: Bài Tiết
blurb: The ten path factors each expel their opposite.

title: Trú Xứ
blurb: Five factors that a mendicant should have, and five factors of a lodging that they should occupy.

title: Vô Học (1)
blurb: An adept has fulfilled the ten path factors.

title: Vô Học (2)
blurb: An adept has fulfilled the ten path factors.

title: Phi Pháp
blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in brief.

title: Không Phải Mục Ðích
blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in detail.

title: Phi Pháp
blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching. After hearing this in brief from the Buddha, the mendicants seek a detailed answer from Ānanda.

title: Ajita
blurb: The wanderer Ajita informs the Buddha that a philosopher has proposed 500 cases for knowing that and argument has been won or lost. The Buddha asks the mendicants about these.

title: Sangàrava
blurb: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.

title: Bờ Bên Này Và Bờ Bên Kia
blurb: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.

title: Sự Xuất Ly của Bậc Thánh (1)
blurb: The Buddha sees Jāṇussoṇī observing the brahmanical ceremony of “descent”. The Buddha teaches his revised version.

title: Sự Xuất Ly Của Bậc Thánh (2)
blurb: The Buddha teaches his revised version of the brahmanical ceremony of “descent” to the mendicants.

title: Các Chi Phần
blurb: A mendicant should abandon the five hindrances and possess the five factors of the adept.

title: Ðiềm Báo Trước
blurb: As the dawn is the forerunner of the sunrise, right view is the forerunner of the path.

title: Các Lậu Hoặc
blurb: The ten path factors lead to the end of the defilements.

title: Các Kiết Sử
blurb: Five lower and five higher fetters.

title: Mục Ðích và Phi Mục Ðích
Tâm Hoang Vu
blurb: Five kinds of emotional barrenness and five emotional shackles.

title: Hối Hận và Không Hối Hận
Ði Ðến Tích Tập và Không Tích Tập
Khổ Dị Thục và Lạc Dị Thục
Diệu Pháp và Phi Diệu Pháp
Chân Nhân Pháp và Phi Chân Nhân pháp
Cần Khởi Lên và Không Cần Khởi Lên
Cần Phải Thực Hiện và Không Cần Phải Thực Hiện
Không Phóng Dật
blurb: Diligence is the foremost of all good qualities.

title: Cần Phải Tu Tập Và Không Cần Phải Tu Tập
Cần Phải Làm Sung Mãn và Không Cần Phải Làm Sung Mãn
Cần Phải Nhớ và Không Cần Phải Nhớ
Cần Phải Chứng Ngộ và Không Cần Phải Chứng Ngộ
Ðáng Ðược Cúng Dường
blurb: Ten persons who are worthy.

title: Sự Xuất Ly Của Bậc Thánh (1)
blurb: The Buddha sees Jāṇussoṇī observing the brahmanical ceremony of “descent”. The Buddha teaches his revised version.

title: Sự Xuất Ly Của Bậc Thánh (2)
blurb: The Buddha teaches his revised version of the brahmanical ceremony of “descent” to the mendicants.

title: Sangàrava
blurb: The Buddha teaches the brahmin Saṅgārava that the wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.

title: Bờ Bên Này và Bờ Bên Kia
blurb: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.

title: Vị Hộ Trì (1)
blurb: Ten qualities that serve as protector.

title: Pháp và Phi Pháp (1)
blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in brief.

title: Pháp và Phi Pháp (2)
blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching. After hearing this in brief from the Buddha, the mendicants seek a detailed answer from Mahākaccāna.

title: Pháp và Phi Pháp (3)
blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in detail.

title: Do Tham Sân Si
blurb: The various kinds of bad deeds are caused by greed, hate, and delusion.

title: Thoát Ly
blurb: Through the teaching one may avoid the various kinds of bad deeds.

title: Cunda Người Thợ Rèn
blurb: Cunda the smith tells the Buddha of rites of purification practiced by the western brahmins. The Buddha explains purification in his teaching.

title: Jànussoni
blurb: Jāṇussoṇī describes brahmanical memorial rites for the dead, and asks if sharing merit actually benefits dead relatives. The Buddha replies that it might do in some circumstances.

title: Vị Hộ Trì (2)
blurb: Ten qualities that serve as protector, in detail.

title: Thánh Cư (1)
blurb: Ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present and future abide.

title: Thánh Cư (2)
blurb: Ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present and future abide, in detail.

title: Nghĩ Với Dụng Ý
blurb: There’s no need to make a wish to get enlightened; it happens naturally when the conditions are there.

title: Con Sư Tử
blurb: Like a lion, a Realized One roars his preeminence based on ten powers.

title: Ðịa Ngục, Thiên Giới
blurb: The ten kinds of bad deeds lead you to hell; the ten good deeds to heaven.

title: Pháp Môn Quanh Co
blurb: Those who do the ten kinds of bad deeds are like creepy creatures.

title: Ngọc Ma-Ni
blurb: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. This statement precedes a long explanation of deeds and their causes.

title: Tổn Giảm và Tăng Trưởng
blurb: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. This statement precedes a long explanation of deeds and their causes.

title: Phạm Thiên Trú
blurb: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. If one develops the heart’s release through love, no bad deeds can persist there.

title: Sau Khi Chết
blurb: The Buddha teaches a brahmin that bad conduct leads to hell, good conduct to heaven.

title: Những Tuyên Bố về Pháp
blurb: The Buddha claims to be assured regarding the various different doctrinal hypotheses, based on the ten powers.

title: Với Thân
blurb: Some things are to be given by body, others by speech, and still others by wisdom.

title: Maha Cunda
blurb: Venerable Mahācunda teaches that, though a mendicant might claim to be free of greed, hate, and delusion, this is not always the case.

title: Thiền Án Xứ
blurb: Ten universal dimensions of meditation, or kasiṇas.

title: Kalì
blurb: The female lay follower Kāḷī of Kuraraghara in Avantī asks Venerable Mahākaccāna about a verse spoken by the Buddha in “The Maidens’ Questions” (SN 4.25). He replies in terms of the ten universal dimensions of meditation.

title: Những Câu Hỏi Lớn (1)
blurb: Some wanderers claim to teach the direct knowledge of all things, just like the Buddha. However the Buddha disputes this by presenting ten “Great Questions” that they cannot answer.

title: Những Câu Hỏi Lớn (2)
blurb: Some lay people ask the nun from Kajaṅgalā regarding the ten “Great Questions”. Though she has not heard this teaching herself, she explains from her own understanding, and is praised by the Buddha.

title: Người Kosalà
blurb: Starting with a comparison with the King of Kosala, the Buddha teaches a series of ten advanced teachings. He culminates by affirming that he teaches the full understanding of sensual pleasures, forms, and feelings.

title: Kosalà (2)
blurb: King Pasenadi returns victorious from battle and immediately goes to see the Buddha, bowing reverentially to his feet, and declaring ten reasons for his love and devotion to the Buddha.

title: Sở Y
blurb: The Buddha teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.

title: Upàli Và Giới Bổn
blurb: The Buddha teaches Venerable Upāli the ten reasons for establishing the training rules.

title: Người Ðoạn Sự
blurb: Ten reasons for suspending the recitation of the code of conduct.

title: Cụ Túc Giới
blurb: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to be appointed to judge a dispute.

title: Y Chỉ Sa Di
blurb: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to give ordination.

title: Phá Hòa Hợp Tăng
blurb: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to give dependence.

title: Hòa Hợp Tăng
blurb: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to be attended by a novice.

title: Phá Hòa Hợp Tăng
blurb: Ten reasons for schism in the Saṅgha.

title: Quả Của Phá Hòa Hợp Tăng
blurb: Ten reasons for harmony in the Saṅgha.

title: Hòa Hợp Tăng
blurb: The Buddha teaches Ānanda the ten reasons for schism in the Saṅgha, as well as the outcome of causing schism.

title: Quả Do Hòa Hợp Tăng Ðưa Lại
blurb: The Buddha teaches Ānanda the ten reasons for harmony in the Saṅgha, as well as the outcome of creating harmony.

title: Có Sở Y ( Do Sariputta Thuyết)
blurb: Sāriputta teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.

title: Tranh Luận
blurb: Ten reasons for disputes in the Saṅgha.

title: Cội Gốc Của Tranh Luận
blurb: Ten roots for disputes in the Saṅgha.

title: Cội Gốc Của Tranh Luận
blurb: Ten roots for disputes in the Saṅgha.

title: Tại Kusanàrà
blurb: A mendicant who wishes to admonish another should first reflect on five things in themselves and establish a further five.

title: Ði Vào Hậu Cung
blurb: Ten dangers for a monk who enters a royal harem.

title: Các Vị Sakya (Thích tử)
blurb: The Sakyans say that they don’t always observe the eight precepts on the sabbath. The Buddha strongly admonishes them to be more consistent.

title: Mahàli
blurb: Mahāli the Licchavi asks the Buddha for the causes of bad deeds.

title: Các Pháp
blurb: Topics for frequent reflection by one gone forth.

title: Trú Thân
blurb: Ten things that depend on the body.

title: Ðấu Tranh
blurb: Some monks are arguing, so the Buddha teaches them ten warm-hearted principles.

title: Có Sở Y (Do Tôn Giả Ananda Thuyết)
blurb: Ānanda teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.

title: Tâm Của Mình (1)
blurb: The Buddha teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.

title: Tâm Của Mình (2)
blurb: Sāriputta teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.

title: Ðứng Một Chỗ
blurb: The Buddha doesn’t praise stagnation in wholesome qualities, let alone decline.

title: Tịnh Chỉ
blurb: The Buddha teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection. Includes a teaching on various things that should or should not be cultivated.

title: Tổn Giảm
blurb: Sāriputta explains what the Buddha meant by a mendicant who is in decline.

title: Tưởng (1)
blurb: Ten meditative perceptions that lead to the deathless.

title: Tưởng (2)
blurb: Ten meditative perceptions that lead to the deathless.

title: Lấy Căn Bản Nơi Thế Tôn
blurb: The root of all things, and similar principles.

title: Xuất Gia
blurb: Ten reflections that strengthen the mind of a renunciate.

title: Girimananda
blurb: The monk Girimānanda is sick. The Buddha encourages Ānanda to visit him and speak of ten perceptions.

title: Ðịnh Do Bậc Ðạo Sư Thuyết
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a mysterious state of immersion in meditation where there is no normal perception, yet one is still conscious.

title: Vô Minh
blurb: Even though ignorance has no discernible first point, it still has a cause.

title: Hữu Ái
blurb: Even though craving has no discernible first point, it still has a cause.

title: Cứu Cánh
blurb: Those who have certainty in the Buddha may realize the final goal in this life or the next.

title: Bất Ðộng
blurb: Stream-enterers may realize the final goal in this life or the next.

title: Lạc Và Khổ (1)
blurb: Sāriputta explains to the wanderer Sāmaṇḍakāni that rebirth is suffering, freedom from rebirth is happiness.

title: Lạc Và Khổ (2)
blurb: Sāriputta explains to the wanderer Sāmaṇḍakāni that dissatisfaction is suffering, enjoyment is happiness.

title: Tại Nalakapàna (1)
blurb: At Naḷakapāna the Buddha invites Sāriputta to teach. He speaks of ten qualities that lead to decline or non-decline.

title: Nalakapàna (2)
blurb: At Naḷakapāna the Buddha invites Sāriputta to teach. He speaks of ten qualities that lead to decline or non-decline.

title: Những Ðề Tài Câu Chuyện (1)
blurb: The monks are sitting around chatting about this and that. The Buddha admonishes them and teaches ten topics of conversation suitable for mendicants.

title: Những Ðề Tài Câu Chuyện (2)
blurb: The monks are sitting around chatting about this and that. The Buddha admonishes them and teaches ten grounds of praise.

title: Ðịnh Do Tôn Giả Sariputta Thuyết
blurb: Ānanda asks Sāriputta about a mysterious state of immersion in meditation where there is no normal perception, yet one is still conscious. Sāriputta confirms that there is, and claims to have attained it.

title: Ước Nguyện
blurb: If a mendicant wishes to attain spiritual heights, they should begin by practicing the code of training rules.

title: Cây Gai
blurb: When the Buddha receives noisy visitors, several monks withdraw to a nearby forest to meditate. The Buddha praises them, saying that noise is a thorn to absorption.

title: Khả Lạc
blurb: Ten desirable things that are hard to get.

title: Tăng Trưởng
blurb: Ten aspects of prosperity.

title: Migasàlà
blurb: The female lay disciple Migasālā questions Ānanda how the Buddha could have declared her father and her uncle had the same level of spiritual attainment, when one was much more strict than the other. Ānanda conveys this to the Buddha, who responds that only such as he can pass judgment, since the spiritual faculties of individuals are complex and hard to understand.

title: Không Thể Tăng Trưởng
blurb: Without rebirth, old age, and death, there would be no teaching of Dhamma. The Buddha teaches a series of sets of three things leading to liberation.

title: Con Quạ
blurb: A bad monk has ten bad qualities, like a crow.

title: Ni-Kiền-Tử
blurb: Jain ascetics have ten bad qualities.

title: Những Trường Hợp Hiềm Hận.
blurb: Ten ground for resentment.

title: Nhiếp Phục Hiềm Hận
blurb: Ten ways of removing resentment.

title: Người Có Lòng Tin
blurb: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.

title: Bàhuna
blurb: Giving up ten things, the Buddha lives free of limits.

title: Ananda
blurb: A mendicant cannot achieve progress if they have ten bad qualities starting with lack of faith.

title: Punniya
blurb: Venerable Puṇṇiya asks why the Buddha sometimes feels like teaching, other times not.

title: Nói Lên Chánh Trí
blurb: When a mendicant declares enlightenment, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.

title: Khoe Khoang
blurb: Venerable Mahācunda teaches that when a mendicant boasts about spiritual attainments, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.

title: Câu Hỏi Về Chánh Trí
blurb: Venerable Mahākassapa teaches that when a mendicant declares enlightenment, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.

title: Tỷ Kheo Kàlaka
blurb: The Buddha, speaking in reference to the monk Kalandaka, explains ten qualities that lead to discord or unity.

title: Tai Nạn
blurb: A mendicant who insults their spiritual companions incurs ten disasters.

title: Tỷ Kheo Kokàlika
blurb: The monk Kokālika accuses Sāriputta and Moggallāna of having evil wishes. The Buddha defends them. Later, Kokālika suffers calamity and is reborn in hell.

title: Những Sức Mạnh
blurb: Ten powers by which a mendicant knows that they have ended the defilements.

title: Tịch Tịnh Giải Thoát
blurb: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.

title: Người Hưởng Dục
blurb: The Buddha teaches Anāthapiṇḍika ten kinds of persons who enjoy sensual pleasures.

title: Sợ Hãi Và Hận Thù
blurb: A noble disciple has eliminated five perils, realized the four factors of stream-entry, and seen the noble process.

title: Kiến
blurb: Anāthapiṇḍika visits some wanderers, who ask him about the Buddha’s views. Anāthapiṇḍika asks them to explain their own view first. He then declares his own understanding of impermanence, leaving the wanderers speechless.

title: Vajjiyamahita
blurb: The householder Vajjiyamāhita visits some wanderers, who accuse the Buddha of condemning all asceticism. Vajjiyamāhita counters this by saying the Buddha only criticizes what is worthy of criticism. The Buddha praises him, and explains in detail what this means.

title: Uttiya
blurb: The wanderer Uttiya asks the Buddha a series of ten metaphysical questions as to whether the cosmos is finite, etc. The Buddha responds by saying that he only teaches the end of suffering. Uttiya goes on to ask whether all beings will be liberated. The Buddha is silent, and Ānanda answers on his behalf.

title: Kokanuda
blurb: The wanderer Kokanada meets Ānanda at the baths and engages him on the topic of the ten metaphysical questions.

title: Ðáng Ðảnh Lễ
blurb: With ten qualities, a mendicant is worthy.

title: Vị Trưởng Lão
blurb: With ten qualities, a senior mendicant is at ease wherever they live.

title: Upàli
blurb: When Upāli asks to go into retreat, the Buddha warns him that secluded wilderness dwellings are hard to endure unless one is accomplished in meditation. He gives a long account of the training required before going into solitude, and ends by encouraging Upāli to stay in the Saṅgha.

title: Rừng Khổng Tước
blurb: Possessing various sets of qualities, a mendicant is best among gods and men.

title: Có Lợi Ích Gì
blurb: Good conduct leads to non-regret, to joy, and so on all the way to liberation.

title: Mahànàma (1)
blurb: Mahānāma the Sakyan sees that the monks are preparing robes after the rains season. Knowing that the Buddha will soon depart, he asks how they are to live with their busy lives.

title: Mahànàma (2)
blurb: Mahānāma the Sakyan sees that the monks are preparing robes after the rains season. Knowing that the Buddha will soon depart, he asks how they are to live with their busy lives.

title: Nandiya
blurb: Nandiya the Sakiyan moves to Sāvatthī to be near the Buddha. At the end of the rains, he asks the Buddha’s advice on how to live.

title: Subhùti
blurb: Venerable Subhūti brings the young monk Saddha to meet the Buddha. The Buddha goes on to teach the manifestations of faith.

title: Từ
blurb: The meditation on love has eleven benefits.

title: Gia Chủ Dasama
blurb: Asked by a householder to teach a path to freedom, Venerable Ānanda explains no less than eleven meditative states that may serve as doors to the deathless.

title: Người Chăn Bò
blurb: A cowherd with eleven qualities is competent to look after a herd of cattle. Likewise, a mendicant with eleven qualities can grow in the Dhamma.

title: Thiền Ðịnh (1)
blurb: The Buddha is asked by the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

title: Thiền Ðịnh (2)
blurb: The Buddha teaches the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

title: Thiền Ðịnh (3)
blurb: Sāriputta is asked by the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

title: Nghĩ Với Dụng Ý
blurb: A virtuous person need not make a wish; it is natural for the path to flow on.

title: Thiền Ðịnh (4)
blurb: Sāriputta teaches the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

title: Sở Y, Do Bậc Ðạo Sư Thuyết
blurb: The Buddha teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.

title: Sở Y, Do Tôn Giả Sariputta Thuyết
blurb: Sāriputta teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.

title: Sở Y, Do Tôn Giả Ananda Thuyết
blurb: Ānanda teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.

title: Tai Họa
blurb: When a mendicant abuses their fellow monastics, eleven disasters follow.

title: Saññāsutta
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists. Ānanda puts the same question to Sāriputta, and gets the same answer.

title: Tác Ý
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal attention has ceased, but there is still attention. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists.

title: Sandha
blurb: The Buddha tells Venerable Sandha to meditate like a trained thoroughbred, not like a wild colt. Doing so, they may attain a deep state.

title: Kinh Phạm võng
blurb: While others may praise or criticize the Buddha, they tend to focus on trivial details. The Buddha presents an analysis of 62 kinds of wrong view, seeing through which one becomes detached from meaningless speculations.

title: Kinh Sa-môn quả
blurb: The newly crowned King Ajātasattu is disturbed by the violent means by which he achieved the crown. He visits the Buddha to find peace of mind, and asks him about the benefits of spiritual practice. This is one of the greatest literary and spiritual texts of early Buddhism.

title: Kinh Ambaṭṭha (A-ma-trú)
blurb: A young brahmin student attacks the Buddha’s family, but is put in his place.

title: Kinh Soṇadaṇḍa (Chủng Ðức)
blurb: A reputed brahmin visits the Buddha, despite the reservations of other brahmins. They discuss the true meaning of a brahmin, and the Buddha skillfully draws him around to his own point of view.

title: Kinh Kūṭadanta (Cứu-la-đàn-đầu)
blurb: A brahmin wishes to undertake a great sacrifice, and asks for the Buddha’s advice. The Buddha tells a legend of the past, in which a king is persuaded to give up violent sacrifice, and instead to devote his resources to supporting the needy citizens of his realm. However, even such a beneficial and non-violent sacrifice pales in comparison to the spiritual sacrifice of giving up attachments.

title: Kinh Mahāli
blurb: The Buddha explains to a diverse group of lay people how the results of meditation depend on the manner of development.

title: Kinh Jāliya
blurb: This discourse is mostly quoted by the Buddha in the previous.

title: Kinh Ca-diếp Sư tử hống
blurb: The Buddha is challenged by a naked ascetic on the topic of spiritual austerities. He points out that it is quite possible to perform all kinds of austere practices without having any inner purity of mind.

title: Kinh Poṭṭhapāda (Bố-sá-bà-lâu)
blurb: The Buddha discusses with a wanderer the nature of perception and how it evolves through deeper states of meditation. None of these, however, should be identified with a self or soul.

title: Kinh Subha (Tu-bà)
blurb: Shortly after the Buddha’s death, Venerable Ānanda is invited to explain the core teachings.

title: Kinh Kevaddha (Kiên Cố)
blurb: The Buddha refuses to perform miracles, explaining that this is not the right way to inspire faith. He goes on to tell the story of a monk whose misguided quest for answers led him as far as Brahmā.

title: Kinh Lohicca (Lô-hi-gia)
blurb: A brahmin has fallen into the idea that there is no point in trying to offer spiritual help to others. The Buddha goes to see him, and persuades him of the genuine benefits of spiritual teaching.

title: Kinh Tevijjā (Tam minh)
blurb: A number of brahmins are discussing the true path to Brahmā. Contesting the claims to authority based on the Vedas, the Buddha insists that only personal experience can lead to the truth.

title: Kinh Ðại bổn
blurb: The Buddha teaches about the six Buddhas of the past, and tells a lengthy account of one of those, Vipassī.

title: Kinh Ðại duyên
blurb: Rejecting Venerable Ānanda’s claim to easily understand dependent origination, the Buddha presents a complex and demanding analysis, revealing hidden nuances and implications of this central teaching.

title: Kinh Ðại Bát-Niết-Bàn
blurb: The longest of all discourses, this extended narrative tells of the events surrounding the Buddha’s death. Full of vivid and moving details, it is an ideal entry point into knowing the Buddha as a person, and understanding how the Buddhist community coped with his passing.

title: Kinh Ðại Thiện Kiến vương
blurb: An elaborate story of a past life of the Buddha as a legendary king who renounced all to practice meditation.

title: Kinh Xa-ni-sa
blurb: Beginning with an account of the fates of disciples who had recently passed away, the scene shifts to a discussion of Dhamma held by the gods.

title: Kinh Ðại Ðiển Tôn
blurb: A minor deity informs the Buddha of the conversations and business of the gods.

title: Kinh Ðại hội
blurb: When deities from all realms gather in homage to the Buddha, he gives a series of verses describing them. These verses, which are commonly chanted in Theravadin countries, give one of the most detailed descriptions of the deities worshiped at the the time of the Buddha.

title: Kinh Ðế-thích sở vấn
blurb: After hearing a love song from a god of music, the Buddha engages in a deep discussion with Sakka on the conditioned origin of attachment and suffering.

title: Kinh Ðại Niệm xứ
blurb: The Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This discourse is essentially identical to MN 10, with the addition of an extended section on the four noble truths derived from MN 141.

title: Kinh Tệ-túc
blurb: This is a long and entertaining debate between a monk and a skeptic, who went to elaborate and bizarre lengths to prove that there is no such thing as an afterlife. The discourse contains a colorful series of parables and examples.

title: Kinh Ba-lê
blurb: When Sunakkhatta threatens to disrobe, the Buddha is unimpressed. Rejecting showy displays of asceticism or wondrous powers, he demonstrates his pre-eminence.

title: Kinh Ưu-đàm-bà-la sư tử hống
blurb: This discourse gives a specially good example of dialog between religions. The Buddha insists that he is not interested to make anyone give up their teacher or practices, but only to help people let go of suffering.

title: Kinh Chuyển luân Thánh vương Sư tử hống
blurb: In illustration of his dictum that one should rely on oneself, the Buddha gives a detailed account of the fall of a kingly lineage of the past, and the subsequent degeneration of society. This process, however, is not over, as the Buddha predicts that eventually society will fall into utter chaos. But far in the future, another Buddha, Metteyya, will arise in a time of peace and plenty.

title: Kinh Khởi thế nhân bổn
blurb: In contrast with the brahmin’s self-serving mythologies of the past, the Buddha presents an account of evolution that shows how human choices are an integral part of the ecological balance, and how excessive greed destroys the order of nature.

title: Kinh Tự hoan hỷ
blurb: Shortly before he passes away, Venerable Sāriputta visits the Buddha and utters a moving eulogy of his great teacher.

title: Kinh Thanh tịnh
blurb: Following the death of Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, the leader of the Jains, the Buddha emphasizes the stability and maturity of his own community. He encourages the community to come together after his death and recite the teachings in harmony.

title: Kinh Tướng
blurb: This presents the brahmanical prophecy of the Great Man, and explains the 32 marks in detail. This discourse contains some of the latest and most complex verse forms in the canon.

title: Kinh Giáo thọ Thi-ca-la-việt
blurb: The Buddha encounters a young man who honors his dead father by performing rituals. The Buddha recasts the meaningless rites in terms of virtuous conduct. This is the most detailed discourse on ethics for lay people.

title: Kinh A-sá-nang-chi
blurb: Mighty spirits hold a congregation, and warn the Buddha that, since not all spirits are friendly, the mendicants should learn verses of protection.

title: Kinh Phúng tụng
blurb: The Buddha encourages Venerable Sāriputta to teach the mendicants, and he offers an extended listing of Buddhist doctrines arranged in numerical sequence.

title: Kinh Thập thượng
blurb: This is similar to the previous, but with a different manner of exposition. These two discourses anticipate some of the methods of the Abhidhamma.

title: Lobhasutta
blurb: Abandon greed, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Dosasutta
blurb: Abandon aversion, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Mohasutta
blurb: Abandon delusion, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Kodhasutta
blurb: Abandon anger, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Makkhasutta
blurb: Abandon contempt, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Mānasutta
blurb: Abandon conceit, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Sabbapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for the All, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Mānapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for conceit, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Lobhapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for greed, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Dosapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for aversion, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Mohapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for delusion, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Kodhapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for anger, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Makkhapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for contempt, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Avijjānīvaraṇasutta
blurb: Hindered by the hindrance of ignorance, people go wandering and transmigrating on for a long, long time.

title: Taṇhāsaṁyojanasutta
blurb: Fettered with the fetter of craving, beings go wandering and transmigrating on for a long, long time.

title: Paṭhamasekhasutta
blurb: Appropriate attention as the prime internal factor to help those in training.

title: Dutiyasekhasutta
blurb: Friendship with admirable people as the prime external factor to help those in training.

title: Saṁghabhedasutta
blurb: Schism in the Sangha leads to the detriment and unhappiness of many beings, both human and divine.

title: Saṁghasāmaggīsutta
blurb: Concord in the Sangha leads to the welfare and happiness of many beings, both human and divine.

title: Paduṭṭhacittasutta
blurb: Corrupt-mindedness leads to rebirth in the planes of deprivation.

title: Pasannacittasutta
blurb: Clear-mindedness leads to rebirth in a heavenly world.

title: Mettasutta
blurb: “Acts of merit” is a synonym for what is blissful, desirable, pleasing, endearing, charming. The Buddha recalls the results he himself has experienced from doing meritorious deeds.

title: Ubhayatthasutta
blurb: Heedfulness with regard to skillful qualities keeps both kinds of benefit secure: benefit in this live and benefit in lives to come.

title: Aṭṭhipuñjasutta
blurb: In this course of transmigrating, one person would leave behind a heap of bones as large as a mountain—if there were someone to collect the bones and the collection were not destroyed.

title: Musāvādasutta
blurb: A person who tells a deliberate lie is capable of any evil deed.

title: Dānasutta
blurb: If you knew, as the Buddha did, the results of giving and sharing, you wouldn’t eat without having shared.

title: Mettābhāvanāsutta
blurb: Goodwill far outshines all other ways of making merit.

title: Dukkhavihārasutta
blurb: Not guarding the doors of the sense faculties and knowing no moderation in food leads to suffering in this life and the next.

title: Sukhavihārasutta
blurb: Guarding the doors of the sense faculties and knowing moderation in food leads to ease in this life and the next.

title: Tapanīyasutta
blurb: Two things that cause remorse.

title: Atapanīyasutta
blurb: Two things that cause lack of remorse.

title: Paṭhamasīlasutta
blurb: A person of evil habits and evil views goes to hell.

title: Dutiyasīlasutta
blurb: A person of auspicious habits and auspicious views goes to heaven.

title: Ātāpīsutta
blurb: To lack ardency and compunction makes you incapable of unbinding.

title: Paṭhamajananakuhanasutta
blurb: The holy life is lived for the purpose of restraint and abandoning.

title: Dutiyajananakuhanasutta
blurb: The holy life is lived for the purpose of direct knowledge and full comprehension.

title: Somanassasutta
blurb: A sense of urgency and appropriate exertion bring ease here-and-now, and lead to the ending of the defilements.

title: Vitakkasutta
blurb: Two thoughts that often occur to the Buddha as he delights in non-ill will and seclusion.

title: Desanāsutta
blurb: Two Dhamma sequences: see evil as evil, and become released from it.

title: Vijjāsutta
blurb: Ignorance leads to lack of conscience and prudence.

title: Paññāparihīnasutta
blurb: The rewards of noble discernment.

title: Sukkadhammasutta
blurb: Conscience and prudence safeguard the world.

title: Ajātasutta
blurb: The existence of an unfabricated dimension allows for the escape from conditions.

title: Nibbānadhātusutta
blurb: Two unbinding properties: with fuel remaining and with no fuel remaining.

title: Paṭisallānasutta
blurb: Live enjoying aloofness, delighting in aloofness, inwardly committed to awareness-tranquility, not neglecting jhāna, endowed with clear-seeing insight, and frequenting empty buildings.

title: Sikkhānisaṁsasutta
blurb: Live with the trainings as your reward, with discernment uppermost, with release the essence, and with mindfulness the governing principle.

title: Jāgariyasutta
blurb: Be wakeful, mindful, alert, centered, sensitive, clear, and calm. And there you should, at the appropriate times, see clearly into skillful mental qualities.

title: Āpāyikasutta
blurb: Two types of behavior that lead to hell.

title: Diṭṭhigatasutta
blurb: How those with vision differ from those who adhere to craving for rebirth and those who slip past into craving to be annihilated.

title: Mūlasutta
blurb: Three roots of what is unskillful.

title: Dhātusutta
blurb: Three properties: form, formlessness, cessation.

title: Paṭhamavedanāsutta
blurb: Three feelings.

title: Dutiyavedanāsutta
blurb: How the three types of feeling should be viewed.

title: Paṭhamaesanāsutta
blurb: Three searches: for sensuality, for rebirth, for a holy life.

title: Dutiyaesanāsutta
blurb: Three searches: for sensuality, for rebirth, for a holy life.

title: Paṭhamaāsavasutta
blurb: Three defilements.

title: Dutiyaāsavasutta
blurb: Three defilements.

title: Taṇhāsutta
blurb: Three cravings.

title: Māradheyyasutta
blurb: Three qualities that lead beyond Māra’s domain.

title: Puññakiriyavatthusutta
blurb: Three grounds for meritorious activity.

title: Cakkhusutta
blurb: Three eyes: the eye of flesh, the divine eye, and the eye of discernment.

title: Indriyasutta
blurb: The noble attainments described in terms of three faculties.

title: Addhāsutta
blurb: Three time periods and the importance of comprehending signs.

title: Duccaritasutta
blurb: Three kinds of misconduct.

title: Sucaritasutta
blurb: Three kinds of good conduct.

title: Soceyyasutta
blurb: Three kinds of cleanliness: bodily, verbal, and mental.

title: Moneyyasutta
blurb: Three forms of sagacity: bodily, verbal, and mental.

title: Paṭhamarāgasutta
blurb: One whose passion, aversion, and delusion are abandoned is freed from Māra’s power.

title: Dutiyarāgasutta
blurb: To abandon passion, aversion, and delusion is like crossing over the dangers of the ocean.

title: Micchādiṭṭhikasutta
blurb: The Buddha reports having seen, for himself, beings reborn in planes of deprivation in line with their wrong views and evil actions.

title: Sammādiṭṭhikasutta
blurb: The Buddha reports having seen, for himself, beings reborn in good destinations in line with their right views and good actions.

title: Nissaraṇiyasutta
blurb: Three properties for escape: from sensuality, from form, and from whatever is fabricated and dependently co-arisen.

title: Santatarasutta
blurb: Formless phenomena are more peaceful than forms; cessation, more peaceful than formless phenomena.

title: Puttasutta
blurb: Three types of sons and daughters (when compared to their parents): of heightened birth, of similar birth, and of lowered birth.

title: Avuṭṭhikasutta
blurb: Three types of people: one like a cloud without rain, one who rains locally, and one who rains everywhere.

title: Sukhapatthanāsutta
blurb: Aspiring to three forms of bliss, wise people should guard their virtue.

title: Bhidurasutta
blurb: This body falls apart; consciousness is subject to fading; all acquisitions are inconstant, sufferingful, subject to change.
