blurb: Fleeing the demon host, Sakka’s chariot risks endangering the nests of little birds in the forest. Rather than render the birds homeless, Sakka instructs his charioteer to turn back, even at the cost of his life.

title: Không Gian Trá
blurb: Sakka reflects that one should not harm even one’s enemy. Knowing this, Vepacitti immediately takes advantage of it.

title: Vua A-Tu-La Verocana hay Mục Ðích
blurb: Sakka, lord of gods, and Verocana, lord of demons, approach the Buddha’s hut and speak in praise of effort.

title: Các Ẩn Sĩ Ở Rừng hay Hương
blurb: In days gone by, Sakka, lord of gods, and Vepacitti, lord of demons, visited a hermitage of seers. But Vepacitti behaves rudely, while Sakka honors them. However, the seers beg Sakka to leave, on account of the stink of their unwashed bodies. But he says he loves their smell.

title: Mahà Sakya Muni Gotama: Ðại Thích-ca-mâu-ni Cù-đàm.
blurb: The current Buddha Gotama, reflecting on how the world had fallen into suffering, became awakened by understanding dependent origination.

title: Thuyết Pháp —
blurb: The famous twelve links of dependent origination are spelled out, showing the origin and cessation of suffering dependent on ignorance.

title: Các Loại Ðồ Ăn
blurb: The Buddha defines the four kinds of “food” or “nutriment”, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness. These are all produced by craving, and hence connect with dependent origination.

title: Moliya Phagguna
blurb: Venerable Moḷiyaphagguna asks who eats the consciousness food. The Buddha says the question is improper, as it assumes a self as agent. Rather, all the factors of dependent origination are simply natural conditions and have nothing to do with a “self”.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn
blurb: One who does not understand dependent origination is no true ascetic.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn
blurb: One who does not understand dependent origination is no true ascetic.

title: Kaccàyanagotta: (Ca-chiên-diên Thị)
blurb: Venerable Kaccānagotta asks the Buddha about right view, and the Buddha answers that right view arises when one sees the origin and cessation of the world and is free of attachments. This sutta, brief but profound and difficult, became renowned as the only canonical reference named in Nāgārjuna’s Mūlamadhyamakakārikā, perhaps the most famous philosophical treatise in all Buddhism.

title: Vị Thuyết Pháp
blurb: One is qualified to be called a “Dhamma speaker” if one teaches for the ending of suffering.

title: Loã Thể
blurb: A naked ascetic named Kassapa approaches the Buddha while he is on alms round and asks whether suffering is created by oneself, by another, by both, or by chance. Explaining why he rejects all these options, the Buddha asserts that suffering arises due to conditions.

title: Timbaruka
blurb: A wanderer named Timbaruka asks the Buddha whether pleasure and pain are created by oneself, by another, by both, or by chance. Explaining why he rejects all these options, the Buddha asserts that pleasure and pain arise due to conditions.

title: Bậc Hiền So Sánh Với Kẻ Ngu
blurb: Both the wise and the foolish have been reborn in this life due to their deeds conditioned by ignorance in past lives. But a fool continues to make the same mistakes and is reborn yet again, whereas a wise person does not.

title: Duyên
blurb: The Buddha distinguishes between “dependently originated phenomena”—the twelve factors—and “dependent origination”—the principle of conditionality. Someone who understands these things no longer worries about the past or future.

title: Phân Biệt —
blurb: The Buddha gives definitions for each of the twelve links. These are general definitions that apply wherever the twelve links are mentioned.

title: Mười Lực
blurb: The Buddha’s teaching rests on his possession of ten powers and four grounds for self-confidence.

title: Mười Lực
blurb: The Buddha’s teaching rests on his possession of ten powers and four grounds for self-confidence. When hearing such an open teaching, a mendicant puts forth great effort, considering the good for both themselves and for others.

title: Duyên
blurb: The ending of defilements comes only when the truth is seen. But seeing the truth comes about due to a vital condition. In this way, twelve factors leading to freedom are united with the twelve factors leading to suffering.

title: Ngoại Ðạo
blurb: Sāriputta is asked by various ascetics as to the origin of suffering. He replies that the Buddha teaches that suffering originates by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact. Ānanda reports the exchange to the Buddha, who praises Sāriputta’s answer.

title: Bhùmija
blurb: Sāriputta is asked by Venerable Bhūmija as to the origin of pleasure and pain. He replies that the Buddha teaches that pleasure and pain originate by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions on this question are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact. Ānanda reports the exchange to the Buddha, who praises Sāriputta’s answer.

title: Upavāna (Ưu-ba-ma-na)
blurb: The Buddha is asked by Venerable Upavāṇa as to the origin of suffering. He replies that suffering originates by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact.

title: Duyên
blurb: Dependent origination is framed within the four noble truths.

title: Vị Tỷ Kheo
blurb: A mendicant who understands dependent origination is a trainee who is accomplished in view.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn
blurb: An ascetic who understands dependent origination will realize the goal of the ascetic life.

title: Sa Môn , Bà La Môn (như trên)
blurb: An ascetic who understands dependent origination may well escape those conditions.

title: Con Ðường...
blurb: The origin of suffering is the wrong way, the end is the right way.

title: Sanh: Bhūta
blurb: The Buddha asks Sāriputta to explain a verse from “The Questions of Ajita” in the Parāyana (Snp 5.2). At first, Sāriputta hesitates, but proceeds when the Buddha indicates he is looking for an answer in terms of conditionality.

title: Kaḷāra
blurb: A mendicant named Kaḷāra the Khattiya informs Sāriputta that the mendicant Moḷiyaphagguna had disrobed. Overinterpreting Sāriputta’s reply, Kaḷāra reports to the Buddha that Sāriputta had claimed to have ended all defilements. The Buddha calls Sāriputta to clarify his statements, and Sāriputta explains in terms of dependent origination.

title: Những Căn Bản Của Trí: Ñāṇavatthu
blurb: An analysis of 44 contexts for developing insight with regard to dependent origination. This includes an important distinction between knowledge arising from direct vision of the present, and that derived from inference as to the past and future.

title: Những Căn Bản Của Trí: Dutiyañāṇavatthu
blurb: An analysis of 77 contexts for developing insight with regard to dependent origination.

title: Do Duyên Vô Minh: Avijjāpaccaya
blurb: A mendicant asks who possesses old age and death, and the other factors. The Buddha says the question is improper, as it assumes a self as agent. Rather, dependent origination is the teaching “by the middle”, explaining phenomena according to natural conditions.

title: Do Duyên Vô Minh
blurb: The content of this discourse is identical with SN 12.35, except presented as a general teaching by the Buddha, without an questioner.

title: Không Phải Của ông: Natumha
blurb: The body is not yours, but is old kamma, generated by choices in past lives.

title: Tư Tâm Sở: Cetanā
blurb: Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.

title: Tư Tâm Sở
blurb: Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.

title: Tư Tâm Sở
blurb: Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.

title: Vipassì (Tỳ-bà-thi)
blurb: In the far past, the Buddha Vipassī reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.

title: Năm Hận Thù, Sợ Hãi: Pañcabhayavera
blurb: A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.

title: Năm Sợ Hãi Hận Thù (2): Dutiyapañcabhayavera
blurb: A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.

title: Khổ: Dukkha
blurb: The origin and ending of suffering are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving.

title: Thế Giới: Loka
blurb: The origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering.

title: Ñātika
blurb: While on retreat, the Buddha exclaims how the origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering. A mendicant overhears him, and the Buddha urges him to remember that teaching.

title: Một Vị Bà-la-môn: Aññatarabrāhmaṇa
blurb: A brahmin asks whether the person who acts is the same or different to the person who receives the result. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.

title: Jāṇussoṇi
blurb: The brahmin Jāṇussoṇi asks the Buddha whether all exists or nothing exists. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.

title: Thuận Thế Phái: Lokāyatika
blurb: A brahmin cosmologist asks the Buddha whether all exists or nothing exists. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.

title: Thánh Ðệ Tử
blurb: A noble disciple does not wonder about the links of dependent origination, as they see it for themselves, independent of others.

title: Thánh Ðệ Tử
blurb: A noble disciple does not wonder about the links of dependent origination, as they see it for themselves, independent of others.

title: Sikhì (Thi-khí)
blurb: In the far past, the Buddha Sikhī reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.

title: Tư Lường: Parivīmaṁsana
blurb: A mendicant should thoroughly investigate the causes of suffering in accordance with dependent origination. If someone who still has ignorance makes a choice, their consciousness fares on to a suitable state of existence. But one who has eradicated ignorance is detached and is not reborn anywhere.

title: Thủ: Upādāna
blurb: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a bonfire.

title: Kiết Sử: Saññojana
blurb: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a lamp.

title: Kiết Sử
blurb: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a lamp.

title: Cây Lớn: Mahārukkha
blurb: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a tree.

title: Cây Lớn: Dutiyamahārukkha
blurb: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a tree.

title: Cây Non: Taruṇarukkha
blurb: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a sapling.

title: Danh Sắc: Nāmarūpa
blurb: The mental and physical organism is reborn when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a tree.

title: Thức: Viññāṇa
blurb: Consciousness is reborn when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a tree.

title: Nhân: Nidāna
blurb: When Ānanda suggests that dependent origination is simple, the Buddha rebukes him. The opening of this is similar to DN 15 Mahānidāna.

title: Vessabhū (Tỳ-xá-phù)
blurb: In the far past, the Buddha Vessabhū reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.

title: Hạng Người Ít Nghe: Assutavantu
blurb: An ignorant person might become free of attachment to their body, but not their mind. Still, it would be better to attach to the body, as it is less changeable than the mind, which jumps about like a monkey.

title: Hạng Người Ít Nghe
blurb: An ignorant person might become free of attachment to their body, but not their mind. Still, it would be better to attach to the body, as it is less changeable than the mind. But a noble disciple reflects on dependent origination.

title: Thịt Ðứa Con: Puttamaṁsūpama
blurb: The Buddha defines the four kinds of “food” or “nutriment”, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness. He illustrates them with a series of powerful and horrifying similes.

title: Có Tham: Atthirāga
blurb: The Buddha defines the four kinds of “food” or “nutriment”, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness, showing how they lead to suffering according to dependent origination.

title: Thành Ấp: Nagara
blurb: The Buddha tells the story of how his awakening came about through investigation into dependent origination. He compares it to a man discovering and ancient city, lost and overgrown with weeds.

title: Xúc Chạm, Biết Rõ: Sammasa
blurb: The right way to investigate inside oneself is to see how suffering is created by craving and attachment, stimulated by pleasant experiences.

title: Bó Lau: Naḷakalāpī
blurb: Venerables Mahākoṭṭhita and Sāriputta discuss whether the factors of dependent origination are created by oneself, another, both, or by chance.

title: Kosambī
blurb: Venerable Saviṭṭha questions Venerable Musīla about his attainments, and concludes he is an arahant. But Venerable Nārada offers an explanation showing that it is possible to see the Dhamma without having fully realized arahantship.

title: Nước Thủy Triều Dâng: Upayanti
blurb: Like rivers flowing to the ocean, the factors of dependent origination lead to suffering.

title: Susīma
blurb: The wanderer Susı̄ma fraudulently enters the Sangha so that the wanderers can learn the secret to the Buddha’s fame and success. Hearing that some mendicants claimed to be perfected, Susīma approaches and asks them if they have developed psychic powers or the formless states, to which they say no. Perplexed, he asks the Buddha, who explains that awakening follows insight into the principles of impermanence and causality. Eventually Susı̄ma confesses his misdeed.

title: Kakusandha (Câu-lưu-tôn)
blurb: In the far past, the Buddha Kakusandha reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.

title: Già, Chết: Jarāmaraṇa
blurb: One who does not understand aging and death is no true ascetic.

title: Jātisuttādidasaka
blurb: One who does not understand the various factors of dependent origination is no true ascetic.

title: Konāgamana (Câu-na-hàm)
blurb: In the far past, the Buddha Koṇāgamana reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.

title: Bậc Đạo Sư: Satthu
blurb: One who does not understand the various factors of dependent origination should seek a teacher.

title: Kassapa (Ca-diếp)
blurb: In the far past, the Buddha Kassapa reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.

title: Ví Dụ Núi
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Himalayas; what remains is like seven bits of gravel.

title: Ðầu Ngón Tay
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like the dirt under a fingernail.

title: Ví Dụ Núi
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Sineru, king of mountains; what remains is like seven bits of gravel

title: Hồ Sen
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in a massive dam; what remains is like a few drops on a blade of grass.

title: Nước Sông Hợp Dòng
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water at the confluence of great rivers; what remains is like a few drops.

title: Nước Sông Hợp Dòng
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water at the confluence of great rivers; what remains is like a few drops.

title: Quả Ðất
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like seven balls of clay.

title: Quả Ðất
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like seven balls of clay.

title: Biển
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in the ocean; what remains is like a few drops.

title: Biển
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in the ocean; what remains is like a few drops.

title: Ví Dụ Với Núi
blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Himalayas; what remains is like seven bits of gravel.

title: Xúc
blurb: It is not the case that diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, quests, and material possessions give rise to diverse external elements of sense experience.

title: Giới
blurb: The senses function due to the various different elements of sense experience, namely, the internal sense organ, the external sense stimulus, and consciousness.

title: Bảy (Pháp) Này
blurb: A rare group of seven elements: light, beauty, the four formless states, and the attainment of cessation. Each of these is known due to the negation of something: light vs. darkness, beauty vs. ugliness, and so on.

title: Có Nhân
blurb: Thoughts of sensuality, ill-will, and cruelty arise due to a series of causes.

title: Căn Nhà Bằng Gạch
blurb: When unenlightened people have the view that certain people are Buddhas, this is due to ignorance.

title: Liệt Ý Chí
blurb: People of poor character associate together, while people of good character associate together.

title: Nghiệp
blurb: The Buddha points out that each of the great disciples has a retinue of students of a similar character. And the monks in Devadattas’s retinue all have evil wishes.

title: Kinh Với Các Bài Kệ: Sagāthā
blurb: People of poor character associate together, while people of good character associate together. Illustrated with similes and verses.

title: Bất Tín: Assaddhasaṁsandana
blurb: The faithless and those of other bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Căn Bản Bất Tín: Assaddhamūlaka
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Căn Bản Không Biết Thẹn: Ahirikamūlaka
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Căn Bản Không Biết Sợ: Anottappamūlaka
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Xúc
blurb: The diverse internal elements of sense experience give rise to diverse contacts.

title: Ít Nghe: Appassutamūlaka
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Biếng Nhác: Kusītamūlaka
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Không Tịch Tịnh: Asamāhita
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Ác Giới: Dussīla
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Năm Học Pháp: Pañcasikkhāpada
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Bảy Nghiệp Ðạo: Sattakammapatha
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Mười Nghiệp Ðạo: Dasakammapatha
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Tám Chi: Aṭṭhaṅgika
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Mười Chi: Dasaṅga
blurb: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.

title: Bốn Giới: Catudhātu
blurb: The four material elements of earth, water, heat, and air. Note that “air” is close in meaning to “wind”.

title: Và Không Phải Như Vậy
blurb: It is not the case that diverse contacts give rise to the diverse elements of sense experience.

title: Trước Khi Giác Ngộ: Pubbesambodha
blurb: Before his awakening the Buddha saw the gratification, the drawback, and the escape in the four material elements.

title: Ta Ðã Ði: Acariṁ
blurb: The Buddha set out to discover the gratification, the drawback, and the escape in the four material elements, and found it.

title: Nếu Không Có Cái Này: Nocedaṁ
blurb: Each of the three aspects of the four material elements performs its own function. Gratification stimulates desire; drawbacks lead to disillusionment, while escape opens the possibility of freedom.

title: Khổ Tướng: Dukkhalakkhaṇa
blurb: If the material elements were solely painful, beings would not get attached. If they were solely pleasurable, it would be impossible to become detached.

title: Hoan Hỷ: Abhinandana
blurb: When you seek pleasure in the material elements, you seek pleasure in suffering.

title: Sanh Khởi: Uppāda
blurb: The arising of the material elements is the arising of suffering.

title: Sa-môn, Bà-la-môn: Samaṇabrāhmaṇa
blurb: One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.

title: Sa-môn, Bà-la-môn (2): Dutiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇa
blurb: One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.

title: Sa-môn, Bà-la-môn (3): Tatiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇa
blurb: One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.

title: Thọ
blurb: Diverse contacts give rise to diverse feelings.

title: Thọ
blurb: It is not the case that diverse feelings give rise to diverse contacts.

title: Giới
blurb: The senses function due to the various different external elements of sense experience, namely, the various sense stimuli.

title: Tưởng
blurb: The diverse external elements of sense experience give rise to diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, and quests.

title: Và Không Phải Như Vậy
blurb: It is not the case that diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, and quests give rise to diverse external elements of sense experience.

title: Xúc
blurb: The diverse external elements of sense experience give rise to diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, quests, and material possessions.

title: Người
blurb: The bones you’ve left behind in transmigration are greater than a mountain.

title: Cỏ Và Củi
blurb: Transmigration is endless, like the grass and twigs in India.

title: Khốn Cùng
blurb: When you see someone suffer, know that you too have experienced that.

title: An Lạc
blurb: When you see someone happy, know that you too have experienced that.

title: Khoảng Ba Mươi
blurb: The blood you have shed from being slaughtered or beheaded in transmigration is greater than the waters in the oceans.

title: Mẹ
blurb: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your mother.

title: Cha
blurb: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your father.

title: Anh
blurb: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your brother.

title: Chị
blurb: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your sister.

title: Con Trai
blurb: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your son.

title: Con Gái
blurb: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your daughter.

title: Núi Vepulla
blurb: The Buddha recounts how peoples of the past had different names for the mountains of Rājagaha. Yet now they have all gone

title: Quả Ðất
blurb: Transmigration is endless, like the great earth.

title: Nước Mắt
blurb: The tears you have shed in transmigration are greater than the waters in the oceans.

title: Sữa
blurb: The mother’s milk you have drunk in transmigration is greater than the waters in the oceans.

title: Núi
blurb: A great mountain would erode before the end of the eon.

title: Hột Cải
blurb: A city filled with mustard seeds might be emptied before the end of an eon.

title: Các Ðệ Tử
blurb: Even recollecting 100,000 eons per day you’ll never remember the beginning of transmigration.

title: Sông Hằng
blurb: There have been more eons than the sands in the Ganges river.

title: Cây Gậy
blurb: Like a stick falling on this side or that, beings are reborn in different realms.

title: Trú Xứ: Upassaya
blurb: When Kassapa is persuaded by Ānanda to go with him to teach the nuns, the nun Thullatissā compares him unfavorably to Ānanda, prompting Kassapa to issue a warning and make a bold claim of his spiritual mastery. This discourse appears to be set after the Buddha’s passing.

title: Tri Túc
blurb: Kassapa is content with robes, alms-food, lodging, and medicines.

title: Y Áo: Cīvara
blurb: When several of Ānanda’s students disrobe, Kassapa admonishes him, calling him “boy”. The nun Thullanandā hears of this and criticizes Kassapa, claiming he formerly followed another teacher. But Kassapa refutes this, and gives an account of his going forth and first encounter with the Buddha.

title: Sau Khi Chết: Paraṁmaraṇa
blurb: Sāriputta asks Kassapa about whether a Realized One survives death.

title: Tượng Pháp: Saddhammappatirūpaka
blurb: Kassapa asks the Buddha why there are now more rules but fewer awakened mendicants. The Buddha replies that it is due to the arising of the counterfeit Dhamma, giving five factors that lead to decline

title: Không Biết Sợ: Anottappī
blurb: Sāriputta approaches Kassapa and asks how it is that only someone who is keen and conscientious can realize freedom.

title: Nguyệt Dụ: Candūpama
blurb: Kassapa approaches families like the moon, with humility, keeping his distance, and not getting involved. So when he teaches, it is with pure intentions.

title: Ði Ðến Các Gia Ðình: Kulūpaka
blurb: Some mendicants approach families in the hope of receiving fine gifts or respect—but not Kassapa.

title: Trở Về Già: Jiṇṇa
blurb: The Buddha points out that Kassapa has grown old, and urges him to give up his ascetic life and stay in a comfortable monastery.

title: Giáo Giới: Ovāda
blurb: The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, since certain students of Anuruddha and Ānanda have been competing to see who can teach better.

title: Giáo Giới (2): Dutiya-ovāda
blurb: The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, saying that the mendicants have become stubborn and their good qualities are declining.

title: Giáo Giới (3): Tatiya-ovāda
blurb: The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, saying that the senior mendicants used to set a good example, but now instead of respecting good practice, they respect fame and fortune.

title: Thiền Và Thắng Trí: Jhānābhiñña
blurb: The Buddha asserts that just as he has full mastery of all the meditation attainments and higher spiritual realizations, so does Kassapa.

title: Kinh Với Bài Kệ
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, and attachment to them leads to a bad rebirth.

title: Khổ Lụy
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, obstructing spiritual progress.

title: Bình Bát
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.

title: Bình Bát
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.

title: Từ Một Ðồng Tiền Vàng Cho Ðến Người Mỹ Nhân Ðịa Phương
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.

title: Lưỡi Câu
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which catch you like fish on a hook.

title: Phụ Nữ
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise can be even more tempting than a woman.

title: Mỹ Nhân
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise can be even more tempting than the finest lady in the land.

title: Con Trai
blurb: A laywoman should wish that if her son remains in the household life, he should be like Citta and Hatthaka. But if he becomes a monk, may material possessions, honor, and praise not come to him!

title: Con Gái Một
blurb: A laywoman should wish that if her daughter remains in the household life, she should be like Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇḍakiyā. But if she becomes a nun, may material possessions, honor, and praise not come to her!

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn
blurb: Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn
blurb: Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn
blurb: Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.

title: Da
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise cut to the bone.

title: Dây
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise cut to the bone, like a rope.

title: Tỷ Kheo
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are even a problem for a perfected one, as they interfere with their meditation.

title: Con Rùa
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which hit you like a harpoon hits a careless turtle.

title: Cắt
blurb: Devadatta provoked a schism due to material possessions, honor, and praise.

title: Gốc
blurb: Devadatta’s wholesome root was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.

title: Pháp.
blurb: Devadatta’s wholesome nature was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.

title: Trắng
blurb: Devadatta’s bright nature was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.

title: Bỏ Ði
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise led to Devadatta’s downfall, like the fruit of a plantain.

title: Xe
blurb: Prince Ajātasattu supplied devadatta with 500 carts of offerings, leading to his downfall.

title: Mẹ
blurb: Even someone who would not lie for the sake of their mother would so so when corrupted by material possessions.

title: Cha, Anh, Chị, Con Trai, Con Gái, Vợ
blurb: Even someone who would not lie for the sake of their father and other relatives would so so when corrupted by material possessions.

title: Lông Dài
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which snare you like a long-haired goat in a briar patch.

title: Trùng Phẩn
blurb: A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is like a dung beetle proud of their ball of dung.

title: Sét Ðánh
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, like a lightning strike.

title: Trúng Ðộc
blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, like a poison dart.

title: Con Giả Can
blurb: A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a mangy jackal.

title: Cuồng Phong
blurb: A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a bird in a gale.

title: Uẩn
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the five aggregates in light of the three characteristics.

title: Mắt
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the internal sense organs in light of the three characteristics.

title: Mắt
blurb: The Buddha teaches Rāhula about the internal sense organs in light of the three characteristics.

title: Rūpādisuttanavaka
blurb: The Buddha teaches Rāhula about the senses, aggregates, and elements in light of the three characteristics.

title: Sắc
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the external sense objects in light of the three characteristics.

title: Tùy Miên
blurb: Rāhula asks how to see so that conceit no longer occurs. The Buddha teaches him to investigate the five aggregates in terms of not-self.

title: Viễn Ly
blurb: Rāhula asks how to see so conceit no longer occurs and one is peaceful. The Buddha teaches him to investigate the five aggregates in terms of not-self

title: Thức
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on sense consciousness in light of the three characteristics.

title: Xúc
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on sense contact in light of the three characteristics.

title: Thọ
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on feelings in light of the three characteristics.

title: Tưởng
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on perceptions in light of the three characteristics.

title: Tư
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on intentions in light of the three characteristics.

title: Ái
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on cravings in light of the three characteristics.

title: Giới
blurb: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the four material elements in light of the three characteristics.

title: Người Phán Quan Tham Nhũng Với Hòn Dái Lớn
Ðống Xương
blurb: While walking for alms down Vulture’s Peak, Venerable Moggallāna smiled at something invisible. Later, he told the Buddha it was a skeleton flying through the air, being pecked at by vultures. The Buddha confirmed that the man he had seen had been a butcher in his past life

title: Kẻ Thông Dâm Bị Chìm Trong Hố
Tà Ác Là Bà La Môn Ăn Phân
Người Phụ Nữ Xấu Xí Bói Toán
Người Ðàn Bà Khô Héo Ðã Rải Than Ðỏ trên Một Người Ðàn Bà
Một Miếng Thịt và Kẻ Bắt Chim
Người Giết Dê Bị Lột Da
Người Giết Heo Với Ðao Kiếm
Người Săn Thú Với Cây Lao
Người Tra Tấn Với Mũi Tên.
Người Ðánh Xe Với Các Cây Kim
Con Mèo
blurb: As a cat may suffer from eating too hastily, so a mendicant may suffer by not restraining senses.

title: Chóp Mái
blurb: As rafters depend on the roof-peak, unwholesome qualities depend on ignorance.

title: Con Chó Rừng (Giả-can)
blurb: A mangy jackal howls in discomfort, but even that would be a good rebirth for some.

title: Con Giả Can
blurb: An old jackal howls at dawn, but even they have more gratitude than some

title: Ðầu Ngón Tay
blurb: As the dirt in a fingernail is smaller than the great earth, the beings reborn as humans are few.

title: Gia Ðình
blurb: As a family with few men and many women is easily attacked, non-human beings may attack a mendicant without love.

title: Cái Nồi
blurb: Love is more beneficial than generosity.

title: Cây Lao (Satti)
blurb: As it is not possible to bend back a spear, it is not possible to overthrow a mendicant who has developed love.

title: Người Bắn Cung
blurb: Only a speedster could catch arrows in flight, yet conditioned phenomena perish faster than that.

title: Cái Chốt Trống
blurb: As an ancient drum has disintegrated, so too will the true teachings disappear.

title: Cỏ Rơm
blurb: Warriors who sleep on wooden pillows remain vigilant, and so it is for the spiritual seeker.

title: Voi
blurb: A mendicant who overly associates with the laity is like an elephant calf who tries to copy the great bull elephants.

title: Tên Trưởng Lão
blurb: A monk named “Senior” likes to live alone, but the Buddha questions whether it is the true solitude.

title: Kolita
blurb: Moggallāna reflects that second absorption is the true noble silence, and the Buddha encourages him to develop it.

title: Kappina
blurb: The Buddha describes Venerable Mahākappina as thin, fair-skinned, with a big nose—and as awakened.

title: Thân Hữu
blurb: The Buddha praises two friends who are students of Venerable Mahākappina

title: Upatissa...
blurb: Sāriputta says that not even if the Buddha changed would it cause him sorrow.

title: Cái Ghè
blurb: Sāriputta and Moggallāna come together for a discussion, which touches on the use of psychic powers and energy. The two great monks end up warmly praising each other.

title: Tân Tỷ Kheo
blurb: When a certain monk neglects his duties in favor of solitude, other monks complain. The Buddha questions him, and finds that he is awakened.

title: Thiện Sanh
blurb: The Buddha praises Venerable Sujāta as beautiful both inside and out.

title: Bhaddi
blurb: Venerable Lakuṇṭaka Bhaddiya is a dwarf, considered to be ugly and unsightly. The Buddha warns the monks not to despise him as he had realized full awakening.

title: Visākha
blurb: The Buddha praises Venerable Visākha Pañcāliputta for teaching the Dhamma.

title: Nanda
blurb: Venerable Nanda wore pretty robes, a fancy bowl, and makeup, so the Buddha encouraged him to embrace simplicity.

title: Tissa
blurb: Venerable Tissa admonished others but got upset when he was admonished. The Buddha encourages him to let go of his anger.

title: Dây Thằng (Hay Dây Buộc)
blurb: A dog leashed to a post will always remain close to that post. In the same way, beings remain close to aggregates in this endless cycle of transmigration. The Buddha refers to a well-known painting called “Conduct”, and says the mind is even more diverse than that; and indeed, the animal realm is the most diverse of them all, and it is produced by the mind.

title: Ba Thời Là Khổ
blurb: The aggregates are suffering in the past and future as in the present.

title: Nakulapitā
blurb: The householder Nakulapitā asks the Buddha for help in coping with old age. The Buddha says to reflect: “Even though I am afflicted in body, my mind will be unafflicted.” Later Sāriputta explains this in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Cán Búa (Hay Chiếc Thuyền)
blurb: Contemplating the aggregates leads to liberation, but this may not be immediately apparent. The Buddha illustrates this with similes of a chook sitting on eggs, the wearing away of an axe handle, and the rotting of a ship’s rigging.

title: Vô Thường Tánh (Hay Tưởng)
blurb: The perception of impermanence eliminates lust, ignorance, and conceit. Illustrated with a long series of similes.

title: Biên Kinh
blurb: The aggregates considered in light of the four noble truths, phrased as “portions” or “sides”.

title: Khổ
blurb: The aggregates considered in light of the four noble truths in terms of suffering.

title: Hữu Thân
blurb: The aggregates considered in light of the four noble truths in terms of identity.

title: Sở Biến Tri
blurb: The aggregates are to be fully understood, ending the defilements is the full understanding of them, and an arahant is the one who has achieved this.

title: Các Sa Môn
blurb: Only a true ascetic fully understands the five aggregates.

title: Các Sa Môn
blurb: Only a true ascetic fully understands the five aggregates.

title: Dự Lưu
blurb: One who truly understand these five aggregates is a stream-enterer.

title: A-La-Hán
blurb: One who truly understand these five aggregates and is freed from them is a perfected one.

title: Ba Thời Là Vô Ngã
blurb: The aggregates are not-self in the past and future as in the present.

title: Dục Ðược Ðoạn Trừ
blurb: Give up desire for the aggregates and they will come to an end.

title: Dục Ðược Ðoạn Trừ
blurb: Give up desire for the aggregates and they will come to an end.

title: Vô Minh (Hay Vị Tỷ-kheo)
blurb: Ignorance is not understanding the aggregates.

title: Minh (Hay Vị Tỷ-kheo)
blurb: Knowledge is understanding the aggregates.

title: Vị Thuyết Pháp
blurb: A true Dhamma speaker teaches for letting go of the aggregates.

title: Vị Thuyết Pháp
blurb: A true Dhamma speaker teaches for letting go of the aggregates.

title: Trói Buộc
blurb: An unawakened person is bound both internally and externally to the aggregates and grows old in bondage.

title: Giải Thoát
blurb: The Buddha questions the mendicants on the aggregates.

title: Giải Thoát
blurb: The Buddha questions the mendicants on the aggregates.

title: Kiết Sử
blurb: The aggregates are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: Because the aggregates are impermanent, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.

title: Chấp Thủ
blurb: The aggregates are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.

title: Vị Giữ Giới
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks what an ethical mendicant should focus on, and Sāriputta replies that if they focus on aggregates as impermanent, etc. they may become a stream-enterer. A stream-enterer contemplating in the same way may become a non-returner, a once-returner, and a perfected one.

title: Vị Có Nghe
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks what an educated mendicant should focus on, and Sāriputta replies that if they focus on aggregates as impermanent, etc. they may become a stream-enterer. A stream-enterer contemplating in the same way may become a non-returner, a once-returner, and a perfected one.

title: Kappa
blurb: Venerable Kappa asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.

title: Kappa
blurb: Venerable Kappa asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit and be freed. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.

title: Tập Pháp
blurb: The Buddha explains to a mendicant that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing, while knowledge is understanding the aggregates.

title: Tập Pháp
blurb: Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing.

title: Tập Pháp
blurb: Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that knowledge is understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing.

title: Vi Ngọt
blurb: Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Vị Ngọt
blurb: Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that knowledge is understanding the aggregates in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Khổ
blurb: Because the aggregates are suffering, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.

title: Tập Khởi
blurb: Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Tập Khởi
blurb: Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that knowledge is understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Kotthika
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita explains to Sāriputta that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape, while knowledge is understanding the aggregates.

title: Kotthika
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita explains to Sāriputta that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing, gratification, drawback, and escape, while knowledge is understanding the aggregates.

title: Kotthika
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita explains to Sāriputta that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of the four noble truths, while knowledge is understanding the aggregates.

title: Than Ðỏ Hực
blurb: The aggregates are like burning chaff.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: Give up desire for what is impermanent, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: Give up lust for what is impermanent, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: Give up desire and lust for what is impermanent, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Khổ: Dukkha
blurb: Give up desire for what is suffering, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Vô Ngã
blurb: Because the aggregates are not-self, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.

title: Khổ: Dukkha
blurb: Give up lust for what is suffering, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Khổ: Dukkha
blurb: Give up desire and lust for what is suffering, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Vô Ngã: Anatta
blurb: Give up desire for what is not-self, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Vô Ngã: Anatta
blurb: Give up lust for what is not-self, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Vô Ngã: Anatta
blurb: Give up desire and lust for what is not-self, i.e. the aggregates.

title: Thiện Nam Tử Khổ: Nibbidābahula
blurb: One gone forth should dwell full of disillusionment for the aggregates.

title: Thấy Vô Thường: Aniccānupassī
blurb: One gone forth should dwell contemplating impermanence in the aggregates.

title: Thấy Khổ: Dukkhānupassī
blurb: One gone forth should dwell contemplating suffering in the aggregates.

title: Thấy Vô Ngã: Anattānupassī
blurb: One gone forth should dwell contemplating not-self in the aggregates.

title: Nội: Ajjhatta
blurb: Pleasure and pain arise inside oneself due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Cái Gì Vô Thường
blurb: One should truly understand the five aggregates as impermanent, etc.

title: Cái Này Là Của Tôi: Etaṁmama
blurb: The ideas of “me’ and “mine” arise due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Cái Này Là Ngã: So-attā
blurb: The idea that the self is identical with the cosmos arises due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Nếu Không Phải Của Tôi: Nocamesiyā
blurb: Even subtle forms of self identification arise due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Tà Kiến: Micchādiṭṭhi
blurb: Wrong view arises due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Thân Kiến: Sakkāyadiṭṭhi
blurb: Identity view arises due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Ngã Kiến: Attānudiṭṭhi
blurb: View of self arises due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Thiên Chấp: Abhinivesa
blurb: Fetters and shackles arise due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Thiên Chấp (2): Dutiyābhinivesa
blurb: Fetters and holding arise due to grasping the aggregates.

title: Ānanda
blurb: When Ānanda wants to go on retreat, the Buddha advises him to contemplate the aggregates

title: Cái Gì Khổ
blurb: One should truly understand the five aggregates as suffering, etc.

title: Cái Gì Vô Ngã
blurb: One should truly understand the five aggregates as not-self.

title: Có Nhân Là Vô Thường
blurb: Since the causes of the aggregates are impermanent, how can the aggregates be permanent?

title: Có Nhân Là Khổ
blurb: Since the causes of the aggregates are suffering, how can the aggregates be free of suffering?

title: Có Nhân Là Vô Ngã
blurb: Since the causes of the aggregates are not-self, how can the aggregates be self?

title: Devadaha
blurb: A number of mendicants are heading for lands west, but the Buddha advises them to speak with Sāriputta before they go. Sāriputta reminds them that in foreign lands they will be scrutinized for their understanding, so they need to be able to answer questions on the teaching. He goes on to explain that the Dhamma is for the removal of desire for the five aggregates.

title: Ānanda
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha what exactly is meant when we say that things cease. The Buddha explains it as the cessation of the aggregates.

title: Gánh Nặng
blurb: The aggregates are the burden, a person carries that burden, craving takes up the burden, and letting go puts down the burden.

title: Liễu Tri (Parinna)
blurb: The aggregates are to be fully understood, and the full understanding is the ending of defilements.

title: Thắng Tri
blurb: Only by directly knowing the aggregates can one end suffering.

title: Dục Tham
blurb: By letting go desire, the aggregates come to an end.

title: Vị Ngọt
blurb: Before his awakening, the Buddha investigated the aggregates in terms of their gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Vị Ngọt
blurb: When the Buddha fully knew the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the five aggregates he became awakened.

title: Vị Ngọt
blurb: Beings are attached to the five aggregates due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.

title: Hoan Hỷ
blurb: If you enjoy the aggregates, you enjoy suffering.

title: Sanh Khởi
blurb: The arising of the aggregates is the arising of suffering.

title: Hàliddikàni
blurb: The householder Hāliddakāni approaches the Venerable Mahākaccāna in the Avanti country and asks how to understand a verse from “The Questions of Māgandiya” of the Aṭṭhakavagga (Snp 4.9). Though the verse appears to be pitched at an ethical level, describing a sage intimate with none in the village, Mahākaccāna explains it in philosophical terms as non-attachment to the aggregates.

title: Cội Gốc Của Ðau Khổ
blurb: The aggregates are misery, desire for them is the root of misery.

title: Hoại Pháp
blurb: The aggregates are fragile and their passing is not fragile.

title: Không Phải Của Các Ông
blurb: Let go of what is not yours: the five aggregates. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the aggregates?

title: Không Phải Của Các Ông
blurb: Let go of what is not yours: the five aggregates.

title: Tỷ Kheo
blurb: The Buddha teaches a mendicant who wants to go on retreat that one is reckoned by what one has an underlying tendency for. The mendicant gives a full explanation.

title: Vị Tỷ Kheo
blurb: The Buddha teaches a mendicant who wants to go on retreat that one is measured by what one has an underlying tendency for. The mendicant gives a full explanation.

title: Ānanda
blurb: The Buddha speaks to Ānanda on what at AN 3.47 described as the “characteristics of conditioned phenomena”: arising, ceasing, and change while persisting. This was to become a critical aspect of later theories on the nature of change. Ānanda explains in terms of the aggregates.

title: Ānanda
blurb: The Buddha speaks to Ānanda on what at AN 3.47 described as the “characteristics of conditioned phenomena”: arising, ceasing, and change while persisting, as applied to past, future, and present. Ānanda explains in terms of the aggregates.

title: Tùy Pháp
blurb: To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on disillusionment with the aggregates.

title: Tùy Pháp
blurb: To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as impermanent.

title: Hàliddikàni
blurb: The householder Hāliddakāni approaches the Venerable Mahākaccāna in the Avanti country and asks how to understand a passage on liberation from “The Questions of Sakka” (see MN 37 and DN 21). Mahākaccāna explains it in terms of freedom from attachment to the aggregates.

title: Tùy Pháp
blurb: To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as suffering.

title: Tùy Pháp
blurb: To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as not-self.

title: Tự Mình Làm Hòn Ðảo
blurb: Dwell with yourself as an island and refuge, with the Dhamma as an island and refuge. How? By investigating how suffering arises from identification with the aggregates.

title: Con Ðường
blurb: Contemplation of the five aggregates as not-self is the path to the end of identity.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: Seeing the five aggregates as impermanent, etc., leads to freedom.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: Seeing the five aggregates as impermanent, etc., leads to letting go of views and ultimately to freedom.

title: Quán Kiến
blurb: When you identify anything as self, you always identify one or other of the five aggregates.

title: Các Uẩn
blurb: The distinction between “five aggregates” and “five grasping aggregates”.

title: Sona
blurb: The Buddha teaches a householder named Soṇa not to be conceited about the five aggregates.

title: Sona
blurb: The Buddha teaches a householder named Soṇa that any true ascetic understands the five aggregates.

title: Thiền Ðịnh
blurb: A mendicant should develop immersion (samādhi) in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.

title: Hỷ Ðược Ðoạn Tận
blurb: Right view is seeing the aggregates as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.

title: Hỷ Ðược Ðoạn Tận
blurb: Focusing properly on the five aggregates you see them as they are and become free.

title: Tham Luyến
blurb: Consciousness stands dependent on the other four aggregates, and this attachment is what fuels the cycle of rebirth.

title: Chủng Tử
blurb: Consciousness is like a seed that is planted in the soil of the other four aggregates and watered with craving.

title: Lời Cảm Hứng
blurb: The Buddha utters an enigmatic saying that non-identification leads to cutting off the fetters. A mendicant asks how to achieve this.

title: Thủ Chuyển
blurb: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood each of the five aggregates in the light of each of the four noble truths. This discourse includes definitions of each of the aggregates.

title: Bảy Xứ (Sattatthàna)
blurb: To be fully accomplished, a mendicant should investigate the five aggregates in light of the four noble truths, as well as their gratification, drawback, and escape. In addition, they should investigate the elements, sense fields, and dependent origination.

title: Chánh Ðẳng Giác
blurb: The Buddha declares that a mendicant is freed by wisdom by non-attachment to the aggregates, in just the same way as he himself. He then explains that the difference between himself and another awakened mendicant is simply that he was the first to discover the path and teach it to others.

title: Năm Vị (Vô ngã tưởng)
blurb: In the Deer Park at Varanasi the Buddha teaches the famous second discourse, on not-self with regard to the aggregates, to the group of five monks. At the conclusion, they become perfected ones.

title: Mahāli
blurb: Mahāli the Licchavi reports to the Buddha that the rival teacher Pūraṇa Kassapa asserts that there is no reason for beings to be either defiled or pure. The Buddha denies this, and goes on to explain how it happens.

title: Tỉnh Mặc
blurb: A mendicant should make an effort in seclusion in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.

title: Lửa Cháy
blurb: The five aggregates are burning.

title: Ngôn Lộ
blurb: All philosophers must accept that the five aggregates are described in language that refers to either the past, future, or present.

title: Chấp Trước
blurb: A mendicant comes to the Buddha to ask for instructions before going on retreat. The Buddha teaches them that in clinging to the aggregates one is bound by Māra.

title: Suy Tưởng
blurb: In conceiving regarding the aggregates one is bound by Māra.

title: Hoan Hỷ
blurb: In seeking enjoyment in the aggregates one is bound by Māra.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: One should let go of desire for what is impermanent, namely the five aggregates.

title: Khổ
blurb: One should let go of desire for what is suffering, namely the five aggregates.

title: Vô Ngã
blurb: One should let go of desire for what is not-self, namely the five aggregates.

title: Không Ðáng Thuộc Tự Ngã
blurb: One should let go of desire for what does not belong to self, namely the five aggregates.

title: Chỉ Trú Cho Ô Nhiễm
blurb: One should let go of desire for what appears tantalizing, namely the five aggregates.

title: Chấp Thủ Và Ưu Não
blurb: An ordinary person identifies their self with the five aggregates and suffers anxiety when the aggregates change. But a noble disciple, free of such identification, does not suffer.

title: Rādha
blurb: Venerable Rādha asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.

title: Surādha
blurb: Venerable Surādha asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit and be freed. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.

title: Vị Ngọt
blurb: Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Tập Khởi
blurb: Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Tập Khởi
blurb: Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Các Vị A-La-Hán
blurb: One who is freed after truly understanding the aggregates is a perfected one. They are the best of beings, even up to the pinnacle of existence. A set of verses extols the perfected ones.

title: Các Vị A-La-Hán
blurb: One who is freed after truly understanding the aggregates is a perfected one. They are the best of beings, even up to the pinnacle of existence.

title: Sư Tử
blurb: When a lion emerges from its lair and roars, animals are terrified. Similarly, when the Buddha teaches of the impermanence of the aggregates, even the gods are filled with fear. This is illustrated with a set of verses.

title: Ðáng Ðược Ăn
blurb: One of the most extensive discourses in this collection begins with the Buddha saying that when anyone recollects a past life, all they are recollecting is the five aggregates. He then gives a distinctive set of definitions of the aggregates in terms of their functions, and discusses them from various aspects.

title: Người Khất Thực
blurb: While staying at Kapilavatthu the Buddha dismissed the the Sangha for misbehaving. Later he decided to support them for the sake of the young mendicants. He reminds them that their livelihood is considered a lowly one, and that one should let go of bad thoughts and wrong views, and see the aggregates as impermanent.

title: Chấp Thủ Và Ưu Não
blurb: An ordinary person identifies their self with the five aggregates and suffers anxiety when the aggregates change. But a noble disciple, free of such identification, does not suffer.

title: Pàrileyya
blurb: Leaving behind the quarreling monks at Kosambi, the Buddha went to stay in the empty forest at Pārileyyaka. Ānanda brings some mendicants to receive a teaching, and one of them wonders how to see so as to end defilements in this very life. The Buddha teaches the 37 practices that lead to awakening, and then goes on to show that various ways of regarding the aggregates are conditioned phenomena.

title: Trăng Rằm
blurb: On a sabbath day with the Sangha at Sāvatthi, the Buddha answers a series of ten questions on the aggregates.

title: Ānanda
blurb: Ānanda praises Venerable Puṇṇa Mantāniputta, and says that it was when hearing his teaching on the aggregates that he understood the Dhamma.

title: Tissa
blurb: Venerable Tissa, the Blessed One’s paternal cousin, tells the monks that he is dissatisfied as a monk. When the Buddha hears of this, he calls Tissa to him, and questions him on the aggregates. As Tissa showed his understanding of each question, the Buddha praised him, lifting his spirits.

title: Yamaka
blurb: Venerable Yamaka had the wrong view that one whose defilements have ended is annihilated at death. The monks ask Sāriputta to help, and he asks Yamaka whether a realized one in this very life may be identified as one of the aggregates, or apart from them. Convinced, Yamaka lets go of his view and sees the Dhamma.

title: Anuràdha
blurb: Venerable Anurādha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that a realized one is described in terms other than “still existing after death” and so on. The wanderers say he’s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a realized one is not even apprehended in this life, so how can he be described after death?

title: Vakkàli
blurb: Venerable Vakkali is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, but says there is no point in seeing his physical body, as one who sees the Dhamma sees him. Later, Vakkali is taken to the Black Rock on Isigili, where he declares that he has no attachment to the aggregates, and takes his own life. The Buddha says that he had attained final extinguishment.

title: Assaji
blurb: Venerable Assaji is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, and learns that Assaji has difficulty maintaining his meditation. The Buddha encourages him to contemplate the impermanence of the aggregates.

title: Khemaka
blurb: Venerable Khemaka is ill, and some senior mendicants ask Dāsaka to convey their concern to him. There follows a series of exchanges mediated by Dāsaka until eventually Khemaka, despite his illness, goes to see the other mendicants himself. The seniors are asking to determine Khemaka’s understanding of the Dhamma, and he says that although he has let go of the five lower fetters, he still has a residual attachment to the five aggregates.

title: Channa
blurb: Hearing that the Buddha, while on his deathbed, had announced a special punishment for him, Venerable Channa asks for teachings from the mendicants. Unsatisfied, he seeks out Ānanda, who teaches him the address to Kaccāyana (SN 12.15).

title: Ba Thời Là Vô Thường
blurb: The aggregates are impermanent in the past and future as in the present.

title: Rāhula
blurb: Rāhula asks how to contemplate to let go of conceit. The Buddha urges him to see the aggregates as not-self.

title: Rāhula
blurb: Rāhula asks how to contemplate to let go of conceit and be free. The Buddha urges him to see the aggregates as not-self.

title: Dòng Sông
blurb: If you grasp at the aggregates as a self, you will meet with calamity, like a man swept down by a mountain river, grasping at grass or rushes.

title: Bông Hoa (hay Tăng trưởng)
blurb: The Buddha doesn’t dispute with the world; the world disputes with him. He has understood the five aggregates and explains them. Like a lotus, he was born in the swamp, but rises above it.

title: Bọt Nước
blurb: The Buddha gives a series of similes for the aggregates: physical form is like foam, feeling is like a bubble, perception is like a mirage, choices are like a coreless tree, and consciousness is like an illusion.

title: Phân Bò
blurb: Nothing in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence. In a past life, the Buddha was a great king with vast properties, but all those conditions have passed away.

title: Ðầu Ngón Tay
blurb: A mendicant asks whether anything in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence. The Buddha answers using the simile of a little dirt under his fingernail.

title: Thanh Tịnh (hay Biển)
blurb: A mendicant asks whether anything in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence.

title: Dây Thằng (Hay Dây Buộc)
blurb: Transmigration has no knowable beginning; even the oceans, mountains, and this great earth will perish. But like a dog on a leash running around a post, beings remain attached to the aggregates.

title: Dục Tham
blurb: Give up desire for the aggregates and they will come to an end.

title: Māra
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about Māra, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates. Seeing in this way leads to freedom.

title: Māra
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about Māra, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Tánh Chất Của Māra.
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about being subject to Māra, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about impermanence, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Vô Thường Tánh
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about what is of impermanent nature, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Khổ
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about suffering, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Khổ Tánh
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about what is of painful nature, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Vô Ngã
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about not-self, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Vô Ngã Tánh
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about what is of selfless nature, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Tận Pháp
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about what is liable to end, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Diệt Pháp
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about what is liable to vanish, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Chúng Sanh
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about a the term “sentient being”, and the Buddha explains in terms of craving for the five aggregates. He compares such craving to a child playing with sandcastles.

title: Tập Khởi Pháp (Samudayadhamma)
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about what is liable to arise, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Ðoạn Diệt Pháp (Nirodhadhamma)
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about what is liable to cease, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Mārādisuttaekādasaka
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha for a teaching before going on retreat, and the Buddha says that he should abandon desire, explaining in terms of the various teachings in SN 23.11–21.

title: Sợi Dây Tái Sanh
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about the tie or conduit to rebirth, and the Buddha explains in terms of craving for the five aggregates.

title: Ðoạn Diệt Tánh
blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha for a teaching before going on retreat, and the Buddha says that he should abandon desire, explaining what is liable to cease in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Mārādisuttaekādasaka
blurb: The Buddha tells Rādha that he should abandon desire, explaining in terms of the various teachings in SN 23.11–21.

title: Sở Biến Tri
blurb: The aggregates are to be fully understood, ending the defilements is the full understanding of them, and an arahant is the one who has achieved this.

title: Ðoạn Diệt Tánh
blurb: The Buddha tells Rādha that he should abandon desire, explaining what is liable to cease in terms of the five aggregates.

title: Sa Môn
blurb: Only a true ascetic fully understands the five aggregates.

title: Sa Môn
blurb: Only a true ascetic fully understands the five aggregates.

title: Bậc Dự Lưu
blurb: One who truly understand these five aggregates is a stream-enterer.

title: Bậc A-La-Hán
blurb: One who truly understand these five aggregates and is freed from them is a perfected one.

title: Dục Tham
blurb: Give up desire for the aggregates and they will come to an end.

title: Thế Gian Là Vô Thường
blurb: The view that the cosmos is not eternal is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Gió
blurb: The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates. But by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent, such a view is given up and one becomes a stream-enterer.

title: Hữu Biên
blurb: The view that the cosmos is finite is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Vô Biên
blurb: The view that the cosmos is infinite is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Mạng Với Thân Là Một
blurb: The view that the soul is the same thing as the body is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Mạng Với Thân Là Khác

title: Như Lai Có Tồn Tại
blurb: The view that a realized one still exists after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Như Lai Không Có Tồn Tại
blurb: The view that a realized one no longer exists after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Như Lai Có Tồn Tại Và Không Có Tồn Tại

title: Như Lai Không Tồn Tại Và Không Không Tồn Tại
blurb: The view that a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Gió
blurb: The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, such a view is given up.

title: Phi Hữu Phi Vô
blurb: The various views arise from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, these views are given up.

title: Cái Này Là Của Tôi
blurb: The view of me and mine is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Cái Này Là Tự Ngã
blurb: The view that the self is identical with the cosmos is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Nevahotinanahotisutta
blurb: The view that a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, this views is given up

title: Tự Ngã Có Sắc Và Không Sắc.
Tự Ngã Không Có Sắc Và Không Không Sắc
Có Thể Không Phải Của Tôi
blurb: The view that “I might not be” is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Chẳng Phải Khổ , Chẳng Phải Lạc
Không Có
blurb: The view of annihilationism is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Ðối Với Người Hành Ðộng
blurb: The view of moral nihilism is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Nhân
blurb: The view that denies causality is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Ðạt Tà Kiến
blurb: The view that transmigration is fixed is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Thế Gian Là Thường
blurb: The view that the cosmos is eternal is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

title: Uẩn
blurb: One with faith in the teachings on the five aggregates is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer

blurb: The arising of the five aggregates is the arising of suffering

title: Sùcimukhi (Tịnh Diện)
blurb: Sāriputta encountered a female wanderer named Sucimukhī, who asks him a series of enigmatic questions regarding what direction he faces when eating. Sāriputta denies all of them, explaining that they are various kinds of wrong livelihood.

title: Lý
blurb: Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing first absorption without any thought of self.

title: Không Tầm
blurb: Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing second absorption without any thought of self.

title: Hỷ
blurb: Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing third absorption without any thought of self.

title: Xả
blurb: Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing fourth absorption without any thought of self.

title: Không Vô Biên Xứ
blurb: Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing the dimension of infinite space without any thought of self.

title: Thức Vô Biên Xứ
blurb: Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing the dimension of infinite consciousness without any thought of self.

title: Diệt Tận Ðịnh
blurb: Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing the attainment of cessation without any thought of self.

title: Nghe
blurb: One becomes a spontaneously born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.

title: Chủng Loại
blurb: Dragons may be born from eggs, the womb, moisture, or spontaneously.

title: Ủng Hộ Bố Thí
blurb: One becomes an egg born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life, the appropriate aspiration, and giving various gifts.

title: Diệu Thắng
blurb: Dragons may be born from eggs, the womb, moisture, or spontaneously. Those born spontaneously are the best.

title: Ủng Hộ Bố Thí
blurb: One becomes a womb born, moisture born, or spontaneously born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life, the appropriate aspiration, and giving various gifts

blurb: Spontaneously born dragons sometimes transform their bodies and observe the sabbath in order to get a good rebirth.

blurb: One becomes a womb born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.

blurb: One becomes an egg born phoenix due to ambivalent deeds in a past life, the appropriate aspiration, and giving various gifts.

title: Chủng Loại
blurb: Centaurs may live in fragrant roots and other vegetation.

title: Ủng Hộ Bố Thí (1)
blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a god living in fragrant roots if they give various gifts.

title: Thiện Hành
blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a centaur.

title: Ủng Hộ Bằng Bố Thí (2-10)
blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a god living in various kinds of vegetation if they give various gifts

blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a god living in fragrant roots if they give fragrant roots.

blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a cloud god living in various kinds of cloud if they give various gifts.

blurb: When the cool cloud gods decide to revel in their own element, the weather becomes cool.

blurb: When the warm cloud gods decide to revel in their own element, the weather becomes warm.

title: Vô Tri (1)
blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not knowing form.

title: Không Hiện Quán (anabhisamaya) (1-5)

title: Thiền Tịnh (Patisallàna)
blurb: Develop seclusion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.

title: Vô Thường (4) Ngoại
blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Vô Thường (1) Nội
blurb: The six interior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Không Phải Của Các Ông
blurb: Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the aggregates?

title: Không Phải Của Các Ông
blurb: Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience.

title: Uddaka
blurb: The Buddha’s former teacher Uddaka Rāmaputta claimed to be a knowledge master, a universal victor, who had excised the tumor. But a true knowledge master understands the senses, a victor is freed from them, and excising the tumor is being free from attachment to the body.

title: Người Ðược An Ổn, Khỏi Các Khổ Ách
blurb: Someone who has given up attraction to the senses has arrived at the sanctuary.

title: Chấp Thủ
blurb: Pleasure and pain arise inside oneself due to grasping the senses.

title: Khổ
blurb: The origin and ending of suffering are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving.

title: Thế Giới
blurb: The origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering.

title: Thắng
blurb: Conceit stems from clinging to the senses.

title: Kiết Sử
blurb: The interior sense fields are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.

title: Chấp Thủ
blurb: The interior sense fields are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.

title: Khổ (4) Ngoại
blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Tuệ Tri (Pajànàti)
blurb: Without understanding the six interior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards them, it is impossible to be free of suffering.

title: Tuệ Tri
blurb: Without understanding the six exterior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards them, it is impossible to be free of suffering.

title: Nghe Trộm (upassuti)
blurb: While on retreat, the Buddha exclaims how the origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering. A mendicant overhears him, and the Buddha urges him to remember that teaching.

title: Māra (Ma) Lưới Bẫy
blurb: A mendicant who craves the senses is under the sway of Māra.

title: Māra (Ma) Lưới Bẫy
blurb: A mendicant who craves the senses is under the sway of Māra.

title: Thế Giới Dục Công Ðức
blurb: The Buddha states that the end of the world cannot be reached by traveling, yet it is impossible to end suffering without reaching the end of the world. The mendicants ask Ānanda to explain this enigmatic statement.

title: Thế Giới Dục Công Ðức
blurb: While practicing for awakening, the Buddha reflected that he should be diligent when his mind strayed to sense pleasures of the past, future, or present. He urges the mendicants to realize that place where the senses completely cease, and they ask Ānanda to explain this to them.

title: Sakka
blurb: Sakka asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

title: Pancasikha
blurb: The fairy Pañcasikha asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

title: Sāriputta
blurb: A mendicant informs Sāriputta that one of his friends had disrobed. Sāriputta attributes this to lack of sense restraint, eating too much, and not being wakeful.

title: Vô Ngã (4) Ngoại
blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Rāhula
blurb: Realizing that his son Rāhula was ripe for awakening, the Buddha takes him for a personal teaching. He questions Rāhula on the impermanence of all the factors of sense experience, leading Rāhula to realize full freedom.

title: Kiết Sử
blurb: The exterior sense fields are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.

title: Chấp Thủ
blurb: The exterior sense fields are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.

title: Vesālī
blurb: At the Great Wood, the householder Ugga of Vesālī asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

title: Vajjī
blurb: At Hatthigāma, the householder Ugga of Hatthigāma asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

title: Nālanda
blurb: At Nālandā, the householder Upāli asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

title: Bharadvāja
blurb: King Udena of Kosambi asks Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja how even young monks can maintain the celibate life. Piṇḍola says it’s because they see women as their sisters, mothers, or daughters. If this doesn’t work, they meditate on the ugliness of the body. Finally they exercise sense restraint.

title: Sona
blurb: At Rājagaha, the householder Soṇa asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

title: Ghosita
