blurb: The householder Ghosita asks Ānanda about the diversity of elements, and he answers in terms of the elements of sense experience.

title: Haliddhaka
blurb: The householder Hāliddakāni asks Mahākaccāna about the relation between the diversity of elements and the diversity of contacts, and he answers in terms of the elements of sense experience.

title: Chánh Giác (1)
blurb: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six interior sense fields.

title: Nakulapitā
blurb: At Suṁsumāragira, the householder Nakulapitā asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

title: Lohicca
blurb: Students of the brahmin Lohicca make a racket while collecting firewood near Mahākaccāna’s hut. Mahākaccāna hushes them and recites a series of verses contrasting the virtuous brahmins of old with those of today. Taking umbrage, they tell Lohicca, who goes to Mahākaccāna to ascertain the truth. But when Lohicca hears what Mahākaccāna teach on the six senses, he is so impressed he goes for refuge.

title: Verahaccàni
blurb: A student of the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan recommends to her the teaching of Venerable Udāyı̄, so she invites him for a meal. But when she displays a conceited attitude, he leaves without teaching. However, she corrects herself so he teaches her that pleasure and pain depend on the senses.

title: Sát Na Ở Devadaha
blurb: Not all mendicants have completed their work with regards to the six senses, but some of them have.

title: Thâu Nhiếp
blurb: The Buddha speaks of the hell named the “six senses” where all one experiences is sheer pain and unpleasantness.

title: Không Thâu Nhiếp (1)
blurb: Gods and humans take delight in the six sense, but the Realized One does not. This teaching is illustrated with a long series of verses.

title: Không Thâu Nhiếp (2)
blurb: Gods and humans take delight in the six sense, but the Realized One does not.

title: Các Lậu (1)
blurb: Let go of what is not yours: the six interior sense fields. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the senses?

title: Các Lậu (2)
blurb: Let go of what is not yours: the six exterior sense fields. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the senses?

title: Nội Căn Do Nhân (1)
blurb: Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are impermanent, how can the senses be permanent?

title: Chánh Giác (2)
blurb: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six exterior sense fields.

title: Nội Căn Do Nhân (2)
blurb: Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are suffering, how can the senses be free of suffering?

title: Nội Căn Do Nhân (3)
blurb: Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are not-self, how can the senses be self?

title: Ngoại Căn Do Nhân (1)
blurb: Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are impermanent, how can the senses be permanent?

title: Ngoại Căn Do Nhân (2)
blurb: Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are suffering, how can the senses be free of suffering?

title: Ngoại Căn Do Nhân (3)
blurb: Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are not-self, how can the senses be self?

title: Nghiệp
blurb: The six interior sense fields are not yours, but are old kamma, generated by choices in past lives. This is explained in terms of the four noble truths.

title: Thích ứng (1)
blurb: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent.

title: Thích ứng (2)
blurb: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as suffering.

title: Thích ứng (3)
blurb: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as not-self.

title: Thích ứng (4)
blurb: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent, suffering, and not-self.

title: Vị Ngọt (1)
blurb: The Buddha set out to find the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six interior sense fields.

title: Ðệ Tử Nội Trú
blurb: One with no “student” and no “teacher” dwells in happiness. Here the Buddha plays with the Pali words such that “student” means “one who dwells within” and “teacher” means “one who assails”.

title: Với Mục Ðích Gì?
blurb: If anyone asks why we live the holy life, it is for the ending of suffering.

title: Có Pháp Môn Nào?
blurb: How is it that a mendicant can declare their awakening? By understanding whether any desire arises from sense stimuli.

title: Căn
blurb: One is accomplished in the sense faculties by being freed from attachment to them.

title: Vị Thuyết Pháp
blurb: A speaker on the Dhamma is someone who teaches for letting go of the senses.

title: Duyệt Hỷ Tiêu Tận
blurb: Right view is seeing the interior sense fields as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.

title: Duyệt Hỷ Tiêu Tận (2)
blurb: Right view is seeing the exterior sense fields as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.

title: Duyệt Hỷ Tiêu Tận (3)
blurb: Focusing properly on the interior sense fields you see them as they are and become free.

title: Duyệt Hỷ Tiêu Tận (4)
blurb: Focusing properly on the exterior sense fields you see them as they are and become free.

title: Trong Vườn Xoài Jiivaka (1)
blurb: A mendicant should develop immersion (samādhi) in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the process of sense experience.

title: Vị Ngọt (2)
blurb: The Buddha set out to find the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six exterior sense fields.

title: Trong Vườn Xoài Jiivaka (2)
blurb: A mendicant should make an effort in seclusion in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the process of sense experience.

title: Kotthika (1)
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is impermanent, i.e. the process of sense experience.

title: Kotthika (2)
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is suffering, i.e. the process of sense experience.

title: Kotthika (3)
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is not-self, i.e. the process of sense experience.

title: Tà Kiến
blurb: Wrong view arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.

title: Thân Kiến
blurb: Identity view arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.

title: Ngã Kiến
blurb: View of self arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.

title: Nếu Không Có (1)
blurb: Beings are attached to the six interior sense fields due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.

title: Nếu Không Có (2)
blurb: Beings are attached to the six exterior sense fields due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.

title: Với Ưa Thích (1)
blurb: If you enjoy the six interior sense fields, you enjoy suffering.

title: Ưa Thích (2)
blurb: If you enjoy the six exterior sense fields, you enjoy suffering.

title: Khổ (1) Nội
blurb: The six interior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Sự Sanh Khởi (1)
blurb: The arising of the six interior sense fields is the arising of suffering.

title: Sự Sanh Khởi (2)
blurb: The arising of the six exterior sense fields is the arising of suffering.

title: Biển (1)
blurb: In the Buddha’s teaching the “ocean” is the sense organs, the current is the sense objects.

title: Biển (2)
blurb: In the Buddha’s teaching the “ocean” is the delights of sense stimuli.

title: Người Câu Cá
blurb: Sense pleasures are like a baited hook.

title: Tất Cả
blurb: The “all” consists of the six interior and exterior sense fields.

title: Cây Có Nhựa
blurb: Like a tree that yields sap when cut, so long as desire is present it will be activated by the senses.

title: Kotthika
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether the interior and exterior sense fields are the fetters of each other. No; it is desire that is the fetter, like the yoke that binds two oxen. One with no desire still experiences the senses but without fetters.

title: Kàmabhù
blurb: Kāmabhū asks Ānanda whether the interior and exterior sense fields are the fetters of each other. No; it is desire that is the fetter. One with no desire still experiences the senses but without fetters.

title: Udāyi
blurb: Udāyı̄ notes to Ānanda that the Buddha has taught the body as not-self; what then of consciousness? Ānanda then explains how consciousness arises dependent on conditions.

title: Với Lửa Cháy
blurb: It would be better for the sense organs to be pierced with red-hot spikes than to get attached to a pleasant sense experience.

title: Ví Dụ Tay Và Chân (1)
blurb: So long as this body exists there is suffering due to the senses.

title: Ví Dụ Tay Và Chân (2)
blurb: So long as this body exists there is suffering due to the senses.

title: Rắn Ðộc
blurb: The Buddha strings a series of powerful similes—vipers, murderers, an empty village, and more—into an extended parable of the dangers of existence and the way of escape.

title: Hỷ Lạc
blurb: When a mendicant has three qualities they live happily: sense restraint, moderation in eating, and wakefulness.

title: Con Rùa
blurb: A parable of a jackal who fails to eat a tortoise who stays still, with limbs retracted, like a mendicant guarding the senses.

title: Ðoạn Tận (1)
blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields should be given up.

title: Khúc Gỗ (1)
blurb: The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. A mendicant asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item. A cowherd named Nanda was listening, and determined to go forth.

title: Khúc Gỗ (2)
blurb: The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. Venerable Kimbila asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item.

title: Dục Lậu
blurb: The Buddha is invited to teach in a new hall in Kapilavatthu. Late at night, after teaching the Sakyans, the Buddha invites Moggallāna to teach. He speaks on the mental corruption that flows from attachment to the senses.

title: Khổ Pháp
blurb: The Buddha defines the things that entail suffering as the five aggregates, and urges mendicants to be free of desire for the six senses, giving a series of vivid similes. He then speaks of how even for a mendicant practicing restraint a lapse of mindfulness might occur from time to time.

title: Phải Gọi Là Gì (Kimsukà)
blurb: A mendicant goes to a series of teachers and asks how vision is purified. Dissatisfied with all their answers, he complains to the Buddha, who illustrates his quandary with the famous simile of the Kiṁsuka tree. Just as the same Kiṁsuka tree might be described differently by people focusing on the leaves, or the fruit, or the bark, etc., so too the various teachers each speak of the aspect of Dhamma most meaningful to them.

title: Ðờn Tỳ Bà
blurb: One should restrain the senses like a farmer watching over a field. The Buddha gives the parable of a man bewitched when he first hears a lute. He takes apart the instrument in search of the sound, but is disillusioned when no sound is found.

title: Sáu Sanh Vật
blurb: The senses are like a snake, a crocodile, a bird, a dog, a jackal, and a monkey all tied up together, pulling this way and that. Mindfulness is like a post that keeps them grounded.

title: Bó Lúa
blurb: The six senses are like a sheaf of barley struck with six flails; and the desire for rebirth is a seventh flail. The Buddha goes on to speak of the cunning trap of the gods; but the trap of Māra, conceit, is even more subtle.

title: Ðoạn Tận (2)
blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields should be given up by understanding.

title: Liễu Tri (1) (Parjànàna)
blurb: Without understanding the “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards it, it is impossible to be free of suffering.

title: Liễu Tri (2)
blurb: Without understanding the “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields and the associated consciousness and becoming dispassionate towards it, it is impossible to be free of suffering.

title: Bị Bốc Cháy
blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is burning. This is the famous “third sermon” taught at Gayā’s Head to the followers of the three Kassapa brothers.

title: Mù Lòa
blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields, and the phenomena they condition, is weighed down.

title: Thích Hợp (1) (Sàruppa)
blurb: The way to uproot all conceivings is to not conceive in relation to the six sense fields.

title: Vô Ngã (1) Nội
blurb: The six interior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Thích Hợp (2)
blurb: The way to uproot all conceivings is to not conceive in relation to the six sense fields.

title: Thích Hợp (3)
blurb: The way to uproot all conceivings is to investigate the six sense fields as impermanent, etc.

title: Jātidhammāsutta
blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is liable to be reborn, to age, etc.

title: Vô Thường (2) Ngoại
blurb: The six exterior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Aniccādisuttanavaka
blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is impermanent, etc.

title: Khổ (2) Ngoại
blurb: The six exterior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Bị Áp Ðảo… (upassattha)
blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is afflicted.

title: Vô Minh
blurb: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up ignorance. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.

title: Kiết Sử (1)
blurb: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the fetters. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.

title: Kiết Sử (2)
blurb: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the fetters. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.

title: Các Lậu Hoặc (1-2)
blurb: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the defilements. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.

title: Āsavasamugghātasutta
blurb: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the defilements. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.

title: Các Tùy Miên (1-2)
blurb: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the underlying tendencies. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.

title: Anusayasamugghātasutta
blurb: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the underlying tendencies. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.

title: Liễu Tri (Parijnnà)
blurb: To fully understand grasping, see how sense experience gives rise to feeling.

title: Vô Ngã (2) Ngoại
blurb: The six exterior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Ðược Chấm Dứt (1) (Pariyàdinnam)
blurb: To end grasping, see how sense experience gives rise to feeling.

title: Ðược Chấm Dứt (2)
blurb: To end grasping, investigate the six sense fields as impermanent, etc.

title: Bởi Migajāla
blurb: Venerable Migajāla asks how one lives alone, and how with a partner. The Buddha says that so long as one is bound by desire to the senses, one lives with a partner. A mendicant free of such desire dwells alone, even if they live in close association with worldly people.

title: Migajāla
blurb: Venerable Migajāla asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are delightful, but if you hold to them you will suffer. Meditating on this while on retreat, Migajāla became awakened.

title: Samiddhi (I)
blurb: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what Māra is. The Buddha says that Māra is present so long as the senses exist.

title: Samiddhi (2)
blurb: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what a “sentient being” is. The Buddha says that a sentient being is present so long as the senses exist.

title: Samiddhi (3)
blurb: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what suffering is. The Buddha says that suffering is present so long as the senses exist.

title: Samiddhi (4)
blurb: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what the world is. The Buddha says that the world is present so long as the senses exist.

title: Upasena
blurb: A viper bit Venerable Upasena, but he remained poised, declaring that he had no identification with the six senses.

title: Upavāna (1)
blurb: The teaching that can be realized in this very life is the desire for the senses, and letting go of that desire.

title: Vô Thường (3) Nội
blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Sáu Xúc Xứ (1)
blurb: One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.

title: Sáu Xúc Xứ (2)
blurb: One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.

title: Sáu Xúc Xứ (3)
blurb: One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.

title: Bệnh (1)
blurb: Hearing that a newly-ordained mendicant was sick, the Buddha visited him to offer support and Dhamma encouragement.

title: Bệnh (2)
blurb: Hearing that a newly-ordained mendicant was sick, the Buddha visited him to offer support and Dhamma encouragement.

title: Rādha (1)
blurb: Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is impermanent.

title: Rādha (2)
blurb: Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is suffering.

title: Rādha (2)
blurb: Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is not-self.

title: Vô Minh (I)
blurb: Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent.

title: Vô Minh (2)
blurb: Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent. Then a mendicant truly understands, and sees everything differently.

title: Khổ (3) Nội
blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Tỷ Kheo
blurb: Some mendicants check with the Buddha that it’s correct to say that the spiritual life is lived to end suffering. The Buddha answers that it is, and explains what that suffering is: the process of sense experience.

title: Lokapañhāsutta
blurb: The “world” consisting of six sense experience is said to be falling apart.

title: Thế Giới
blurb: The Buddhas of the past cannot be described in terms of the six senses.

title: Biến Hoại (Paloka)
blurb: The Buddha tells Ānanda that in the training of the noble one the “world” consisting of six sense experience is liable to wear out.

title: Trống Không
blurb: The Buddha tells Ānanda that the “world” consisting of six sense experience is empty because it is empty of self and what belongs to self.

title: Vắn Tắt
blurb: Ānanda asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are impermanent, etc.

title: Channa
blurb: Sāriputta and Mahācunda visit Channa, who is ill. Channa says that he lacks for no care, but is in such great pain that he wishes to take his own life, insisting that he will do so blamelessly. Sāriputta tries to dissuade him, and questions him closely about attachment to the six senses. Later Channa does take his own life, and the Buddha confirmed that, despite Sāriputta’s doubts, he was indeed blameless.

title: Puñña
blurb: Venerable Puṇṇa goes to the Buddha and asks for a teaching before he departs to the foreign land of Sunāparanta. The Buddha warns him that folk there are fierce, and questions whether he is ready for such a difficult assignment.

title: Bāhiya
blurb: Venerable Bāhiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are impermanent, etc.

title: Ái Nhiễm (Ejà)
blurb: Being stirred by craving is painful, so the Realized One lives unstirred, not identifying with any aspect of sense experience.

title: Vô Ngã (3) Nội
blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

title: Ái Nhiễm
blurb: Being stirred by craving is painful, so the Realized One lives unstirred, not identifying with any aspect of sense experience, or indeed, with the entire scope of the aggregates, elements, and senses.

title: Cả Hai (1)
blurb: The dyad is the interior sense organ with its corresponding exterior sense stimulus.

title: Cả Hai (2)
blurb: Consciousness arises from the dyad of the interior sense organ with its corresponding exterior sense stimulus. All these things are conditioned, impermanent, and constantly falling apart.

title: Thâu Nhiếp
blurb: The six fields of contact lead to suffering if left unguarded, but if guarded lead to happiness. A lengthy set of verses illustrate this.

title: Thâu Nhiếp
blurb: Venerable Māluṅkyaputta asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha wonders how to teach an old monk like him, then questions him on his desire for sense experience that has been or might be, and encourages him to simply let sense experience be. Māluṅkyaputta says he understands, and expands the Buddha’s teaching in a series of verses.

title: Thối Ðọa (Parihànam)
blurb: When a mendicant tolerates evil thoughts that arise from the senses, they are liable to decline. If they don’t tolerate them, they’re not liable to decline. When such thoughts not longer arise, they have mastered the senses.

title: Sống Phóng Dật (Pamàdavihàri)
blurb: When a mendicant lives without restraint regarding the senses, they are negligent. If they have restraint, they are diligent.

title: Nhiếp Hộ (Samvara)
blurb: Non-restraint is delighting in the senses, restraint is not delighting in them.

title: Thiền Ðịnh
blurb: Develop meditative immersion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.

title: Căn Bản Của Xúc
blurb: The three feelings are each produced by the appropriate contact.

title: Thiền Ðịnh
blurb: There are three feelings, and a meditator practicing immersion can understand them.

title: Sống Một Mình
blurb: A mendicant wonders how there can be three kinds of feeling, yet all of them are suffering.

title: Hư Không (1)
blurb: Feelings arise in the body like winds blowing in the sky. With illustrative verses.

title: Hư Không (2)
blurb: Feelings arise in the body like winds blowing in the sky.

title: Khách Xá
blurb: Feelings arise in the body like guests in a hotel.

title: Thuộc Sở Hữu (1)
blurb: The Buddha explains the feelings to Ānanda in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Thuộc Sở Hữu (2) (Santakam)
blurb: The Buddha asks about the feelings to Ānanda in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Tám Lần (1) (Aṭṭhaka)
blurb: The Buddha explains the feelings to several mendicants in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Tám Lần (2)
blurb: The Buddha asks about the feelings to several mendicants in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Năm Vật Dụng
blurb: The chamberlain Pañcakaṅga disagreed with Venerable Udāyī about how many kinds of feeling the Buddha taught. The Buddha affirms that each is a genuine teaching, valid in different contexts.

title: Bởi Vị Tỷ Kheo
blurb: The Buddha has taught many different kinds of feeling, valid in different contexts.

title: An Lạc
blurb: There are three feelings, and all of them are suffering.

title: Sìvaka
blurb: When the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka asks if all feelings are caused by karma in past lives. The Buddha denies this, asserting that feelings have many different causes.

title: Một Trăm Lẻ Tám
blurb: The Buddha explains the different kinds of feelings analyzed into 108 aspects.

title: Vị Tỷ Kheo
blurb: A mendicant asks the Buddha to explain the feelings in terms of the four noble truths.

title: Trí Về Quá Khứ
blurb: Before his awakening the Buddha reflected on feeling in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Ñāṇasutta
blurb: At his awakening, the Buddha saw feeling in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Bởi Vị Tỷ Kheo
blurb: Several mendicants ask the Buddha to explain the feelings in terms of the four noble truths.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn (1)
blurb: One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn (2)
blurb: One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn (3)
blurb: One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.

title: Suddhikasutta
blurb: There are three feelings: painful, pleasant, neutral.

title: Ðoạn Tận
blurb: One should give up desire for pleasant feeling, aversion for painful feeling, and ignorance regarding neutral feeling.

title: Thanh Tịnh, Không Liên Hệ Ðến Vật Chất
blurb: The Buddha explains feelings as spiritual and carnal, associated with worldly states and with deep meditation.

title: Vực Thẳm (Pàtàla)
blurb: Ordinary people think the ocean is a bottomless abyss; but really, it is the three feelings.

title: Cần Phải Quán Kiến
blurb: See pleasant feeling as painful, painful feeling as a dart, and neutral feeling as impermanent.

title: Với Mũi Tên
blurb: Both ordinary and awakened people experience the three feelings. The difference is that when an ordinary person is stricken with feeling, they react, creating more suffering, whereas an awakened person responds with equanimity.

title: Tật Bệnh
blurb: A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.

title: Tật Bệnh (2)
blurb: A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.

title: Vô Thường
blurb: The three feelings are impermanent.

title: Ác Giới
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Khả Ý Và Không Khả Ý (1)
blurb: Five things that make a woman either agreeable or disagreeable to men.

title: Ít Nghe
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Biếng Nhác (Kusīta)
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Thất Niệm (Mutthassati)
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Năm Cấm (Pancaveram)
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Không Phẫn Nộ
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Anupanāhīsutta
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Anissukīsutta
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Amaccharīsutta
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Anaticārīsutta
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Susīlasutta
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Khả Ý, Không Khả Ý (2)
blurb: Five things that make a man either agreeable or disagreeable to women.

title: Bahussutasutta
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Āraddhavīriyasutta
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Upaṭṭhitassatisutta
blurb: A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.

title: Pañcasīlasutta
blurb: A woman who keeps the five precepts has a good rebirth.

title: Không Sợ Hãi (Visàradà)
blurb: A woman with five powers lives confident at home.

title: Ức Chế (Pasaykà)
blurb: A woman with five powers lives at home having won over her husband.

title: Chinh Phục (Abhibhùyya)
blurb: A woman with five powers lives at home with her husband under her control.

title: Một
blurb: A man with one power has a woman under his control: authority.

title: Bộ Phận
blurb: A woman may be complete with five powers.

title: Họ Ðuổi Ði
blurb: A woman lacking in any of the five powers may be expelled from a family.

title: Ðặc Thù (Avenika)
blurb: Five kinds of suffering that only women are subject to, not men.

title: Nhân
blurb: It is not because of beauty, wealth, relatives, or sons that a woman has a good rebirth, but because of ethical conduct.

title: Sự Kiện (Thànam)
blurb: For a woman who has not made merit, five things are hard to come by.

title: Không Sợ Hãi
blurb: A woman with five qualities lives confidently at home.

title: Tăng Truởng
blurb: A woman who grows in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom acquires the best.

title: Ba Sự Việc
blurb: A woman who is selfish, envious, and lustful has a bad rebirth.

title: Phẫn Nộ
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Có Hận (Upanàhi)
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Tật Ðố (Issukii)
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Do Xan Tham (Macharena)
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Phạm Dâm (Aticari)
blurb: A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.

title: Khát Ái
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is craving.

title: Nibbāna (Niết-bàn)
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about extinguishment and the path to realize it.

title: Bộc Lưu (Ogha)
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what are the floods.

title: Chấp Thủ (Upàdànam)
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is grasping.

title: Hữu
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about the three realms of rebirth.

title: Khổ
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about suffering.

title: Có Thân (Sakkāya)
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is identity.

title: Khó Làm
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is difficult to do in this teaching and training.

title: A-La-Hán
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about perfection (arahantship) and the path to realize it.

title: Vị Thuyết Pháp
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta who in the world are proponents of Dhamma.

title: Có Cái Gì?
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about the purpose of the spiritual path.

title: Ðiều Hòa Hơi Thở (Assàsa)
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about who has attained consolation.

title: Ðiều Hòa Hơi Thở Tối Thượng
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about who has attained supreme consolation.

title: Thọ
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is feeling.

title: Lậu Hoặc
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is a defilement.

title: Vô Minh.
blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is ignorance.

title: Khó Làm
blurb: The wanderer Sāmaṇḍaka asks Sāriputta what is difficult to do in this teaching and training.

title: Sakka (Ðế-thích)
blurb: Moggallāna ascended to the heaven of the Thirty-Three to address Sakka, the lord of gods, and his extensive retinue. He spoke in praise of going for refuge, as it leads to heaven. Sakka affirmed this on multiple occasions, adding that gods who had gone for refuge and kept ethics surpassed the other deities in the heavens.

title: Với Tầm
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the first absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Candana
blurb: The dialogue in SN 40.10 is repeated with a series of other deities.

title: Không Tầm
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the second absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Với Lạc
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the third absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Xả
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the fourth absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Hư Không
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of infinite space was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Thức
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of infinite consciousness was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Vô Sở Hữu Xứ
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of nothingness was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Phi Tưởng
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Vô Tướng
blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the signless immersion was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

title: Thăm Người Bệnh
blurb: When Citta was on his deathbed, rather than receiving comfort, he gave comfort and teaching to those present.

title: Kiết Sử
blurb: Citta the householder hears of a conversation among the monks regarding the distinction between the fetters and the things that are fettered. He goes to ask them on this topic, but they are unable to give a satisfactory answer, so he explained it to them. It is desire that is the fetter, like the yoke that binds two oxen.

title: Isidattà (1)
blurb: Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. He asks them about the diversity of the elements, but only the junior monk, Isidatta, is able to answer.

title: Isidattà (2)
blurb: Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. He asks them what is the cause of the ten metaphysical questions and the 62 views of the Brahmajāla Sutta, but only the junior monk, Isidatta, is able to answer. Citta realizes that Isidatta is in fact an unseen friend of his from Avantī. He offers to support him with requisites, but Isidatta left, never to return.

title: Mahaka
blurb: Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. When they left he followed them, and witnessed the junior monk Venerable Mahaka performing a psychic feat. Citta approached Mahaka in his hut and asked him to demonstrate his skills, and Mahaka obliged. Citta offers to support him with requisites, but Mahaka left, never to return.

title: Kàmabhù (1)
blurb: Venerable Kāmabhū asks Citta to explain an enigmatic verse on a “one-spoked chariot”. After a brief consideration, Citta is able to explain it in detail.

title: Kàmabhù (2)
blurb: Citta asks Kāmabhū about the different kinds of processes (saṅkhāra) in a series of questions that lead to the most profound of meditation experiences.

title: Godatta
blurb: Venerable Godatta asks Citta whether the liberations of measurelessness, nothingness, emptiness, and signlessness are different states, or just different words for the same thing. Citta explains that they are both: they are terms for different meditation experiences, but may also be used of perfection or arahantship.

title: Nigaṇṭha (Ni-kiền-tử)
blurb: The Jain leader Mahāvīra, known as Nigaṇṭha Nātaputa in the Buddhist tradition, is visited by Citta. Mahāvīra asks him whether he believes in a certain state of immersion. When Citta replies that he doesn’t go by faith in the Buddha on this point, Mahāvīra is delighted. But it turns out Citta doesn’t need faith, as he experiences such a state for himself.

title: Acela (Lõa thể)
blurb: Citta meets with the naked ascetic Kassapa, an old friend of his, and asks what gains he has realized from the spiritual life. Kassapa admits he has realized no higher attainments, whereupon Citta reveals he has realized many such attainments. Kassapa decides to ordain as a Buddhist mendicant.

title: Manicùlam (Châu báu trên đỉnh đầu)
blurb: Several members of the king’s retinue criticize the Buddhist mendicants for accepting offerings of money. Chief Maṇicūḷaka is among them, and he visits the Buddha to find out the truth. The Buddha categorically denies the accusation.

title: Canda (Tàn bạo)
blurb: A headman known for his aggressive nature approaches the Buddha and asks how to give up irritability. The Buddha points out that such reactions are fueled by greed, hate, and delusion.

title: Bhadra (Hiền) hay Bhagandha-Hat—Thaha
blurb: The chief Bhadraka asks the Buddha about the origin and ending of suffering, and the Buddha points out that a loss among Bhadraka’s own community would cause him suffering, due to his attachment.

title: Ràsiya
blurb: The chief Rāsiya asks whether the Buddha completely rejects all forms of asceticism. The Buddha denies that this is the case, and explains what he means by the middle way in a lengthy disquisition, covering useful and useless forms of asceticism.

title: Pātali (Khả ý)
blurb: The chief Pāṭaliya asks whether the Buddha knows magic. He says he does—but that does not make him a magician.

title: Putta
blurb: Talapuṭa the head of a troupe of performers asks the Buddha whether the belief that performers have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by inciting lust they head to a bad rebirth. Talapuṭa is distressed and asks to ordain.

title: Yodhàjivo (Kẻ chiến đấu)
blurb: Yodhājı̄va the professional warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Yodhājı̄va is distressed and takes refuge.

title: Voi
blurb: Hatthāroha the elephant warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Hatthāroha is distressed and takes refuge.

title: Ngựa
blurb: Assāroha the cavalry warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Yodhājı̄va is distressed and asks to ordain.

title: Người Ðất Phương Tây hay Người Ðã Chết
blurb: The chief Asibandhakaputta asks whether the rituals advocated by the western brahmins can bring a person to heaven. The Buddha asserts that only good deeds can take you to a good rebirth, and rituals have no effect.

title: Thuyết Pháp
blurb: The chief Asibandhakaputta asks the Buddha why, if he has equal compassion for all, he teaches some more than others. The Buddha answers with a simile of a field: a farmer knows to put most of their effort into the fertile land.

title: Vỏ Ốc
blurb: The Buddha asks the chief Asibandhakaputta, a Jain, how Mahāvīra the Jain leader teaches his followers. He replies that you go to a rebirth depending on what you usually do. But the Buddha points out that even a killer only spends a small amount of time actually killing. The Buddha’s approach is to point out that deeds have results, and to encourage the abandoing of bad deeds and the adoption of good deeds.

title: Gia Tộc
blurb: Mahāvīra asks Asibandhakaputta to refute the Buddha on behalf of the Jains. He suggests to try to trap the Buddha with a dilemma: he claims to have compassion for householders, yet visits them with a large Saṅgha in a time of scarcity. But the Buddha says no family has been harmed from this.

title: Ānanda (hay Sự có mặt của ngã)
blurb: Vacchagotta asks the Buddha whether a self exists, but the Buddha is silent. When Ānanda later asks him why he didn’t answer, the Buddha replied that it was to avoid misunderstanding.

title: Trưởng Lão Ni Khemà
blurb: While staying in Toraṇavatthu, King Pasenadi wishes to visit a spiritual teacher, and the nun Khemā is highly recommended to him. He asks her about whether a realized one still exists after death, and she says this is not answerable. Later he visits the Buddha, who replies in exactly the same way.

title: Sabhiya
blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna whether a Realized One exists after death. He answers that the basis for describing a Realized One no longer applies. Vacchagotta is impressed that such a junior monk understands this subtle matter.

title: Anuràdha.
blurb: Venerable Anurādha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that a realized one is described in terms other than “still existing after death” and so on. The wanderers say he’s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a realized one is not even apprehended in this life, so how can they be described after death?

title: Sāriputta-Kotthika (1) (hay Trú trước)
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that to answer this would be to get involved in the five aggregates, something that a Realized One is free from.

title: Sāriputta—Kotthika (2) (hay Tập khởi)
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that one who understands the five aggregates would not think in such terms.

title: Sāriputta—Kotthika (3) (hay Ái)
blurb: Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that only someone who has desire for the five aggregates would think in such terms.

title: Sāriputta—Kotthika (4) (hay Vườn)
blurb: Sāriputta asks Mahākoṭṭhita whether a Realized One exists after death. Mahākoṭṭhita says that only someone who delights in the five aggregates would think in such terms, and offers a variety of further explanations of the same point.

title: Moggallāna (hay Xứ)
blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Moggallāna the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. Moggallāna says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the six senses. Vacchagotta then asks the Buddha the same questions.

title: Vaccha (hay Trói buộc)
blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. He says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the five aggregates.

title: Luận Nghị Ðường (Kutūhalasālā)
blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta reports to the Buddha a conversation among ascetics on the views of the six heretical teachers as to where a perfected one is reborn. Unsure of what the Buddha’s position was, he asks how it is to be understood. The Buddha says it is like a flame that burns dependent on fuel, and goes out when that fuel is extinguished.

title: Nandiya
blurb: The wanderer Nandiya asks how many things lead to extinguishment.

title: Vô Minh
blurb: Following ignorance comes the wrong eightfold path. But the right eightfold path follows true knowledge.

title: Trú (1)
blurb: The Buddha goes on retreat for a fortnight. When he emerges, he describes his meditation on the conditionality of the eightfold path, which was similar to a practice he did shortly after awakening.

title: Trú (2)
blurb: The Buddha goes on retreat for a fortnight. When he emerges, he describes his meditation on the conditionality of the eightfold path, which was similar to a practice he did shortly after awakening.

title: Hữu Học
blurb: A mendicant asks how a person is a “trainee”.

title: Sanh Khởi (1)
blurb: The eightfold path does not arise apart from a Realized One.

title: Sanh Khởi (2)
blurb: The eightfold path does not arise apart from a Holy One’s training.

title: Thanh Tịnh (1)
blurb: The eight pure factors of the path do not arise apart from a Realized One.

title: Thọ (I-IV)
blurb: Develop the eightfold path to abandon the three cravings. This sutta is doubled by replacing taṇhā with another form of the same word, tasina. This variation is found in Burmese but not Sinhalese manuscripts.

title: Thanh Tịnh (2)
blurb: The eight pure factors of the path do not arise apart from a Holy One’s training.

title: Vườn Gà (1) (Kukkutàràma)
blurb: In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the unholy life, or the unspiritual path. It is the wrong eightfold path.

title: Vườn Gà (2)
blurb: In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the holy life, or the spiritual path. It is the right eightfold path.

title: Vườn Gà (3)
blurb: In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the spiritual path, one who follows the spiritual path, and the goal of the spiritual path.

title: Một Nửa (Upaddham)
blurb: When Ānanda says that good friendship is half the spiritual path, the Buddha rebukes him, saying that it is in fact the whole of the spiritual path. Based on good friendship, the eightfold path is fulfilled.

title: Tà Tánh
blurb: The wrong eightfold path is a wrong state; the right eightfold path is a right state.

title: Pháp Bất Thiện
blurb: The factors of the wrong eightfold path are unskillful qualities; those of the right eightfold path are skillful qualities.

title: Ðạo Lộ
blurb: The wrong eightfold path is the wrong way; the right eightfold path is the right way.

title: Ðạo Lộ (2)
blurb: Regardless of whether one is a lay person or a renunciate, the Buddha praises the right way, not the wrong way. The wrong eightfold path is the wrong way; the right eightfold path is the right way.

title: Không Phải Chân Nhân (1) (Asappurisa)
blurb: A bad person practices wrong eightfold path; a good person practices the right eightfold path.

title: Không Phải Chân Nhân (2)
blurb: A bad person practices wrong eightfold path, and a worse person has wrong knowledge and wrong liberation, too; a good person is the opposite.

title: Cái Bình
blurb: Someone without the eightfold path is easily knocked over, like a pot without a stand.

title: Ðịnh
blurb: The eightfold path is the necessary prerequisite for right immersion (samādhi).

title: Thọ
blurb: The eightfold path is developed to understand the three feelings.

title: Uttiya hay Uttika
blurb: The Buddha taught the eightfold path in order to give up the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

title: Sāriputta
blurb: When Sāriputta says that good friendship is the whole of the spiritual path, the Buddha praises him. Based on good friendship, the eightfold path is fulfilled.

title: Hạnh (Patipatti)
blurb: The wrong eightfold path is wrong practice; the right eightfold path is right practice.

title: Người Hành Trì
blurb: Practicing the wrong eightfold path is wrong; practicing the right awakening path is right.

title: Thối Thất (Viraddha)
blurb: Neglecting the eightfold path you neglect the path to the end of suffering.

title: Ðến Bờ Bên Kia
blurb: The eightfold path leads from the near to the far shore. With a long set of verses.

title: Sa Môn Hạnh (1)
blurb: The eightfold path is the ascetic life. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.

title: Sa Môn Hạnh (2)
blurb: The eightfold path is the ascetic life. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.

title: Bà La Môn Hạnh (1-2)
blurb: The eightfold path is brahminhood. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.

title: Bà La Môn Hạnh (1-2)
blurb: The eightfold path is brahminhood. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.

title: Phạm Hạnh (1-2)
blurb: The eightfold path is the spiritual path. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.

title: Phạm Hạnh (1-2)
blurb: The eightfold path is the spiritual path. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.

title: Bà La Môn
blurb: Ānanda sees the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi resplendent on his all-white chariot. He asks the Buddha whether there is a similarly divine vehicle in Buddhism. The Buddha responds by drawing a detailed set of analogies between the eightfold path and a chariot.

title: Ly Tham
blurb: If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for the fading away of lust.

title: Saṁyojanappahānādisuttachakka
blurb: If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for giving up fetters, etc.

title: Không Chấp Thủ
blurb: If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for final extinguishment without anything left over.

title: Liên Hệ Ðến Viễn Ly.
blurb: As the dawn precedes the sun, good friendship precedes the eightfold path.

title: Sīlasampadādisuttapañcaka
blurb: As the dawn precedes the sun, ethics, enthusiasm, confidence, right view, and diligence precede the eightfold path.

title: Với Mục Ðích Gì?
blurb: When asked what is the purpose of the spiritual path, you should answer that it is the ending of suffering.

title: Ngã, Kiến, Không Phóng Dật. (1)
blurb: As the dawn precedes the sun, proper attention precedes the eightfold path.

title: Một Tỷ Kheo Khác (1)
blurb: A mendicant asks what is the purpose of the spiritual path, and the Buddha answers that it is the ending of suffering.

title: Một Tỷ Kheo Khác (2)
blurb: A mendicant asks about Nibbāna and the deathless.

title: Phân Tích
blurb: The Buddha presents the eightfold path together with a detailed analysis of each factor. It should be assumed that these explanations apply wherever the eightfold path is taught.

title: Sùka (Râu lúa mì)
blurb: A mendicant with wrong view will develop the path in the wrong way, harming themselves as if grabbing a sharp spike the wrong way.

title: Sanh (2)
blurb: The awakening factors do not arise apart from a Holy One’s training.

title: Tuyết Sơn
blurb: Dragons nurture their strength in the Himalayas, then enter the rivers and reach the ocean. So too, a mendicant nurtures ethics and then develops the seven awakening factors.

title: Sanh Loại
blurb: Just as living creatures are based on the earth, the awakening factors are based on ethics.

title: Ví Dụ Mặt Trời (1)
blurb: Just as the dawn precedes the sun, good friendship precedes the awakening factors.

title: Ví Dụ Mặt Trời (2)
blurb: Just as the dawn precedes the sun, proper attention precedes the awakening factors.

title: Bệnh (1)
blurb: When Mahākassapa was sick, the Buddha taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.

title: Bệnh (2)
blurb: When Mahāmoggallāna was sick, the Buddha taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.

title: Bệnh (3)
blurb: When the Buddha was sick, Mahācunda taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.

title: Ðến Bờ Bên Kia Hay Không Có Hơn Nữa
blurb: The awakening factors lead from the near to the far shore.

title: Thối Thất (Virdddha) Hay Tấn Tu (Aradda)
blurb: Those who neglect the awakening factors neglect the path to the end of suffering.

title: Thánh
blurb: The awakening factors are noble and emancipating.

title: Nhàm Chán
blurb: The awakening factors lead to disenchantment.

title: Thân
blurb: Just as the body depends on food, the awakening factors depend on nutriment. The Buddha gives specific conditions for each of the factors.

title: Giác (Bodhanà)
blurb: They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.

title: Thuyết Giảng
blurb: A simple statement on the awakening factors.

title: Trú Xứ (Thànà)
blurb: Frequently focusing on things tends to promote similar qualities, whether good (awakening factors) or bad (hindrances).

title: Phi Như Lý (Ayoniso)
blurb: Improper attention grows the hindrances, proper attention grows the awakening factors.

title: Không Tổn Giảm (Aparihàni) (1)
blurb: The awakening factors lead to non-decline.

title: Ðoạn Tận (Khaya)
blurb: The awakening factors lead to the ending of craving.

title: Ðoạn Diệt
blurb: The awakening factors lead to the cessation of craving.

title: Thể Nhập (Nibbedha)
blurb: The awakening factors partake of penetration.

title: Một Pháp
blurb: Nothing is as effective for getting rid of fetters as the awakening factors.

title: Udāyi
blurb: Venerable Udāyı̄ celebrates his progress on the path, gaining faith as a householder, going forth, and realizing the Dhamma. Now he develops the awakening factors for the end of suffering.

title: Giới
blurb: Here the awakening factors are described in the context of hearing the teachings and reflecting on them. This leads to full enlightenment, or at least to some lesser attainment.

title: Thiện (1)
blurb: Skillful qualities are rooted in diligence, which promotes the awakening factors.

title: Thiện (2)
blurb: Skillful qualities are rooted in proper attention, which promotes the awakening factors.

title: Cấu Uế (1)
blurb: Hindrances sully the mind like impurities in gold.

title: Các Cấu Uế (2)
blurb: Awakening factors purify the mind and lead to liberation.

title: Như Lý (1)
blurb: Improper attention promotes the hindrances; proper attention promotes the awakening factors.

title: Như Lý (2)
blurb: The awakening factors lead to growth and non-decline.

title: Tăng Trưởng Hay Không Giảm Thiểu
blurb: Hindrances sully the mind, awakening factors purify it.

title: Chướng Ngại, Triền Cái
blurb: Listening to the teaching, the hindrances are given up and the awakening factors developed.

title: Cây
blurb: As some large trees with small seeds will overgrow and ruin other trees, so the hindrances overgrow and ruin the mind.

title: Triền Cái
blurb: The hindrances cause blindness, the awakening factors cause vision.

title: Chuyển (Vatta)
blurb: The various awakening factors can be donned at different times of the day, like a man who puts on bright colored clothes whenever he wants.

title: Các Kiêu Mạn (Vidhà)
blurb: Anyone who abandons the three kinds of discrimination does so due to the awakening factors.

title: Chuyển Luân
blurb: As the Wheel-turning Monarch manifests seven treasures, the Realized One manifests the seven awakening factors.

title: Māra
blurb: The awakening factors crush Māra’s army.

title: Liệt Tuệ (Duppanna)
blurb: A stupid person has not developed the awakening factors.

title: Có Trí Tuệ
blurb: A wise person has developed the awakening factors.

title: Bần Cùng (Daliddo)
blurb: A person who has not developed the awakening factors is called “poor”.

title: Không Bần Cùng
blurb: A person who has developed the awakening factors is called “prosperous”.

title: Mặt Trời
blurb: As the dawn precedes the sunrise, so too good friendship precedes the awakening factors.

title: Chi Phần (1)
blurb: No internal factor helps the awakening factors so much as proper attention.

title: Chi Phần (2)
blurb: No external factor helps the awakening factors so much as good friendship.

title: Vị Tỷ-Kheo
blurb: They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.

title: Ðồ Ăn
blurb: The Buddha spells out in detail the factors that nourish the hindrances, and those that nourish the awakening factors.

title: Pháp Môn (Pariyàya)
blurb: Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the seven awakening factors, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains by giving a detailed analytical treatment that he says is beyond the scope of the wanderers.

title: Lửa
blurb: Which awakening factors should be developed when the mind is tired, and which when it is energetic? And what is always useful?

title: Từ
blurb: Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the four Brahmā meditations, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains the detailed connection between the Brahmā meditations and the awakening factors, which taken together lead to liberation.

title: Sangàrava
blurb: The brahmin Saṅgārava asks why sometimes verses stay in memory while other times they don’t. The Buddha replies that it is due to the presence of either the hindrances of awakening factors. He gives a set of similes illustrating each of the hindrances with different bowls of water.

title: Abhaya (Vô úy)
blurb: Prince Abhaya reports Pūraṇa Kassapa’s view that there is no cause for ignorance or knowledge, and asks the Buddha’s opinion. The Buddha replies that the cause of ignorance is the hindrances, and the cause of knowledge is the awakening factors.

title: Bộ Xương
blurb: A series of passages on the benefits of meditating on a skeleton. Some editions treat the sections as separate suttas.

title: Kundaliya (Người đeo vòng tai)
blurb: The wanderer Kuṇḍaliya points out that some ascetics argue for the sake of winning debates. But the Buddha says his path is for the sake of liberation. Kuṇḍaliya asks what leads to liberation, and the Buddha traces a sequence of conditions back to sense restraint.

title: Hơi Thở Vô Hơi Thở Ra
Bất Khả Lạc Hay Toàn Thế Giới
Nóc Nhà
blurb: The awakening factors lead to extinguishment, like rafters holding up the roof peak.

title: Upavāna
blurb: Sāriputta asks Upavāṇa how one can reflect and see the awakening factors in oneself.

title: Sanh (1)
blurb: The awakening factors do not arise apart from a Realized One.

title: Trú Xứ Tỷ-Kheo Ni
blurb: When Ānanda visits the nuns’s quarters they tell him that their meditation is prospering to higher and higher levels. Ānanda reporrts the good news to the Buddha, who speaks of two ways of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation: directed and undirected.

title: Ambapāli
blurb: At Ambapālī’s mango grove, the Buddha teaches the mendicants about the “way to convergence”, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Ðại Nhân
blurb: Sāriputta asks the Buddha what is a great man, and the Buddha says it is someone whose mind has been freed by developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Nālanda
blurb: Sāriputta boldly claims that no-one has ever, or will ever, be more enlightened than the Buddha. He admits that he cannot read the minds of all the Buddhas, but he understands a principle of the Dhamma: all those who become awakened do so by giving up the five hindrances, practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, and developing the seven awakening factors.

title: Cunda
blurb: Sāriputta dies of illness, and the novice Cunda together with Ānanda take his bowl and robes and report the sad news to the Buddha. The Buddha dispels Ānanda’s sadness by speaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Celam
blurb: After the passing of Sāriputta and Moggallāna (whose actual death is unrecorded in the canon), the Buddha says the Saṅgha looks empty; yet he is not sad.

title: Bāhiya, hay Bàhika
blurb: When Venerable Bāhiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.

title: Uttiya
blurb: When Venerable Uttiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.

title: Bậc Thánh
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the end of suffering.

title: Phạm Thiên
blurb: Just after the Buddha’s awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supports the Buddha’s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence.

title: Sedaka, hay Ekantaka
blurb: Two acrobats discuss whether one should support the other, or the other way around. The Buddha says they should support each other. In the same way we should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation both for one’s own benefit and to protect others.

title: Quốc Ðộ (hay Ekantaka)
blurb: A parable that sets up an impossible challenge: to walk between a popular performer and the crowd jostling to see her, carrying a bowl of oil filled to the brim, while a man with a drawn sword waits to chop off your head if you spill a drop. That’s mindfulness!

title: Chánh Niệm
blurb: At Ambapālī’s mango grove, the Buddha teaches the mendicants about the four kinds of mindfulness meditation and the practice of situational awareness.

title: Giới
blurb: Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the ethical virtues encouraged by the Buddha—what is their purpose? To develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Trú
blurb: Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the conditions under which the true teaching lasts long or does not last long after the Buddha’s passing. Ānanda says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.

title: Tổn Giảm (Parihànam)
blurb: Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the conditions under which the true teaching declines. Ānanda says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.

title: Thanh Tịnh
blurb: A simple teaching on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Bà La Môn
blurb: A brahmin asks the Buddha about the conditions under which the true teaching lasts long or does not last long after the Buddha’s passing. The Buddha says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.

title: Một Phần
blurb: Sāriputta asks Anuruddha what makes someone a trainee. It is someone who has partly developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Hoàn Toàn (Samattam)
blurb: Sāriputta asks Anuruddha what makes someone an adept. It is someone who has fully developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Thế Giới
blurb: Anuruddha claims to have developed the various direct knowledges by practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Sirivaḍḍha
blurb: When the householder Sirivaḍḍha is sick, Ānanda visits him and encourages him to practice mindfulness meditation. But he has already developed them, and abandoned the five lower fetters.

title: Mànadinna
blurb: When the householder Mānadinna is sick, Ānanda visits him and encourages him to practice mindfulness meditation. But he has already developed them, and abandoned the five lower fetters.

title: Tỷ Kheo
blurb: When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha issues an unexpected rebuke. Evidently the mendicant had been badly behaved; but now, he insists, he is sincere. The Buddha relents, and teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.

title: Chưa Từng Ðược Nghe
blurb: The full knowledge of mindfulness meditation was not learned before the Buddha.

title: Ly Tham
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to peace.

title: Thối Thất (Viraddha)
blurb: Someone who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the noble path.

title: Tu Tập
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead from the near to the far shore.

title: Niệm
blurb: Mindfulness is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. Situational awareness is watching the arising and passing of feelings, thoughts, and perceptions.

title: Chánh Trí
blurb: When the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed, perfection or non-return may be expected.

title: Ước Muốn (Chandam)
blurb: Developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, desire is abandoned.

title: Liễu Tri
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to realizing the deathless.

title: Tu Tập
blurb: The development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Phân Biệt
blurb: The Buddha teaches the simple passage on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation and an advanced analysis, which involves contemplating them as impermanent.

title: Sālā
blurb: Newly ordained mendicants should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation; trainees are practicing them, and perfected ones have perfected the practice.

title: Bất Tử
blurb: Develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, don’t let the deathless be lost.

title: Tập Khởi
blurb: The causes for the origination and cessation of the phenomena upon which the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are grounded.

title: Con Ðường
blurb: The Buddha tells the mendicants how, just after his awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supported the Buddha’s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence

title: Niệm
blurb: Be mindful by developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Ðống Thiện
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are a heap of the skillful.

title: Pātimokkha
blurb: When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on restraint in the code of monastic rules.

title: Ác Hành
blurb: When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on good bodily, verbal, and mental conduct.

title: Thân Hữu
blurb: You should encourage your friends to practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Các Cảm Thọ
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation help to understand the three feelings.

title: Các Lậu Hoặc
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation help to give up the defilements.

title: Một Ðống Thiện
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are a complete heap of what is skillful.

title: Con Chim Ưng (Sakunagghi)
blurb: The parable of the quail and the hawk. When the quail ventured outside her ancestral territory, she became vulnerable. And what is a mendicant’s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Con Vượn
blurb: The parable of the foolish monkey who gets trapped in tar when it ventures outside its ancestral territory. And what is a mendicant’s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Người Ðầu Bếp
blurb: The parable of the cook. They present different kinds of dishes to the king, and observe which the king likes. In the same way, a mendicant observes why their meditation succeeds or fails. When the four kinds of mindfulness meditation succeeds it leads to giving up hindrances and entering immersion.

title: Bệnh
blurb: The Buddha decides to spend his final rains retreat at Vesālī in Beluvagāmaka. During the retreat he becomes very ill, but later recovers. Ānanda wonders who will guide the Saṅgha when the Buddha dies, but the Buddha says they should be their own refuge, grounded on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Phân Tích
blurb: The Buddha gives a detailed explanation of each of the five faculties.

title: Thanh Tịnh
blurb: The five faculties are faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

title: Chứng Ðược
blurb: The Buddha explains the five faculties in terms of how they are obtained.

title: Tóm Tắt (1)
blurb: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments.

title: Tóm Tắt (2)
blurb: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. A difference in faculties leads to a difference in fruits.

title: Tóm Tắt (3)
blurb: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. The faculties are not barren.

title: Rộng Thuyết (1)
blurb: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments.

title: Rộng Thuyết (2)
blurb: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. A difference in faculties leads to a difference in fruits.

title: Rộng Thuyết (3)
blurb: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. The faculties are not barren.

title: Thực Hành (Hướng: Patipanno)
blurb: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. One who has none of them at all is an outsider.

title: Tịch Tịnh (Upasanno)
blurb: Someone who develops the faculties is said to be equipped with faculties.

title: Ðoạn Tận Các Lậu Hoặc
blurb: The five faculties lead to the ending of defilements in this very life.

title: Dự Lưu (1)
blurb: One who understands the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a stream-enterer.

title: Không Có Tái Sanh, hay Người Có Trí
blurb: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he realized the five faculties.

title: Mạng
blurb: Three faculties: femininity, masculinity, and vitality.

title: Chánh Lý
blurb: Three faculties relating to stages in the realization of awakening.

title: Nhứt Thắng Trí, hay Nhứt Chủng Tử
blurb: Depending on the strength of the five faculties, one is perfected, or reaches a lesser attainment.

title: Thanh Tịnh
blurb: Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

title: Dòng Nước Hay Dự Lưu
blurb: Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. One who understand these is a stream-enterer.

title: A-La-Hán (1)
blurb: Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. One who is freed by understanding these is perfected.

title: A-La-Hán hay Phật (2)
blurb: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he realized the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the six faculties.

title: Sa-Môn, Bà-La-Môn (1)
blurb: A true ascetic understands the six faculties in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Sa-Môn, Bà-La-Môn (2)
blurb: A true ascetic understands the six faculties in terms of the four noble truths.

title: Dự Lưu (2)
blurb: One who understands the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a stream-enterer.

title: Thanh Tịnh
blurb: Five faculties: pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

title: Dòng Nước
blurb: One who understands the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity is a stream-enterer.

title: A-La-Hán
blurb: One who is freed after understanding the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity is a perfected one.

title: Sa-Môn, Bà-La-Môn (1)
blurb: A true ascetic understands the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity in terms of the four noble truths.

title: Sa-Môn, Bà-La-Môn (2)
blurb: A true ascetic understands the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity in terms of the four noble truths.

title: Phân Tích (1)
blurb: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail.

title: Phân Tích (2)
blurb: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail. In addition, each is to be seen in one of the three feelings.

title: Phân Tích (3)
blurb: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail. In addition, each is to be seen in one of the three feelings.

title: Cây Quay Ra Lửa (Arani)
blurb: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity arise dependent on the appropriate contact, like sticks making fire.

title: Sanh
blurb: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are taught in a detailed exposition that treats them in an unusual order. The abandoning of each is related to the attainment of a particular meditative absorption.

title: A-La-Hán (1)
blurb: One who is freed after understanding the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a perfected one.

title: Già
blurb: When Ānanda sees the Buddha’s sense faculties fading, the Buddha speaks on the decrepitude of old age, including verses.

title: Bà-La-Môn Unnàbha
blurb: The brahmin Uṇṇābha points out that the five physical sense faculties do not share a common domain, so where do they come together? In the mind. Uṇṇābha pursues the teaching all the way to Nibbāna.

title: Sāketa
blurb: The Buddha discusses the five faculties and the five powers. They are like a river that flows around a central island. From one point of view they can be considered different, but from another they are just the same stream.

title: Pubbakoṭṭhaka (Ngôi nhà phía Ðông)
blurb: Sāriputta does not rely on faith in saying that the five faculties lead to the deathless, for he has seen this for himself.

title: Vườn Phía Ðông (1)
blurb: Having developed wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening, as wisdom fulfills the other faculties.

title: Vườn Phía Ðông (2)
blurb: Having developed wisdom and immersion a mendicant may declare their awakening.

title: Vườn Phía Ðông (3)
blurb: Having developed energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening.

title: Vườn Phía Ðông (4)
blurb: Having developed faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening.

title: Pindolo (Kẻ tìm tòi các đống rác)
blurb: Having developed mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom the mendicant Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja declared his awakening.

title: Tín, hay Ngôi Chợ
blurb: The Buddha asks Sāriputta whether a noble disciple doubts the Buddha. Not only does he have faith, replies Sāriputta, but the other faculties each come to be developed in turn.

title: A-La-Hán (2)
blurb: One who is freed after understanding the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a perfected one.

title: Sālā
blurb: Just as the lion is the king of beasts, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.

title: Mallikà
blurb: Only when noble wisdom arises do the other four faculties become stable.

title: Hữu Học
blurb: How does someone recognize that they are a trainee? By understanding the four noble truths and the five faculties. But only a perfected one fully embodies these qualities.

title: Vết Chân
blurb: Just as all footprints fit into that of an elephant, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.

title: Lõi Cây
blurb: Just as red sandalwood is the best of fragrances, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.

title: Y Chỉ , An Trú
blurb: When established in diligence, the five faculties come to be developed.

title: Phạm Thiên
blurb: Just after the Buddha’s awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supports the Buddha’s reflection that the five faculties lead to the deathless.

title: Hang Con Gấu
blurb: A mendicant honors the Realized One and his teaching for the sake of the supreme sanctuary.

title: Sanh (1)
blurb: The five faculties only arise in the dispensation of a Realized One.

title: Sanh (2)
blurb: The five faculties only arise in the training of a Holy One.

title: Sa Môn, Bà La Môn (1)
blurb: A true ascetic understands the five faculties in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.

title: Liễu Tri hay Con Ðường Ra Khỏi
Sa Môn, Bà La Môn (2)
blurb: A true ascetic understands the five faculties in terms of the four noble truths.

title: Cần Phải Quán
blurb: Each of the five faculties should be seen in a particular set of teachings.

title: Phân Biệt
blurb: The Buddha gives a short explanation of each of the five faculties.

title: Cetiya (Ðền thờ)
blurb: The Buddha says he could live to the end of the eon due to developing the four bases of psychic power. But Ānanda doesn’t get the hint.

title: Bờ Bên Kia
blurb: The four bases of psychic power lead from the near to the far shore.

title: Trước hay Nhân
blurb: The Buddha recounts the process of inquiry that lead to him fully understanding the four bases of psychic power, as well as the powers that result from that.

title: Quả Lớn
blurb: The four bases of psychic power are very beneficial.

title: Ý Muốn (Chando)
blurb: An analysis of the four bases of psychic power showing how enthusiasm, energy, higher consciousness, and inquiry work in the context of advanced meditation.

title: Moggallāna
blurb: When lazy monks were wasting time, the Buddha asks Moggallāna to stir them up. He shakes with his toe the large building in which they were staying, terrifying the monks. They sought refuge in the Buddha, and he taught them the four bases of psychic power.

title: Bà-La-Môn
blurb: Ānanda explains to the brahmin Uṇṇābha that the spiritual path is lived to give up desire through the the four bases of psychic power. But Uṇṇābha says this is a contradiction, as desire is itself one of the four bases. Ānanda resolves the contradiction with the simile of a man walking to a park.

title: Sa-Môn, Bà-La-Môn hay Ðại Thần Thông
blurb: Whatever ascetics are of great spiritual power have developed the four bases of psychic power.

title: Sa-Môn, Bà-La-Môn hay Kiêu Mạn
blurb: Whatever ascetics are of great spiritual power have developed the four bases of psychic power.

title: Tỷ-Kheo
blurb: It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that a mendicant ends the defilements.

title: Thuyết Pháp hay Tu Tập
blurb: The Buddha distinguishes between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.

title: Phân Tích
blurb: The Buddha teaches the bases for psychic power and analyzes them in detail.

title: Thối Thất
blurb: One who has neglected the four bases of psychic power has neglected the path to the end of suffering.

title: Ðạo
blurb: Before his awakening, the Buddha reflected on the path for developing the bases of psychic power.

title: Hòn Sắt
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha whether he travels to the Brahmā realm in a mind-made body or in a physical body.

title: Tỷ kheo
blurb: It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that a mendicant ends the defilements.

title: Thanh Tịnh
blurb: The four bases for psychic power are desire, energy, higher mind, and inquiry.

title: Quả (1)
blurb: The four bases for psychic power lead to perfection or once-return.

title: Quả (2)
