blurb: The four bases for psychic power lead to seven benefits; perfection or one of the lesser attainments.

title: Ānanda (1)
blurb: The Buddha explains to Ānanda the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.

title: Ānanda (2)
blurb: The Buddha explains to Ānanda the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.

title: Tỷ-Kheo (1)
blurb: The Buddha explains to several mendicants the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.

title: Tỷ-Kheo (2)
blurb: The Buddha explains to several mendicants the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.

title: Thánh
blurb: The four bases of psychic power are noble and emancipating.

title: Moggallāna
blurb: Moggallāna is so very powerful due to developing the four bases for psychic power.

title: Như Lai
blurb: The Realized One is so very powerful due to developing the four bases for psychic power.

title: Yếm Ly
blurb: The four bases of psychic power lead to dispassion.

title: Một Phần
blurb: Those who have developed psychic powers in part have developed the four bases of psychic power in part.

title: Toàn Diện
blurb: Those who have developed psychic powers in full have developed the four bases of psychic power in full.

title: Tỷ Kheo
blurb: Whatever mendicants realize perfection do so by developing the four bases of psychic power.

title: Phật hay A-La-Hán
blurb: It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that the Realized One is called a Buddha.

title: Trí
blurb: On the night of his awakening, understanding and vision came to the Buddha regarding the four bases of psychic power.

title: Bị Trọng Bệnh, hay Bệnh
blurb: Some mendicants ask Anuruddha how he remains equanimous even though ill. He replies that it is due to the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Ðộc Cư (1)
blurb: While meditating alone, Anuruddha reflected that one who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the path to the end of suffering. Moggallāna reads his mind and visits to question him on this. Anuruddha speaks of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation internally and externally, in terms of origin and cessation, and developing power over perceptions.

title: Một Ngàn
blurb: By developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation Anuruddha surveys a thousand world systems.

title: Ðộc Cư (2)
blurb: While meditating alone, Anuruddha reflected that one who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the path to the end of suffering. Moggallāna reads his mind and visits to question him on this. Anuruddha speaks of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation internally and externally.

title: Sutanu
blurb: When some mendicants ask Anuruddha how he attained such higher knowledge, he replies it is from developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Katakì (1)
blurb: Sāriputta and Moggallāna ask Anuruddha what a trainee mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Kantakì (2)
blurb: Sāriputta and Moggallāna ask Anuruddha what an adept mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Kantakì (3)
blurb: When Sāriputta ask Anuruddha how he attained such higher knowledge, he replies it is from developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Ái Tận
blurb: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the ending of craving.

title: Nhà Bằng Cây Sāla
blurb: Even if kings beg them to disrobe, a mendicant who has developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation is unmoved. Their mind flows to Nibbāna like the Ganges to the sea.

title: Tất Cả, hay Ambapàla
blurb: Sāriputta asks why Anuruddha looks so peaceful, and he replies it is due to developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Kimbila
blurb: When the Buddha asks Venerable Kimbila about breath meditation, he is unable to answer. At Ānanda’s urging, the Buddha explains in detail.

title: Một Pháp
blurb: Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed by going into seclusion, establishing mindfulness on the breath, and proceeding through sixteen stages.

title: Icchànangala
blurb: The Buddha goes on a three month retreat, and later says that during that time he mostly practiced breath meditation.

title: Nghi Ngờ
blurb: Venerable Lomasavaṅgīsa explains to Mahānāma that the difference between a trainee and the Realized One is that the trainees practice to give up the hindrances, whereas the Realized One has already ended all defilements.

title: Ānanda (1)
blurb: Answering Ānanda, the Buddha explains how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.

title: Ānanda (2)
blurb: The Buddha explains to Ānanda how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.

title: Tỷ-Kheo (1)
blurb: Answering some mendicants, the Buddha explains how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.

title: Tỷ-Kheo (2)
blurb: The Buddha explains to some mendicants how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.

title: Giác Chi
blurb: Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed together with the seven factors of awakening.

title: Thanh Tịnh
blurb: Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed by going into seclusion, establishing mindfulness on the breath, and proceeding through sixteen stages.

title: Quả
blurb: Breath meditation is very beneficial. When developed it leads to perfection or non-return.

title: Quả (2)
blurb: Breath meditation is very beneficial. When developed it leads to perfection or one of the lesser attainments.

title: Ariṭṭha
blurb: When the Buddha asks Venerable Ariṭṭha about breath meditation, his answer, while not incorrect, does not do full justice to the practice.

title: Kappina
blurb: The Buddha sees Venerable Mahākappina meditating nearby and points out that his steadiness and tranquility are due to practicing breath meditation.

title: Ngọn Ðèn
blurb: Before his awakening the Buddha generally practiced breath meditation, which kept him alert and peaceful and led to the ending of defilements. One who wishes for any of the higher fruits of the renunciate life should practice the same way.

title: Vesālī
blurb: The Buddha taught the meditation on the ugliness of the body, then left to go on retreat. However, many monks, misconstruing the teachings, ending up killing themselves. The Buddha taught breath meditation as a peaceful and pleasant abiding.

title: Ngôi Nhà Bằng Gạch (3)
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Vua
blurb: Even a universal monarch may have a bad rebirth, but someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is freed from such destinies.

title: Một Ngàn
blurb: The Buddha teaches a thousand nuns the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Các Bà La Môn
blurb: The Buddha contrasts a foolish brahmanical ritual called “going upwards” with the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Ānanda
blurb: Sāriputta asks Ānanda how many things are given up and how many things possessed by the stream-enterer.

title: Ác Thú (1)
blurb: A noble disciple has transcended fears of a bad rebirth.

title: Ác Thú (2)
blurb: A noble disciple has transcended fears of a bad rebirth.

title: Thân Hữu (1)
blurb: You should encourage your friends in the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Bạn Bè Thân Hữu (2)
blurb: You should encourage your friends in the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Du Hành Chư Thiên
blurb: Moggallāna visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Thăm Viếng Chư Thiên (1)
blurb: Moggallāna visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Thăm Viếng Chư Thiên (2)
blurb: The Buddha visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Thể Nhập
blurb: Someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is a stream-enterer, destined for awakening.

title: Mahānāma (1)
blurb: Mahānāma the Sakyan expresses his fear that if he dies unmindful he may go to a bad rebirth. The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has long practiced the Dhamma.

title: Mahānāma (2)
blurb: Mahānāma the Sakyan expresses his fear that if he dies unmindful he may go to a bad rebirth. The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Godhà hay Mahānāma (3)
blurb: Mahānāma and Godhā the Sakyans discuss whether a stream-enterer has three or four factors. They go to the Buddha to settle it, and Mahānāma testifies to his faith.

title: Sarakàni, hay Saranàni (1)
blurb: When Sarakāni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mahānāma that Sarakāni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.

title: Sarakàni hay Saranàri (2)
blurb: When Sarakāni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mahānāma that Sarakāni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.

title: Ác Giới, hay Anāthapiṇḍika (1)
blurb: When the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, Sāriputta reminds him of his considerable accomplishments in the Dhamma, analyzing stream-entry in ten factors, at which Anāthapiṇḍika recovers. Later he invited Sāriputta and Ānanda for a meal, and Sāriputta thanked him with verses.

title: Ác Giới, hay Anāthapiṇḍika (2)
blurb: When the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, Ānanda reminds him of the four factors of stream-entry, which Anāthapiṇḍika claims to possess.

title: Hận Thù, hay Anāthapiṇḍika (3)
blurb: A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.

title: Sợ Hãi, hay Vị Tỷ-Kheo
blurb: A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.

title: Lichavi, hay Nandaka
blurb: The Buddha teaches the four factors of stream-entry to Nandaka, the minister of the Licchavis. When his servant tells him it is time for his ritual bath, he says that the inner bathing of the Dhamma is enough.

title: Dìghàvu
blurb: The lay follower Dīghāvu is ill and he asks for the Buddha to visit. Dīghāvu confirms that he possesses the four factors of stream-entry and in addition six contemplations leading to insight. Yet he is still worried that his father will miss him when he dies.

title: Sung Mãn (1)
blurb: The four factors of stream-entry—with ethics as the fourth—are streams of merit.

title: Sung Mãn (2)
blurb: The four factors of stream-entry—with generosity as the fourth—are streams of merit.

title: Sung Mãn (3)
blurb: The four factors of stream-entry—with wisdom as the fourth—are streams of merit.

title: Con Ðường Của Chư Thiên (1)
blurb: The four factors of stream-entry are footprints of the gods.

title: Con Ðường Của Chư Thiên (2)
blurb: The four factors of stream-entry are footprints of the gods, for the gods hold non-violence as supreme.

title: Ði Ðến Bạn Bè
blurb: When a person possesses the four factors of stream-entry, the gods regard them as similar to themselves.

title: Mahānāma
blurb: The Buddha explains to Mahānāma what is a lay follower, what is a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower accomplished in faith, generosity, and wisdom.

title: Mưa
blurb: Like rain falling on the mountain top, the four factors of stream-entry flow on to the ending of defilements.

title: Kàli
blurb: Kāḷigodhā the Sakyan lady confirms to the Buddha that she possesses the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Nandiyasakkasutta
blurb: Someone who completely lacks the four factors of stream-entry is an ordinary person. But even a stream-enterer may be negligent if they do not make further effort in meditation.

title: Sāriputta (1)
blurb: Sāriputta explains to Ānanda that someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is a stream-enterer, destined for awakening.

title: Sung Mãn (1)
blurb: The four factors of stream-entry—with ethics as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.

title: Sung Mãn (2)
blurb: The four factors of stream-entry—with generosity as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.

title: Sung Mãn (3)
blurb: The four factors of stream-entry—with wisdom as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.

title: Rất Giàu Hay Giàu (1)
blurb: A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is said to be prosperous.

title: Rất Giàu Hay Giàu (2)
blurb: A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is said to be prosperous.

title: Tỷ-Kheo Hay Thanh Tịnh
blurb: A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.

title: Nandiya
blurb: A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.

title: Bhaddiya
blurb: A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.

title: Mahānāma
blurb: A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.

title: Phần
blurb: Four factors for stream-entry: association with good people, hearing the teaching, proper attention, and right practice.

title: Sāriputta (2)
blurb: The Buddha asks Sāriputta about the four factors for stream-entry: association with good people, hearing the teaching, proper attention, and right practice. He also defines the “stream” and the “stream-enterer”.

title: Với Bài Kệ
blurb: A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer. With verses.

title: An Cư Mùa Mưa
blurb: When a monk comes from Sāvatthī to Kapilavatthu, the Sakyans visit him and ask as to the health of the Buddha and the Saṅgha. Then they ask what the monk has learned. He replies that the number of perfected ones is few, and those on lower levels of attainment are greater in number.

title: Dhammadinna
blurb: The lay follower Dhammadinna leads a group of 500 to visit the Buddha. He encourages them to study deep discourses, but they protest that they don’t have enough time. So the Buddha encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Bị Bệnh
blurb: Mahānāma asks the Buddha how a lay follower should teach a wise lay follower who is ill. He should first be encouraged in the four factors of stream-entry, and then urged to let go of attachments, until he realizes full freedom.

title: Bốn Quả (1)
blurb: Association with good people, hearing the teaching, proper attention, and right practice lead to the fruit of stream-entry.

title: Các Người Thợ Mộc (Thapataye)
blurb: After the rainy season, the chamberlains Isidatta and Purāṇa hear that the Buddha is approaching and go to see him. They describe their joy at knowing when the Buddha is approaching, and speak of their special duties guarding the royal harem. The Buddha says they have four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha; and here generosity rather than ethics as the final factor.

title: Những Người Ở Veludvàra
blurb: The brahmin householders of Bamboo Gate ask the Buddha how to live well in the home. The Buddha teaches them seven principles they can apply to themselves, which are practical applications of the Golden Rule. Someone with these seven principles and the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.

title: Giảng Ðường Bằng Gạch (1)
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Giảng Ðường Bằng Gạch (2)
blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.

title: Lời Nói
blurb: Don’t gossip. Instead, talk about the four noble truths.

title: Ðịnh
blurb: Mendicants should develop immersion so as to understand the four noble truths: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

title: Như Lai Thuyết (1)
blurb: The famous first discourse, taught at Varanasi to the group of five ascetics. It begins by rejecting the extremes of asceticism and indulgence and recommends the middle way of the eightfold path. Then it defines the four noble truths and analyzes them in twelve aspects. It ends with Venerable Kondañña becoming the first person apart from the Buddha to realize the Dhamma.

title: Như Lai Thuyết (2)
blurb: All Realized Ones understand the four noble truths in their twelve aspects.

title: Uẩn
blurb: The four noble truths are defined, with the five aggregates under the truth of suffering.

title: Xứ
blurb: The four noble truths are defined, with the six sense fields under the truth of suffering.

title: Thọ Trì (1)
blurb: The Buddha asks the mendicants how they remember the four noble truths.

title: Thọ Trì (2)
blurb: The Buddha asks the mendicants how they remember the four noble truths.

title: Vô Minh
blurb: Ignorance is not knowing the four noble truths.

title: Minh
blurb: Understanding is knowing the four noble truths.

title: Thi Thiết (Sankàsanà)
blurb: Each of the four noble truths has innumerable implications.

title: Như Thật (Tathà)
blurb: Each of the four noble truths is real, not otherwise.

title: Thiền Tịnh (Patisallàna)
blurb: Mendicants should develop seclusion so as to understand the four noble truths.

title: Minh (1)
blurb: It is because of not understanding the four noble truths that both the Buddha and others have wandered for so long in transmigration. With verses.

title: Minh (2)
blurb: True ascetics understand the four noble truths. With verses.

title: Chánh Ðẳng Giác
blurb: The Realized One is called the Buddha because he understands the four noble truths.

title: A-La-Hán
blurb: All Buddhas become awakened through the four noble truths.

title: Ðoạn Tận Các Lậu Hoặc
blurb: Only by knowing and seeing the four noble truths are the defilements ended.

title: Thân Hữu
blurb: You should encourage your friends in the four noble truths.

title: Như Thật
blurb: The four noble truths is real, not otherwise, that is why they are noble.

title: Thế Giới
blurb: In this world, the Realized One is the noble one, that is why the four truths are noble.

title: Cần Phải Liễu Tri Hay Thắng Tri
blurb: The first truth is to be understood; the second is to be given up; the third is to be realized; and the fourth is to be developed.

title: Gavampati
blurb: Some mendicants are discussing whether the four truths are necessarily seen together. Venerable Gavampati asserts that he has learned it from the Buddha that they are: if you see one, you see them all.

title: Thiện Nam Tử (1)
blurb: Members of good families go forth to understand the four noble truths.

title: Simsapà
blurb: In a siṁsapā grove, the Buddha holds up a handful of leaves, and compares it to all the leaves in the forest. So too, he has taught the four noble truths, which is only a fraction of what he knows.

title: Cây Keo (Khandira)
blurb: Just as it’s impossible to keep water in a basket of pine needles, it’s impossible to end suffering without penetrating the four noble truths.

title: Cái Gậy
blurb: Beings who have not seen the four noble truths roam on from one birth to another, like a stick thrown end to end.

title: Khăn Ðầu
blurb: Even more than if your clothes are on fire, you should make an effort to understand the four noble truths.

title: Một Trăm Cây Thương (Sattisata)
blurb: Even more than if you’re being tortured with spikes, you should make an effort to understand the four noble truths.

title: Sanh Loại (Pànà)
blurb: The small creatures in the ocean are greater in number than all the foliage in the jungles of India. Still, your rebirths are more than this.

title: Ví Dụ Mặt Trời (1)
blurb: As the dawn precedes the sunrise, right view precedes the penetration of the four noble truths.

title: Ví Dụ Mặt Trời (2)
blurb: As long as there are no sun and moon, the world is in darkness. So too, as long as the Realized One has not arisen and declared the four noble truths, the world is in darkness.

title: Cột Trụ (Indakhilo)
blurb: One who has not seen the four noble truths is as feeble as a tuft of cotton wool, while one who has seen them is like a deep-rooted pillar.

title: Tranh Luận
blurb: No-one can refute you if you are well grounded in the four noble truths.

title: Thiện Nam Tử (2)
blurb: Members of good families go forth to penetrate the four noble truths.

title: Tư Duy
blurb: The Buddha tells the curious tale of a man who sat by a lotus pond to speculate about the world, and saw an army enter a lotus stalk. He thought he was going mad. The Buddha said that no, the army was real. Nevertheless, you should not speculate about such things, but should reflect on the four noble truths.

title: Vực Thẳm
blurb: The Buddha takes the mendicants to a steep precipice, and points out that those who do not understand the four noble truths fall into a still deeper precipice.

title: Nhiệt Não
blurb: The Buddha speaks of a hell called the great inferno, and points out that those who do not understand the four noble truths fall into a still fiercer inferno.

title: Nhà Có Nóc Nhọn
blurb: Just as it’s impossible to climb the upper floor without building the lower floors first, it’s impossible to end suffering without penetrating the four noble truths.

title: Chiggala (1) (Lỗ khóa hay sợi lông)
blurb: Ānanda sees Licchavi youths shoot arrows through keyholes. But seeing the four noble truths is even harder.

title: Hắc Ám
blurb: Interstellar space is dark and empty; but not seeing the four noble truths is even worse.

title: Lỗ Khóa (2)
blurb: A blind turtle would put its head through a yoke with a hole in it floating in the ocean sooner than someone in the lower realms would be reborn as a human.

title: Lỗ Khóa (3)
blurb: A blind turtle would put its head through a yoke with a hole in it floating in the ocean sooner than someone in the lower realms would be reborn as a human.

title: Núi Sineru (1) (Tu Di)
blurb: As seven bits of gravel are smaller than Mount Sineru, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Núi Sineru (2) (Tu Di)
blurb: As seven bits of gravel are smaller than Mount Sineru, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Sa-Môn, Bà-La-Môn (1)
blurb: True ascetics understand the four noble truths.

title: Ðầu Móng tay
blurb: As a bit of dirt under a nail compared to the whole earth, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Ao Hồ
blurb: As a drop of water on a blade of grass compared to a massive dam, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Hợp Dòng (Sambhejja) (1)
blurb: As a few drops of water compared to the confluence of great rivers, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Hợp Dòng (2)
blurb: As a few drops of water compared to confluence of the great rivers, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Quả Ðất (1)
blurb: As a few jujube seeds compared to the great earth, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Quả Ðất (2)
blurb: As a few jujube seeds compared to the great earth, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Biển (1)
blurb: As a few drops of water compared to the ocean, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Biển (2)
blurb: As a few drops of water compared to the ocean, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Ví Dụ Với Núi (1)
blurb: As seven bits of gravel are smaller than the Himalayas, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Ví Dụ Với Núi (2)
blurb: As seven bits of gravel are smaller than the Himalayas, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.

title: Sa-Môn, Bà-La-Môn (2)
blurb: True ascetics become awakened through understanding the four noble truths.

title: Kính Trọng Các Bậc Lớn Tuổi
Các Tầm
blurb: Don’t think bad thoughts. Instead, think of the four noble truths.

title: Suy Tư (Cintà)
blurb: Don’t think in useless ways. Instead, reflect on the four noble truths.

title: Tranh Luận (Viggàhikà)
blurb: Don’t argue. Instead, converse on the four noble truths.

title: Sát Hại, Trộm Cắp, Cướp Phá
Āḷavakasutta
blurb: A yakkha challenges the Buddha with riddles and threatens to “hurl out his mind, rip open his heart, or hurl him across the River Ganges” if he doesn’t solve the riddles to the yakkha’s satisfaction.

title: Uragasutta
blurb: One who advances far along the path sloughs off the near shore and far, like a snake who sloughs off its skin.

title: Vijayasutta
blurb: Victory over the defilements through contemplation of the unattractiveness of the body.

title: Munisutta
blurb: The characteristics of the ideal sage, who finds happiness and security in living the solitary life. (This sutta is apparently one of the series of passages that King Asoka recommended for study and reflection by all practicing Buddhists.)

title: Dhaniyasutta
blurb: A poetic dialogue contrasting the wealth and security of lay life with the wealth and security of a person who has lived the renunciate life to its culmination. If you have trouble relating to someone like Dhaniya who measures his wealth in cattle, then when reading this poem substitute stocks and bonds for cows and bulls, and economic downturn for rain.

title: Khaggavisāṇasutta
blurb: If you can’t find a good teacher, it’s better to wander alone.

title: Kasibhāradvājasutta
blurb: The Buddha answers a farmer who claims that monks do no useful work and so don’t deserve to eat.

title: Cundasutta
blurb: Four different types of contemplatives and how to recognize them.

title: Parābhavasutta
blurb: The various actions and attitudes that lead to spiritual decline.

title: Vasalasutta
blurb: Being an outcaste is a matter of behavior, not birth.

title: Kinh Lòng Từ
blurb: The practice of developing universal goodwill: the practices that form a foundation for the practice, the attitude of universal goodwill itself, and the steps that lead from goodwill to awakening.

title: Hemavatasutta
blurb: The Buddha explains to a yakkha how one crosses over the flood.

title: Uṭṭhānasutta
blurb: Get up! Don’t let the opportunity for practice pass you by.

title: Ratanasutta
blurb: The many treasures to be found in the Triple Gem.

title: Rāhulasutta
blurb: Rāhula reflects on the teachings he received from his father, the Buddha.

title: Nigrodhakappa (vaṅgīsa) sutta
blurb: Vaṅgīsa, the foremost poet among the Buddha’s disciples, praises the Buddha in verse.

title: Sammāparibbājanīyasutta
blurb: The sort of person who, having gone forth, is fit to wander through the world.

title: Dhammikasutta
blurb: The proper code of conduct for lay followers of the Dhamma.

title: Āmagandhasutta
blurb: People are defiled, not by eating meat, but by engaging in evil conduct.

title: Hirisutta
blurb: How to recognize a true friend.

title: Kinh Ðiềm Lành
blurb: A list of the types of skillful behavior that give blessings and protection.

title: Sūcilomasutta
blurb: Another yakkha challenges the Buddha with riddles and threatens to “hurl out his mind, rip open his heart, or hurl him across the River Ganges” if he doesn’t solve the riddles to the yakkha’s satisfaction.

title: Kapilasutta (dhammacariyasutta)
blurb: The Buddha encourages the monks to avoid monks who are evil in their desires.

title: Brāhmaṇadhammikasutta
blurb: How brahmans, through greed, abandoned the good principles of their ancestors.

title: Dhamma (nāvā) sutta
blurb: A good teacher, like a good boatman, is one who knows firsthand how to cross to the further shore.

title: Kiṁsīlasutta
blurb: The attitudes and behavior that enable one best to learn and benefit from the Dhamma.

title: Kokālikasutta
blurb: A follower of Devadatta slanders Ven. Sāriputta and Ven. Moggallāna and, after suffering a painful disease, falls into hell. The sutta then gives a graphic description of the sufferings awaiting him there.

title: Pabbajjāsutta
blurb: The young Bodhisatta (Buddha-to-be), soon after leaving home, explains why he refuses King Bimbisāra’s offer of a position in his court.

title: Nālakasutta
blurb: A sutta in two parts. The first part gives an account of events soon after the birth of the Bodhisatta. The second part describes the way of the sage.

title: Dvayatānupassanāsutta
blurb: Not all dualities are misleading. This sutta teaches ways to contemplate the duality of the origination and cessation of stress and suffering so as to reach awakening.

title: Padhānasutta
blurb: Māra attempts to dissuade the Bodhisatta from his path.

title: Subhāsitasutta
blurb: Four characteristics of well-spoken speech.

title: Pūraḷāsa (sundarikabhāradvāja) sutta
blurb: A brahman questions the Buddha to see if the latter deserves to receive the cake resulting from his sacrifice.

title: Māghasutta
blurb: What are the qualities of a recipient that produce the most merit from a gift?

title: Sabhiyasutta
blurb: A sutta dating from early in the Buddha’s teaching career. A wanderer, disappointed in the teachings he has received from other teachers, approaches the Buddha with his questions.

title: Kinh Sela
blurb: Sela the brahman praises the Buddha to see how the latter responds to praise.

title: Sallasutta
blurb: Death and loss are inevitable, but grief is not.

title: Vāseṭṭhasutta
blurb: Is one worthy of respect because of one’s birth, or because of one’s actions?

title: Purābhedasutta
blurb: How to live at peace.

title: Kāmasutta
blurb: The drawbacks of sensual desires.

title: Kalahavivādasutta
blurb: The Buddha is questioned on the source of quarrels and disputes, and on the highest level of spiritual attainment.

title: Cūḷabyūhasutta
blurb: If the truth is one, how should a person behave in a world where many different truths are taught?

title: Mahābyūhasutta
blurb: How to maintain freedom in a world full of disputes.

title: Tuvaṭakasutta
blurb: The attitudes and behavior of a monk training for the sake of total release.

title: Attadaṇḍasutta
blurb: The Buddha speaks in poignant terms of the saṁvega that led him to leave the household life. He concludes with recommendations for practice and a description of the person who has attained the goal of true peace and security.

title: Sāriputtasutta
blurb: When a monk, disaffected with the world, takes up the life of seclusion, what fears should he overcome? What dangers should he beware of? How should he train to blow away the impurities in his heart?

title: Guhaṭṭhakasutta
blurb: Those who remain attached to the body, to sensuality, and to their sense of “mine” will have a hard time freeing themselves from fear of death and from further becoming.

title: Duṭṭhaṭṭhakasutta
blurb: Freedom isn’t to be found by boasting of your precepts and practices or by debating your views.

title: Suddhaṭṭhakasutta
blurb: How to avoid the trap of letting go of one thing only to cling to something more subtle.

title: Paramaṭṭhakasutta
blurb: The conceit that comes from clinging to practices or views—even if they’re supreme—is a fetter preventing full freedom.

title: Jarāsutta
blurb: Life is short. Possessiveness brings grief. Freedom comes from abandoning any sense of “mine.”

title: Tissametteyyasutta
blurb: The drawbacks of falling away from the celibate life.

title: Pasūrasutta
blurb: The drawbacks of engaging in debates, for winners and losers alike.

title: Māgaṇḍiyasutta
blurb: Māgandiya offers the Buddha his daughter in marriage. The Buddha refuses and further subdues Māgandiya’s pride by describing a state of peace that Māgandiya doesn’t understand.

title: Todeyyamāṇavapucchā
blurb: How to recognize an emancipated person.

title: Vatthugāthā
blurb: A brahman teacher sends his students to the Buddha to see if the latter is truly awakened.

title: Kappamāṇavapucchā
blurb: What is the island above the flood of the great danger of birth?

title: Jatukaṇṇimāṇavapucchā
blurb: How does one abandon birth and aging?

title: Bhadrāvudhamāṇavapucchā
blurb: Bhadrāvudha asks the Buddha: How did you come to know the Dhamma?

title: Udayamāṇavapucchā
blurb: How to reach unbinding and bring consciousness to a halt.

title: Posālamāṇavapucchā
blurb: How to develop insight after mastering the perception of nothingness.

title: Mogharājamāṇavapucchā
blurb: How should one view the world so as to escape the king of Death?

title: Ajitamāṇavapucchā
blurb: A brahman questions the Buddha about mindfulness, discernment, and the cessation of name-and-form.

title: Tissametteyyamāṇavapucchā
blurb: Who in the world is truly contented, truly free, truly a great person?

title: Puṇṇakamāṇavapucchā
blurb: Birth and aging can be overcome, not through sacrificial rituals, but through training the mind to go beyond perturbation.

title: Mettagūmāṇavapucchā
blurb: How does one cross the flood of birth and old age, sorrow and grief?

title: Dhotakamāṇavapucchā
blurb: How can one become freed of all doubt?

title: Upasīvamāṇavapucchā
blurb: What support should one hold on to in order to cross over the flood of craving? Can an awakened person be described?

title: Nandamāṇavapucchā
blurb: Who deserves to be called a sage? Who has crossed over birth and aging?

title: Hemakamāṇavapucchā
blurb: How do you cross over entanglements in the world?

title: Bāhiyasutta
blurb: The ascetic Bāhiya becomes an arahant after receiving a brief teaching about adding nothing to sensory experience.

title: Paṭhamabodhisutta
blurb: The Buddha, soon after awakening, contemplates specific conditionality and dependent co-arising.

title: Dutiyabodhisutta
blurb: The Buddha, soon after awakening, contemplates specific conditionality and dependent co-arising.

title: Tatiyabodhisutta
blurb: The Buddha, soon after awakening, contemplates specific conditionality and dependent co-arising.

title: Huṁhuṅkasutta
blurb: A brahmin who recites the mystic syllable huṁ asks the Buddha who is the true brahmin.

title: Brāhmaṇasutta
blurb: The Buddha redefines the term “brahmin” to mean anyone, regardless of birth, who is awakened.

title: Mahākassapasutta
blurb: Ven. Mahā Kassapa chooses to go for alms among the poor rather than among the devas.

title: Ajakalāpakasutta
blurb: An awakened person has gone beyond fear.

title: Saṅgāmajisutta
blurb: A monk’s former wife tries to use their child to lure him back into the lay life.

title: Jaṭilasutta
blurb: The mind is cleansed and purified, not by ablutions, but by truth and rectitude.

title: Bhaddiyasutta
blurb: A former king, now monk, exclaims over the bliss of solitude.

title: Mucalindasutta
blurb: Shortly after the Buddha’s awakening, a dragon protects him from a storm.

title: Rājasutta
blurb: When monks have gathered, they shouldn’t spend their time gossiping about kings.

title: Daṇḍasutta
blurb: A lesson to young boys: If you don’t want to suffer from pain, don’t inflict pain on other beings.

title: Sakkārasutta
blurb: On how to deal with abusive language.

title: Upāsakasutta
blurb: The drawbacks of having.

title: Gabbhinīsutta
blurb: More drawbacks of having.

title: Ekaputtakasutta
blurb: The sorrow that comes from having those who are dear.

title: Suppavāsāsutta
blurb: After a long and difficult pregnancy, Suppavāsā invites the Buddha and the Sangha for a meal.

title: Visākhāsutta
blurb: The drawbacks of having to do business with kings.

title: Lokasutta
blurb: Shortly after awakening, the Buddha contemplates future rebirth.

title: Kammavipākajasutta
blurb: A monk meditates in pain engendered by past kamma but without being struck down by it.

title: Nandasutta
blurb: The Buddha makes a deal with his step-brother: Stay a monk, and you’ll be rewarded with nymphs in the next life.

title: Yasojasutta
blurb: A group of monks, rebuked by the Buddha, take it as an encouragement to reach awakening.

title: Sāriputtasutta
blurb: Ven. Sāriputta meditates, his mind as solid as rock.

title: Mahāmoggallānasutta
blurb: Ven. Mahā Moggallāna meditates.

title: Pilindavacchasutta
blurb: Some old habits die hard.

title: Sakkudānasutta
blurb: A deva-king disguises himself to give alms to Ven. Mahā Kassapa.

title: Piṇḍapātikasutta
blurb: The Buddha rebukes monks who are chatting about the agreeable things that one can encounter on almsround.

title: Sippasutta
blurb: More lessons in what monks should and shouldn’t talk about.

title: Sāriputtaupasamasutta
blurb: Ven. Sāriputta meditates.

title: Meghiyasutta
blurb: A monk leaves the Buddha to go into solitude, only to find his mind overcome by unskillful thoughts.

title: Uddhatasutta
blurb: The need to protect body and mind.

title: Gopālakasutta
blurb: A cowherd is murdered after presenting a meal to the Buddha and the Sangha.

title: Yakkhapahārasutta
blurb: A spirit gives Ven. Sāriputta a blow on the head.

title: Nāgasutta
blurb: The Buddha, hemmed in by his followers, goes into seclusion.

title: Piṇḍolasutta
blurb: Ven. Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja meditates.

title: Sāriputtasutta
blurb: Ven. Sāriputta meditates.

title: Sundarīsutta
blurb: Wanderers of other sects kill a woman and blame her murder on the Sangha.

title: Upasenasutta
blurb: Ven. Upasena Vaṅgantaputta contemplates: “Fortunate has been my life; fortunate will be my death.”

title: Cūḷapanthakasutta
blurb: Ven. Cūḷa Panthaka meditates.

title: Piyatarasutta
blurb: King Pasenadi asks his queen, “Is there anyone dearer to you than yourself?”

title: Appāyukasutta
blurb: Ven. Ānanda comments on how the Buddha’s mother died shortly after his birth.

title: Suppabuddhakuṭṭhisutta
blurb: A leper becomes a stream-enterer, dies, and is reborn as a deva.

title: Kumārakasutta
blurb: A lesson to young boys: If you don’t want to suffer from pain, don’t inflict pain on other beings.

title: Uposathasutta
blurb: Ven. Mahā Moggallāna expels a sham monk from a meeting of the Sangha.

title: Soṇasutta
blurb: A young man in a remote part of India is able to ordain only after many delays.

title: Kaṅkhārevatasutta
blurb: Ven. Revata meditates.

title: Saṁghabhedasutta
blurb: Devadatta announces that he will cause a split in the Sangha.

title: Sadhāyamānasutta
blurb: A group of youths jeer at the monks.

title: Uppajjantisutta
blurb: Other sectarians shine only as long as a Buddha hasn’t appeared in the world.

title: Āyusaṅkhārossajjanasutta
blurb: The Buddha relinquishes the forces that will keep him living.

title: Sattajaṭilasutta
blurb: How to know another person’s character.

title: Paccavekkhaṇasutta
blurb: The Buddha reflects on the unskillful qualities that he has abandoned.

title: Paṭhamanānātitthiyasutta
blurb: The blind people and the elephant.

title: Dutiyanānātitthiyasutta
blurb: Wanderers of other sects dispute over the self, pleasure, pain, and the nature of the world.

title: Tatiyanānātitthiyasutta
blurb: Wanderers of other sects dispute over the self, pleasure, pain, and the nature of the world.

title: Subhūtisutta
blurb: Ven. Subhūti meditates.

title: Gaṇikāsutta
blurb: Two factions fight over a courtesan.

title: Upātidhāvantisutta
blurb: Insects fly into the flames of lamps set out at night.

title: Utenasutta
blurb: Five hundred awakened women die in a fire.

title: Paṭhamalakuṇḍakabhaddiyasutta
blurb: A dwarf becomes an arahant.

title: Dutiyalakuṇḍakabhaddiyasutta
blurb: Ven. Sāriputta doesn’t realize that his listener has already become an arahant.

title: Paṭhamasattasutta
blurb: Attachment to sensual pleasures keeps you from crossing over the flood.

title: Dutiyasattasutta
blurb: Attachment to sensual pleasures keeps you trapped like a fish.

title: Aparalakuṇḍakabhaddiyasutta
blurb: Inner and outer beauty.

title: Taṇhāsaṅkhayasutta
blurb: Ven. Aññata Koṇḍañña meditates.

title: Papañcakhayasutta
blurb: The Buddha contemplates his own abandoning of the perceptions and categories of proliferation.

title: Kaccānasutta
blurb: Ven. Mahā Kaccāyana meditates.

title: Udapānasutta
blurb: Wanderers of other sects try to keep the Buddha from drinking the water in a well.

title: Dutiyadabbasutta
blurb: There’s no destination to describe for those rightly released.

title: Paṭhamanibbānapaṭisaṁyuttasutta
blurb: The nature of extinguishment.

title: Dutiyanibbānapaṭisaṁyuttasutta
blurb: On seeing extinguishment.

title: Tatiyanibbānapaṭisaṁyuttasutta
blurb: The escape from conditions is areal.

title: Catutthanibbānapaṭisaṁyuttasutta
blurb: Extinguishment as independence.

title: Cundasutta
blurb: The Buddha’s last meal.

title: Pāṭaligāmiyasutta
blurb: The rewards of virtue and of dedicating merit to the devas.

title: Dvidhāpathasutta
blurb: One of the Buddha’s attendants disobeys him.

title: Visākhāsutta
blurb: Lady Visākhā wishes for many grandchildren.

title: Paṭhamadabbasutta
blurb: Ven. Dabba Mallaputta performs a miracle on his death.
